SUPPLEMENTATION 
Supplements to this Code provide periodic updating through the removal and replacement of pages. This inter-leaf supplementation system requires that each page which is to be removed and replaced is identified so that the updating may be accurately accomplished and historically maintained. 
Instructions for supplementation are provided for each supplement, identified by Supplement number, date and inclusive ordinance numbers. The Instructions for posting the removal and replacement of pages must be followed and accomplished in sequence, with the most recent supplementation posted last. 
When supplementation is completed and the removal and replacement of all pages are accomplished, the Instruction sheet should be placed behind the Supplementation tab, with the most recent Instruction sheet on top. Previous Instructions should not be removed, so that the user may refer to this tab section to verify whether the code book is fully updated with all supplements included. 
The maintenance of a Municipal Code with all supplementation is an important activity which deserves close attention so that the value of the code is maintained as a fully comprehensive compilation of the legislative ordinances of the municipality. 
AMENDMENTS 
Amendments may be made to the Code by additions, revisions or deletions therefrom. Those changes may be made as follows: 
Additions : Additions may be made by ordinance to the Code as follows: 
The "Rocky Ford Municipal Code" is amended by the addition thereto of a new Section 2-2-90, which is to read as follows: 
(Set out full section number, title and contents) 
or if the location of the new section number or numbers is undetermined, the Code may be amended as follows: 
The "Rocky Ford Municipal Code" is amended by the addition of the following: 
(Set out section title and contents) 
Revisions : A revision of the Code may be accomplished as follows: 
Section 2-2-90 of the "Rocky Ford Municipal Code" is repealed in its entirety and readopted to read as follows: 
(Set out section number, title and entire contents of the readopted code section) 
or as follows: 
Section 2-2-90 of the "Rocky Ford Municipal Code" is amended to read as follows: 
(Set out section number, title and entire contents of the amended code section) 
Repeal : Sections, articles and chapters may be repealed as follows: 
Section 2-2-90 of the "Rocky FordMunicipal Code" is repealed in its entirety. 
MUNICIPAL CODE CORPORATION 
PREFACE 
The City of Rocky Ford, a statutory City, has published its Municipal Code in a format which features the following: 
The Table of Contents is the table containing each chapter and article title, with reference to page location. Preceding each chapter is a chapter table of contents, also identifying each article by the subject name provided. 
The three-place section numbering system places the chapter number first, followed by the article number and section number, separated by hyphens. Each section may be cited by the chapter, article and section number which are in sequence within each chapter. 
The open chapter and page numbering system creates reserved chapter and page numbers for expansion or revision of the code without undue complication when changes are made to the code by supplementation. 
The Code Comparison Table identifies the sources for the contents of the code. The Code Comparison Table identifies prior code sections and their location in the new code and provides ordinance numbers in chronological order and location by section number for the present code contents. Thus, if there is interest in determining whether a prior code section, an ordinance or a portion thereof, is contained within the code, the Code Comparison Table will provide that information. 
The Index provides references by common and legal terminology to the appropriate code sections. Cross references are provided with the Index when appropriate. 
Supplements to the code provide regular updating of the code to maintain it as a current compilation of all the legislation which has general and continuing effect. Without regular supplementation, the code would soon lose its usefulness as a complete source of the general law of the municipality. Supplementation is accomplished by the periodic publication of additions and amendments to the Code.

STATE OF - COLORADO 
CITY OF ROCKY FORD, COLORADO 
    ORDINANCE NO. 914 
    AN ORDINANCE OF THE CITY OF ROCKY FORD, COLORADO, ADOPTING BY REFERENCE AND ENACTING A NEW MUNICIPAL CODE FOR THE CITY OF ROCKY FORD; PROVIDING FOR THE REPEAL OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED THEREIN; PROVIDING FOR THE ADOPTION OF SECONDARY CODES BY REFERENCE; PROVIDING A PENALTY FOR THE VIOLATION THEREOF; PROVIDING FOR THE MANNER OF AMENDING SUCH CODE; AND PROVIDING WHEN SUCH CODE AND THIS ORDINANCE SHALL BECOME EFFECTIVE. 
    Be It Ordained by the City Council of the City of Rocky Ford, Colorado: 
(1)  The Model Traffic Code for Colorado , 2010 edition, published by the Colorado Department of Transportation, as adopted and amended in Section 8-1-10, et seq.; 
(2)  The Uniform Code for the Abatement of Dangerous Buildings , 1997 edition, published by the International Conference of Building Officials, as adopted in Section 18-8-10, et seq.; and 
(3)  The Energy Efficiency Construction and Renovation Standards for Nonresidential Buildings , adopted November 1977, published by the Colorado Office of State Planning and Budgeting, Board for Energy Efficient Nonresidential Building Standards, as adopted and amended in Section 18-9-10, et seq. 
Section  4. The following codes are hereby adopted by reference and incorporated in the Rocky Ford Municipal Code. One copy of each code is on file in the City Clerk's office: 
(1)  The International Building Code , 2012 edition, published by the International Code Council, Inc., as adopted and amended in Section 18-1-10, et seq.; 
(2)  The International Residential Code, 2012 edition, published by the International Code Council, Inc., as adopted in Section 18-2-10; 
(3)  The National Electrical Code , 2011 edition, published by the National Fire Protection Association, as adopted and amended in Section 18-3-10, et seq.; 
(4)  The International Mechanical Code , 2012 edition, published by the International Code Council, Inc., as adopted in Section 18-4-10; 
(5)  The International Plumbing Code , 2012 edition, published by the International Code Council, Inc., as adopted in Section 18-5-10; 
(6)  The International Fire Code , 2012 edition, published by the International Code Council, Inc., as adopted in Section 18-6-10; and 
(7)  The International Sign Code , 2012 edition, published by the International Code Council, Inc., as adopted in Section 18-7-10. 
(1) Sec. 1-4-20. General penalty for violation. (Chapter 1, General Provisions; Article 4, General Penalty) 
(a)  Whenever in this Code or any other ordinance of this City hereafter enacted or any section, rule or regulation prorogated under the provisions of this Code, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful in offense or misdemeanor or the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an offense or misdemeanor. Any person who violates or fails to comply with any provision of this Code, for which a different penalty is not specifically provided, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 or by imprisonment not exceeding one year, or by both such fine and imprisonment, except as hereinafter provided in Section 1-4-30. Such person may also be directed to serve community service, in addition to such penalty and/or imprisonment. In addition, such person shall pay all costs and expenses in the case, including attorney fees. 
(b)  Every day such violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. 
(2) Sec. 1-4-30. Application of penalties to juveniles. (Chapter 1, General Provisions; Article 4, General Penalty) 
    Every person who, at the time of commission of the offense, was at least ten but not yet 18 years of age, and who is subsequently convicted of or pleads guilty or nolo contendere to, a violation of any provision of this Code, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 per violation or count. Any voluntary plea of guilty or nolo contendere to the original charge or to a lesser or substituted charge shall subject the person so pleading to all fines and/or penalties applicable to the original charge. Nothing in this Section shall be construed to prohibit incarceration in an appropriate facility, at the time of charging, of a juvenile violating any section of this Code. 
(3) Sec. 1-4-40. Altering or tampering with Code; penalty. (Chapter 1, General Provisions; Article 4, General Penalty) 
    Any person who alters, changes or amends this Code, except in the manner prescribed in this Chapter, or who alters or tampers with this Code in any manner so as to cause the ordinances of the City to be misrepresented thereby, shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided by Section 1-4-20 hereof. 
(4) Sec. 1-4-50. Penalty for violations of ordinances adopted after adoption of Code. (Chapter 1, General Provisions; Article 4, General Penalty) 
    Any person who violates any provision of any ordinance of a permanent and general nature passed or adopted after adoption of this Code, either before or after it has been inserted in this Code by a supplement, shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided by Section 1-4-20 unless another penalty is specifically provided for the violation. 
(5) Sec. 2-4-90. Contempt power. (Chapter 2, Administration; Article 4, Municipal Court) 
(a)  When the Court finds any person to be in contempt, the Court may vindicate its dignity by imposing on the contemnor a fine not to exceed $300.00 and imprisonment not to exceed a term of ten days. 
(b)  In cases of indirect contempt, the alleged contemnor shall have all the rights, privileges, safeguards and protections of a defendant in a petty offense case, including but not limited to a formal written complaint, arraignment and trial by jury. 
(6) Sec. 2-4-100. Notice to appear or pay fine. (Chapter 2, Administration; Article 4, Municipal Court) 
(a)  Tender by a peace officer or the Code Enforcement Officer of a summons and complaint or a penalty assessment notice shall constitute notice to that person to appear in Municipal Court at the time and date specified or to pay the required fine and surcharge thereon. 
(b)  It is a violation of this Section for any person to fail to appear before the Municipal Court at the time and date specified in the summons and complaint or at any subsequent time and date to which the matter is continued or otherwise set by the Municipal Court, or to fail to pay the required fine, surcharge or costs. 
(c)  Any person convicted of violating this Section may be incarcerated for a period of time not to exceed 90 days or fined an amount not to exceed $300.00, or both. 
(7) Sec. 2-10-70. Willful retention of books. (Chapter 2, Administration; Article 10, Library Board) 
    A person who willfully retains any book, newspaper, magazine, pamphlet, manuscript or other property belonging in or to the public library or other educational institution for 30 days after notice in writing to return the same, given at the expiration of the time that, by the rules of such institution, such article or other property may be kept, shall be guilty of a violation and, upon conviction, shall be punished in accordance with the provisions of Section 1-4-20 of this Code. 
(8) Sec. 4-4-130. Violation; penalty. (Chapter 4, Revenue and Finance; Article 4, Use Tax) 
    It shall be a violation of this Article for any person who, by this Article, is required to make any return or pay any tax to fail or refuse to make any return or pay any tax required to be made or paid by this Article; to make any false or fraudulent return or any false statements in any return; to fail or refuse to make payment to the Finance Director, City Clerk or County Clerk of any taxes collected or due the City; or in any manner to evade the collection of any payment of the tax, or any part thereof, imposed by this Article; or for any person or purchaser to fail or refuse to pay such tax or evade the payment thereof or to aid or abet another in any attempt to evade the payment of the tax imposed by this Article. Any corporation or officer thereof making a false return or a return containing a false statement shall be guilty of a violation of this Article and shall be punished as set forth in Section 1-4-20 of this Code. 
(9) Sec. 4-5-50. Penalty clause. (Chapter 4, Revenue and Finance; Article 5, Occupational Tax) 
    If any officer, agent or manager of a telephone utility company which is subject to the provisions of this Article fails, neglects or refuses to make or file the annual statement of accounts provided in Section 4-5-30 above, said officer, agent, manager or person shall, on conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not less than $25.00 nor more than $300.00; provided that each day after said statement becomes delinquent, during which said officer, agent, manager or person fails, neglects or refuses to make and file such statement, shall be considered a separate and distinct offense. 
(10) Sec. 4-6-50. Penalty clause. (Chapter 4, Revenue and Finance; Article 6, Telephone Utility Occupation Tax) 
    If any officer, agent or manager of a telephone utility company which is subject to the provisions of this Article fails, neglects or refuses to make or file the annual statement of accounts provided in Section 4-6-30 above, said officer, agent, manager or person shall, on conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not less than $25.00 nor more than $300.00; provided that each time the officer, agent, manager or person fails, neglects or refuses to make and file such statement shall be considered a separate and distinct offense. 
(11) Sec. 5-5-330. Crimes and penalties. (Chapter 5, Franchises and Communication Systems; Article 5, Cable Television Franchise) 
(a)  Injury to property of Grantee . No person shall wrongfully or unlawfully injure the property of the Grantee. 
(b)  Intercepting signals of Grantee . No person shall wrongfully or unlawfully intercept the signals of the Grantee. If a wire, apparatus or other equipment of a cable television system has been altered or tampered with, a rebuttable presumption is created that the person lacking authorization of the cable system operator has created the condition as existing. 
(c)  Penalty . Any person violating any of the provisions of this Section shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine not to exceed $100.00 or imprisonment not exceeding 30 days. 
(12) Sec. 6-1-160. Violation, penalty. (Chapter 6, Business Licenses and Regulations; Article 1, Business Licenses) 
(a)  Each day that any person carries on, pursues, conducts or manages any business avocation or calling in the City without first obtaining a license therefor shall be deemed a separate offense, and such person may be convicted accordingly. 
(b)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this Article for which a fine or penalty is not herein specifically provided shall, on conviction, be fined in accordance with Section 1-4-20 of this Code. 
(13) Sec. 6-2-140. Suspension or revocation; fine. (Chapter 6, Business Licenses and Regulations; Article 2, Alcoholic Beverages) 
(a)  The City Council, acting as the Local Licensing Authority, shall have the authority to impose a fine in lieu of a suspension of a liquor license for all or a portion of the period of suspension under the following circumstances: 
(1)  The City Council has made a final decision to suspend the licensee's liquor license for a period of 14 days or less. 
(2)  Prior to the operative date of the suspension, the licensee petitions the City for permission to pay a fine in lieu of suspension. 
(3)  The City is satisfied that the following are met: 
a.  The public welfare and morals would not be impaired by permitting the retail licensee to operate during the period set for suspension and the payment of the fine will achieve the desired disciplinary purposes; 
b.  The books and records of the retail licensee are kept in such a manner that the loss of sales of alcoholic beverages which the retail licensee would have suffered had the suspension gone into effect can be determined with reasonable accuracy therefrom; and 
c.  The retail licensee has not had his or her license suspended or revoked, nor had any suspension stayed by payment of a fine, during the two years immediately preceding the date of the motion or complaint which has resulted in a final decision to suspend the retail license. 
(b)  The City may impose a fine of up to 20 percent of the retail licensee's estimated gross revenues from the sales of alcoholic beverages during the period of the proposed suspension; except that the fine shall be not less than $200.00 nor more than $5,000.00. All fines shall be paid in cash or certified funds, made payable to the City Clerk, and deposited in the general fund of the City. 
(c)  Upon payment of the fine pursuant to this Section, the City Council shall enter its further order permanently staying the imposition of the suspension. 
(d)  In connection with any petition pursuant to this Section, the authority of the City Council is limited to the granting of such stays as are necessary for it to complete its investigation and make its findings and, if it makes such findings, to the granting of an order permanently staying the imposition of the entire suspension or that portion of the suspension not otherwise conditionally stayed. 
(e)  If the City Council does not make the findings required in Subsection (a) above and does not order the suspension permanently stayed, the suspension shall go into effect on the operative date finally set by the City Council. 
(14) Sec. 6-2-230. Keg tagging requirements. (Chapter 6, Business Licenses and Regulations; Article 2, Alcoholic Beverages) 
(a)  Any retail liquor establishment selling alcoholic beverages by the keg within the City shall be required to affix to the keg, at the time of sale, a self-locking plastic identification seal. 
(b)  Any retail liquor establishment selling alcoholic beverages by the keg within the City shall be required at the time of sale to fill out an identifying form with information as to the purchaser's name, address, date of birth, driver's license number and date of sale. The Police Department shall provide the form. 
(c)  At the time of sale of any keg of alcoholic beverage, the retail liquor establishment shall be obligated to affix the seal, fill out the form and maintain those identifying records for purposes of inspection by the Police Department. 
(d)  Retail liquor outlets shall keep identifying forms for a period of six months, and said records shall be kept in a place open for inspection at all reasonable times at the request of the City. 
(e)  Any retail liquor outlet which fails to affix the plastic seal as required in Subsection (c) above, or to fill out the forms as required pursuant to Subsections (b) and (c), shall be in violation of this Section, and as such shall be subject to fines and penalties as authorized herein. 
(f)  Any owner or operator of any premises who, through act of omission or commission, fails to ensure that the owner's employees properly comply with this law, shall be guilty of violation of Subsections (b) and (c). 
(g)  It is unlawful for any person who has purchased alcoholic beverages by the keg within the City to remove the self-locking plastic identification seal required pursuant to Subsection (c). It shall not be a violation of this Subsection if the person removing the tag is an employee of an owner or operator of a retail liquor establishment or a representative of a vendor of wholesale alcoholic beverages, who removes the tag after the return of the keg to the place of retail establishment and after any deposit has been returned to the consumer. 
(h)  It is unlawful for any purchaser of a keg of alcoholic beverage to allow anyone to remove the fixed seal from the keg prior to its return to the retail liquor outlet which sold the keg. 
(i)  It is unlawful for any person to purchase a keg of alcoholic beverage pursuant to the terms of this Section, and to thereafter allow consumption of said alcoholic beverage by minors, unless said consumption is authorized and allowed pursuant to the laws of the State, as enumerated in Section 18-13-122, C.R.S. 
(j)  An owner, operator or employee of a retail liquor outlet who, upon receipt of a keg being returned by a consumer of the alcoholic beverage, shall inspect the returned keg, and, if the tag has been removed or tampered with in any way, the owner or operator shall immediately notify the Police Department of the same. It shall be unlawful for any owner, operator or employee to fail to notify the Police Department as required herein. 
(k)  It is unlawful for any person to be in possession of a keg of alcoholic beverage, wherein that keg was purchased within the City and the keg fails to have the appropriate self-locking plastic identification seal as required by Subsection (a) above. 
(l)  Any person who violates the provisions of this Section shall be subject to a minimum mandatory fine of $250.00 and a maximum fine of $1,000.00. 
(m)  The Police Department may use the penalty assessment procedure as provided in Section 16-2-201, C.R.S., for the enforcement of this Section. 
(15) Sec. 6-2-210. Minors in licensed establishments. (Chapter 6, Business Licenses and Regulations; Article 2, Alcoholic Beverages) 
(a)  Purpose . The purpose and intent of this Section is to prohibit minors from having access to or being on the premises of establishments where alcoholic beverages are sold for consumption on the premises at certain times. 
(b)  Prohibition . This Section shall pertain to any licensed premises. 
(1)  It is unlawful for any minor to be in or remain in or on any licensed premises from 11:00 p.m. to closing of the licensed premises for business that same night. 
(2)  It is unlawful for any licensee or his or her agents or employees to permit a minor to be in or remain in or on any licensed premises from 11:00 p.m. to closing of the licensed premises for business that same night. 
(c)  Exceptions . 
(1)  This Section shall not prohibit the minor children of the licensee or necessary employees of the licensee from being in or remaining in a licensed premises while the licensee or employee is actually working or performing. 
(2)  This Section shall not prohibit minors who are members of an entertainment group or the minor children of entertainment group members paid or employed by the licensee from being present in a licensed premises while the entertainment group is actually working or performing. 
(3)  This Section shall not prevent a minor from remaining on the licensed premises during a private party when the licensed premises are otherwise closed to members of the general public, provided that adequate adult supervision exists. 
It shall be an affirmative defense to a violation of this Section to establish by a preponderance of the evidence that a minor at issue was required by the licensee or his or her agents or employees to produce a Colorado photo identification for viewing and that the Colorado photo identification produced by the minor was fraudulent. 
(d)  Penalties . Any person who violates this Section shall be subject to a fine of not more than $300.00. Prosecution of a person under this Section or imposition of a penalty under this Section shall not prohibit the City from taking other action with respect to the licensee's alcoholic beverage or 3.2 beer license. 
(16) Sec. 6-2-260. Penalty. (Chapter 6, Business Licenses and Regulations; Article 2, Alcoholic Beverages) 
    Any person who violates any provision of this Division may be subject to a fine as set forth in Section 1-4-20 of this Code. Any violation of the provisions of this Division may form the basis of a notice of violation and show cause why the licensee's license should not be revoked or suspended pursuant to proper notice and hearing. 
(17) Sec. 6-3-90. Registration of nonprofit organizations. (Chapter 6, Business Licenses and Regulations; Article 3, Peddlers, Solicitors and Dealers) 
(a)  Any person engaged in short-term fundraising door-to-door within the City on behalf of a nonprofit or government-related organization, including but not limited to school organizations, Boy Scouts, Girl Scouts, 4-H and church organizations, does not require a license, but shall register with the City Clerk. 
(b)  Each person shall complete the same form as required for a license as set forth in this Article, but no fee shall be required. The registration for a nonprofit fundraising event shall be effective for a limited period of time, not to exceed 90 days. When the registration is for a youth organization and the youths participating in the fundraising are all less than 18 years of age, an adult representing the organization may register on behalf of the organization in lieu of individual registration. 
(c)  As part of the registration, the organization shall provide the City Clerk with written documentation demonstrating the nonprofit status of the organization. Acceptable documentation shall include, but not be limited to, a copy of an I.R.S. determination of nonprofit status or a letter from a governmental administrator, such as a school superintendent, stating that the organization is approved by and operates under the umbrella of that government organization. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any nonprofit organization to engage in door-to-door fundraising without registering with the City Clerk. Every person who unlawfully engages in door-to-door fundraising on behalf of a nonprofit organization without registering with the City Clerk as provided for in this Article shall be punished by a fine of not more than $300.00. 
(18) Sec. 6-3-130. Unlawful engagement of business. (Chapter 6, Business Licenses and Regulations; Article 3, Peddlers, Solicitors and Dealers) 
    Every person who unlawfully engages in or allows another to unlawfully engage in, on or about his or her property, the business of a transient dealer, peddler, canvasser or solicitor, and every person who transacts any business which would make him or her a transient dealer, peddler, canvasser or solicitor, without having a valid license as provided for in this Article, shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 and not more than $1,000.00. 
(19) Sec. 6-3-140. Unlawful actions. (Chapter 6, Business Licenses and Regulations; Article 3, Peddlers, Solicitors and Dealers) 
    No person shall make any false or untrue statement in an application for a license as a transient dealer, peddler, canvasser or solicitor. No transient dealer, peddler, canvasser or solicitor shall sell any manufactured goods, wares or merchandise as a transient dealer, peddler, canvasser or solicitor; sell any manufactured goods, wares or merchandise by any false or short weight; measure or sell any goods, wares or merchandise as being composed or manufactured in whole or in part of a material different from which such manufactured goods, wares or merchandise are actually composed or manufactured; or sell any manufactured goods, wares or merchandise which are partly or entirely of a poisonous or injurious character or nature, for consumption by human beings, animals or fowl or for application to the body, hair or skin of any human being or animal. Every person who is convicted of a violation of any provision of this Section shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 and not more than $1,000.00. 
(20) Sec. 6-4-20. Rubbish. (Chapter 6, Business Licenses and Regulations; Article 4, Tree Maintenance) 
    It is unlawful for any person engaged in tree maintenance to deposit any rubbish, trimmings, branches, leaves or other residue from their contract obligation upon any City property, including streets and alleys, and the person so engaged shall be solely responsible for the removal and disposal thereof. In the event that the licensee shall fail to make such proper removal or disposal, the City may, in its discretion, remove and dispose of the same and make a direct charge to the licensee at the rate as set forth in the City's Fee Schedule per man hour for labor and as set forth in the City's Fee Schedule per hour for equipment. In addition, such failure on the part of the licensee shall constitute a violation of this Section and shall subject the licensee to the penalty provisions hereof. In addition, the annual license shall be automatically revoked. 
( 21) Sec. 6-4-60. Penalty. (Chapter 6, Business Licenses and Regulations; Article 4, Tree Maintenance) 
    Any person violating any provision of this Article shall be fined for each offense in accordance with the provisions of Section 1-4-20 of this Code. 
(22) Sec. 6-4-70. Forfeiture of bond. (Chapter 6, Business Licenses and Regulations; Article 4, Tree Maintenance) 
    In addition to the above provisions, in the event that any person is convicted of a violation of this Section in accordance with the terms hereof, the City may declare the required bond in default, or as much thereof as may be necessary for the payment of any fines levied hereunder. 
(23) Sec. 6-5-120. Suspension and revocation of license. (Chapter 6, Business Licenses and Regulations; Article 5, Non-Cigarette Tobacco Product Retail Licenses) 
(a)  Suspension of license for violation . In addition to any other penalty authorized by law, a non-cigarette tobacco product retail license shall be suspended if a court of competent jurisdiction determines (or the Department finds, based on a preponderance of the evidence, after the licensee is afforded notice and an opportunity to be heard) that the licensee has violated any of the requirements, conditions or prohibitions of this Article or has pleaded guilty, no contest or its equivalent, or admitted to a violation of any law designated in Section 6-5-30 of this Article. A non-cigarette tobacco product retailer whose license has been suspended is deemed not to have a valid license during the suspension period for purposes of this Article. 
(1)  After suspension for a first violation of this Article at a location within any 12-month period, no person may engage in non-cigarette tobacco product retailing at the location until 15 days have passed from the date of suspension. 
(2)  After suspension for a second violation of this Article at a location within any 24-month period, no person may engage in non-cigarette tobacco product retailing at the location until 30 days have passed from the date of suspension. 
(3)  After suspension for a third violation of this Article at a location within any 36-month period, no person may engage in non-cigarette tobacco product retailing at the location until 90 days have passed from the date of suspension. 
(b)  Revocation of license for violation . After suspension for a fourth violation of this Chapter within any 48-month period, the non-cigarette tobacco product retail license shall be revoked and the licensee shall be ineligible for one year from the date of suspension to apply for a new non-cigarette tobacco product retail license within the City. 
(c)  Appeal of suspension or revocation of license . A decision of the City or Department to suspend or revoke a non-cigarette tobacco product retail license is appealable to the City Manager and must be filed with the City Clerk within ten days of the mailing of the Department's decision. If an appeal is made, it shall stay enforcement of the appealed action. 
(24) Sec. 6-5-130. Penalties and fines. (Chapter 6, Business Licenses and Regulations; Article 5, Non-Cigarette Tobacco Product Retail Licenses) 
(a)  Each such violation of any local, state or federal law pertaining to the sale of tobacco products to minors or any violation of any law designated above shall be subject to administrative fines as follows: 
(1)  First violation within one year: a fine not to exceed $100.00. 
(2)  Second violation within one year: a fine not to exceed $200.00. 
(3)  Third violation within one year: a fine not to exceed $300.00. 
(4)  Fourth violation within one year: a fine not to exceed $500.00. 
(b)  Penalties and fines collected under this Article shall be paid directly to the Department and used to support education, administration or enforcement of non-cigarette tobacco product retail licenses in the City. 
(25) Sec. 6-5-160. Non-cigarette tobacco product retailing without license. (Chapter 6, Business Licenses and Regulations; Article 5, Non-Cigarette Tobacco Product Retail Licenses) 
(a)  In addition to any other penalty authorized by law, if a court of competent jurisdiction determines, or the Department finds based on a preponderance of evidence, after notice and an opportunity to be heard, that any person has engaged in non-cigarette tobacco product retailing at a location without a valid non-cigarette tobacco product retail license, either directly or through the person's agents or employees, the person shall be ineligible to apply for, or to be issued, a non-cigarette tobacco product retailing license as follows: 
(1)  After a first violation of this Section at a location within any 12-month period, no new license may issue for the person or the location (unless ownership of the business at the location has been transferred in an arm's length transaction), until 14 days have passed from the date of the violation. 
(2)  After a second violation of this Section at a location within any 24-month period, no new license may be issued for the person or the location (unless ownership of the business at the location has been transferred in an arm's length transaction), until 30 days have passed from the date of the violation. 
(3)  After a third or subsequent violation of this Section at a location within any 36-month period, no new license may issue for the person or the location (unless ownership of the business at the location has been transferred in an arm's length transaction) until one year has passed from the date of the violation. 
(b)  Non-cigarette tobacco products offered for sale or exchange in violation of this Section are subject to seizure by the Department or any peace officer and shall be forfeited after the licensee and any other owner of the non-cigarette tobacco products seized are given reasonable notice and an opportunity to demonstrate that the non-cigarette tobacco products were not offered for sale or exchange in violation of this Article. 
(c)  The decision by the Department may be appealed pursuant to the procedures set forth in this Code. 
(d)  Forfeited non-cigarette tobacco products shall be destroyed after all internal appeals have been exhausted and the time in which to seek judicial review has expired without the filing of a lawsuit or, if such a suit is filed, after judgment in that suit becomes final. 
(e)  For the purposes of the civil remedies provided in this Article, the following provisions shall constitute a separate violation of this Article: 
(1)  Each day on which a non-cigarette tobacco product is offered for sale in violation of this Article; or 
(2)  Each individual non-cigarette tobacco product that is distributed, sold or offered for sale in violation of this Article. 
(26) Sec. 6-5-170. Enforcement. (Chapter 6, Business Licenses and Regulations; Article 5, Non-Cigarette Tobacco Product Retail Licenses) (a) The remedies provided by this Article are cumulative and in addition to any other remedies available at law or in equity. (b) Whenever evidence of a violation of this Article is obtained in any part through the participation of a person under the age of 18 years old, such a person shall not be required to appear or give testimony in any civil or administrative process brought to enforce this Article and the alleged violation shall be adjudicated based upon the sufficiency and persuasiveness of the evidence presented. (c) Violations of this Article are subject to a civil action brought by the City Attorney, punishable by a civil fine not less than $200.00 and not exceeding $1,000.00 per violation. (d) Violations of this Article may, at the discretion of the City Attorney, be prosecuted as infractions or misdemeanors when the interests of justice so require. (e) Causing, permitting, aiding, abetting or concealing a violation of any provision of this Article shall also constitute a violation of this Article. (f) Violations of this Article are hereby declared to be public nuisances. (g) In addition to other remedies provided by this Article or by other law, any violation of this Article may be remedied by a civil action brought by the City Attorney, including administrative or judicial nuisance abatement proceedings, civil or criminal code enforcement proceedings and suits for injunctive relief. 
(27) Sec. 7-1-120. Judgment; relief. (Chapter 7, Health, Sanitation and Animals; Article 1, Administration and Abatement of Nuisances) 
(a)  The judgment in an action to abate a public nuisance may include a permanent injunction to restrain, abate and prevent the continuance or reoccurrence of the nuisance. The Court may grant declaratory relief, mandatory orders or any other relief deemed necessary to accomplish the purposes of the injunction and enforce the same, and the Court may retain jurisdiction of the case for the purpose of enforcing its order. 
(b)  The judgment in an action to abate a public nuisance may include an order directing the Chief of Police to seize and close the public nuisance and to keep the same effectually closed until further order of the court, not to exceed one year. 
(c)  The judgment in an action to abate a public nuisance may include, in addition to or in the alternative to other injunctive relief, an order requiring the removal, correction or other abatement of a public nuisance, in whole or in part, by the Chief of Police at the expense of the owner or operator of the public nuisance. 
(d)  The judgment in an action to abate a public nuisance may include, in addition to or in the alternative to any other relief authorized by the provisions of this Article, the imposition of a fine of not more than $300.00, conditioned upon failure or refusal of compliance with the orders of the Court within any time limits therein fixed. 
(28) Sec. 7-1-190. Violation and penalties. (Chapter 7, Health, Sanitation and Animals; Article 1, Administration and Abatement of Nuisances) 
(a)  Whenever the doing of any act is required, prohibited or declared to be unlawful and no definite fine or penalty is provided for a violation of this Chapter, any person who is convicted of a violation shall be subject to such penalties as are provided in Section 7-1-110 of this Article. 
(b)  Any person who has possession or control of any private ground or premises, whether or not he or she is the owner thereof, in or upon which any such nuisance exists or may be found, whether such nuisance has been heretofore or is hereafter created, shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense as the author of a nuisance for every period of 24 hours' continuance of such nuisance after due notice has been given to abate the same. 
(c)  Any violation or disobedience of any injunction or order issued by the Court in an action to abate a public nuisance shall be punished as a contempt of court by a fine of not more than $300.00 and imprisonment of not more than five days; but the Municipal Court may treat each day on which the violation or disobedience of any injunction order continues or recurs as a separate contempt. 
(d)  Fees; costs and fines; liens and collection. 
(1)  For seizing and closing any building or premises as provided in this Chapter, or for performing other duties pursuant to the direction of the Municipal Court pursuant to the provisions of this Chapter, the City shall be entitled to a reasonable sum fixed by the Municipal Court in addition to the actual costs incurred or expended. 
(2)  All fees and costs allowed by the provisions of this Section, the costs of a court action to abate any public nuisance and all fines levied by the Municipal Court in contempt proceedings incidental to any action to abate a public nuisance shall be a first and prior lien upon any real property seized or closed under the provisions of this Chapter, and the same shall be enforceable and collectible by execution issued by order of the Municipal Court, from the property of any person liable therefor. 
(3)  Nothing in this Chapter shall be construed in such a manner as to destroy the validity of a bona fide lien upon real or personal property appearing of record prior to recording of court orders involving real estate as authorized under this Chapter. 
(29) Sec. 7-3-100. Penalty. (Chapter 7, Health, Sanitation and Animals; Article 3, Junk Vehicles) 
    Any person convicted of violating any portion of this Article shall be punished in accordance with Section 1-4-20 of this Code. 
(30) Sec. 7-4-70. Penalty. (Chapter 7, Health, Sanitation and Animals; Article 4, Garbage and Refuse) ;p2; 
    Any person convicted of violation of any provision of this Article shall be punished by a fine in accordance with the provisions of Section 7-1-120 of this Chapter. 
(31) Sec. 7-5-80. Penalty for nonpayment. (Chapter 7, Health, Sanitation and Animals; Article 5, Weeds and Brush) If said assessment is not paid within 60 days, the same may be certified by the City Clerk to the County Treasurer for collection, together with a ten-percent penalty, in the same manner as other taxes are collected. 
(32) Sec. 7-5-90. Violation. (Chapter 7, Health, Sanitation and Animals; Article 5, Weeds and Brush) 
    In addition to the notice and penalty provisions set forth above, any person violating any of the provisions of this Article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and each such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof during which any violation of any of the provisions of this Article is committed, continued or permitted. Upon conviction of any such violation, such person shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $1,000.00. 
(33) Sec. 7-6-40. Penalty. (Chapter 7, Health, Sanitation and Animals; Article 6, Trees) 
(a)  In case any assessment due and payable under this Article, except that set forth in Subsection 7-6-30(g) above, is not paid within 30 days from the date the assessment is made, the City Clerk shall certify the same to the County Treasurer, to be placed by him or her upon the tax rolls of the current year and to be collected in the same manner as other taxes are collected, with a ten-percent penalty thereon to defray the cost of collection. 
(b)  The maintenance of untreated elm trees and bushes upon any premises on or after May 15 of any calendar year is hereby declared to be a misdemeanor, and any person owning, controlling or occupying any premises upon which such untreated elm trees or elm bushes are in existence shall be guilty of a violation and, upon conviction thereof, may be fined. 
(34) Sec. 7-7-190. Failure to register. (Chapter 7, Health, Sanitation and Animals; Article 7, Animals) The minimum penalty for failing to register an animal in accordance with the provisions of this Article shall be a fine of $200.00, and the maximum penalty shall be a fine of $500.00. The amount of $100.00 of the penalty shall not be waived or suspended. (1) All of the penalty may be waived where the owner provides proof that the owner properly registered the animal with the City subsequent to the issuance of the summons and complaint. (2) Where a portion of the penalty was waived pursuant to Paragraph (1) above, an additional portion or all of the penalty may be waived if the owner also provides proof from a licensed veterinarian that the animal has been spayed or neutered. 
(35) Sec. 7-7-390. Animal disturbance of peace and quiet prohibited. (Chapter 7, Health, Sanitation and Animals; Article 7, Animals) 
(a)  It is unlawful for any animal owner or for any person in charge of any animal to own, keep or have in his or her possession an animal which disturbs the peace and quiet of any person or neighborhood by barking, fighting, howling, crying, whining, yowling, squawking, crowing or emitting any other similar unreasonable noise. 
(b)  For purposes of this Section, unreasonable noise shall mean any sound of such level and duration as to be, or tend to be, injurious to human health or welfare, or which would unreasonably interfere with the enjoyment of life or property. Continuous or intermittent barking, fighting, howling, crying, whining, yowling, squawking, crowing or emitting any other similar unreasonable noise over a period of ten minutes shall constitute prima facie evidence of unreasonable interference with the enjoyment of life or property. 
(c)  No summons and complaint shall be issued nor shall there be a conviction for violation of this Section unless there is at least one complaining witness who has signed such complaint and has testified at trial. The Code Enforcement Officer or a police officer who personally observed the behavior of the animal with regard to its barking, fighting, howling, crying, whining, yowling, squawking, crowing or emitting other similar unreasonable noise shall satisfy the requirement of having at least one complaining witness and may testify as to his or her observations at trial. 
(d)  This Section shall not apply to the Code Enforcement Officer or police officers in the performance of their duties, nor to veterinary hospitals or animal shelters. 
(e)  Violations of the provisions of this Section shall be punishable as follows: 
(1)  For a first violation in a 12-month period, a minimum fine of $100.00 and a maximum fine of $1,000.00. Not more than 50 percent of the fine may be suspended where the owner had registered the animals with the City prior to the hearing. 
(2)  For a second violation in a 12-month period, a minimum fine of $250.00 and a maximum fine of $1,000.00. Not more than 50 percent of the fine may be suspended where the owner permanently removed the animals from the City prior to the hearing. 
(3)  For a third and subsequent violation in a 12-month period, a minimum fine of $300.00 and a maximum fine of $1,000.00. 
(36) Sec. 7-7-510. Animals prohibited within City designated; exceptions. (Chapter 7, Health, Sanitation and Animals; Article 7, Animals) 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to keep, maintain, possess or harbor at his or her dwelling within the City more than a total of four animals over the age of three months. This Subsection shall not include fish or birds. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to keep, maintain, possess or harbor any livestock or fowl such as, but not limited to, horses, mules, donkeys, burros, cattle, sheep, goats, swine, chickens, geese, ducks or turkeys, within the City; provided, however, that this Section shall be coordinated with the City's zoning regulations contained in Chapter 16 of this Code, wherein certain animals and numbers thereof may be permitted within certain zoning districts. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person to own, keep, maintain, possess, harbor, sell or in any manner deal or traffic within the City in any living exotic, wild, dangerous or unusual animals, whether domesticated or tamed, including but not necessarily limited to the following: Africanized Apis mellifera (honey bees); bats of any species; bears of any species; felines, other than ordinary domesticated house cats; gorillas, chimpanzees, orangutans, baboons or any other infra-human primate; any member of the Mustelidae family, except ferrets, including but not limited to fishers, martens, minks, otters, porcupines, raccoons, skunks, weasels and wolverines; poisonous reptiles; wolves, foxes, coyotes or other species of canines other than dogs; any animal or bird which has received state or federal government designation as an endangered species; or any other terrestrial predator or other animal determined to be a public nuisance pursuant to the provisions, procedures and means of abatement therefor established by the City. 
(d)  For purposes of this Section, any hybrid or breed mix between wild animals and domestic animals shall be considered a domesticated animal, and as such is allowed. Alleged domestication and keeping of any wild animal is not allowed. 
(e)  This Section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  A zoo or circus authorized by the City. 
(2)  Any entrant in a rodeo, fair or show authorized by the City. 
(3)  The temporary maintenance of an animal by a licensed veterinarian during the time necessary for treatment. 
(4)  The City animal shelter while holding an animal pending legal disposition of the animal. 
(5)  Any animal properly boarded on the Arkansas Valley Fairgrounds. 
(6)  Any person lawfully engaged in the operation of a packing house or slaughter house governed by the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment regulations, who keeps animals or fowl for a temporary period of time not to exceed 72 hours in connection with the operation of such business. 
(7)  Any person granted a hardship permit as set forth below so long as the hardship permit remains valid. 
(f)  The minimum penalty for failure to comply with the provisions of this Section shall be $100.00 for each animal over the stated limit of four or for each excluded animal owned unlawfully. The amount of $50.00 of each penalty shall not be waived or suspended. The owner will have 30 days to comply in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter. In the event the owner refuses to comply with the provisions of this Chapter, a summons will be issued. 
(37) Sec. 7-8-190. Penalties. (Chapter 7, Health, Sanitation and Animals; Article 8, Dogs) 
    Violation of a provision of this Division, unless otherwise specified in this Chapter, shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $1,000.00. 
(38) Sec. 7-8-330. Penalties for violations. (Chapter 7, Health, Sanitation and Animals; Article 8, Dogs) 
    Violations of the provisions of this Division shall be punishable as follows: 
(1)  For any unlawful attack, as defined in Section 7-8-310 of this Article, the Municipal Court shall order the implantation in the dog of a unique identifying computer microchip by a licensed veterinarian at the owner's expense, and the owner will be ordered to register the identifying microchip information with the City Clerk and the central registry for such information. 
(2)  For any unlawful attack where there is no injury to a human or other animal, a fine of not less than $150.00 nor more than $1,000.00, plus any additional penalty which the Municipal Court deems proper, including but not limited to evaluation and successful completion of a recommended animal owner course, mandatory kenneling, confinement, muzzling or, in the case of a dog, compliance with the requirements for vicious dogs as set forth in this Article. 
(3)  For a second attack by the same animal that was involved in the first violation, or any other animal owned by the same person or of the same household during a three-year period following the first violation, a fine of not less than $450.00 and not more than $1,000.00, plus any additional penalty which the court deems proper. 
(4)  For unlawful attacks, as defined in Section 7-8-310 of this Article, where bodily injury to a human or other animal occurs, the penalties shall be: 
a.  For a first violation involving the biting of a human being or an animal, a fine of not less than $300.00 and not more than $1,000.00, plus any additional penalty which the Municipal Court deems proper, including the humane destruction of the animal. A portion of the penalties in this Subsection may be suspended upon order of the Municipal Court for compliance with any other court-ordered conditions, such as evaluation and successful completion of a recommended animal owner course, mandatory kenneling, confinement, muzzling or, in the case of a dog, compliance with the requirements for vicious dogs as set forth in this Article. 
b.  For a second violation involving the biting of or an attack upon a human being or an animal by the same animal that was involved in the first violation, or any other animal owned by the same person or of the same household occurring within a three-year period following the first violation, a fine of not less than $750.00 and not more than $1,000.00 and a jail sentence of not less than five days, plus any additional penalty the Municipal Court deems proper. A portion of the penalties in this Subsection may be suspended upon order of the Municipal Court for compliance with any other court-ordered conditions. Additionally, the animal shall be destroyed in a humane manner. 
(39) Sec. 7-8-510. Penalties. (Chapter 7, Health, Sanitation and Animals; Article 8, Dogs) Whoever violates any provisions of this Division shall be punished by a fine of not less than $50.00 and not more than $1,000.00 or imprisonment of not more than one year, or by both such fine and imprisonment. The Municipal Court shall order appropriate restitution when a vicious dog caused personal or property damage.

(2)  Every person convicted of a violation of any provision adopted in this Article shall be punished by a fine of $35.00 per point lost, not exceeding $300.00, or by imprisonment not exceeding 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment.

    Any person violating any provisions of this Article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000.00. 
(42) Sec. 8-3-40. Penalty. (Chapter 8, Vehicles and Traffic; Article 3, Motorized Wheelchairs) 
    Any person convicted of a violation of any provision of this Article shall be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000.00.
