    Any person who violates the provisions of this Article, or any owner of a vehicle who authorizes or permits the violation of this Article, shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $1,000.00. 
(44) Sec. 10-1-20. Penalties. (Chapter 10, General Offenses; Article 1, General Provisions) 
    Unless otherwise specified in this Chapter, any person convicted of a violation of any section or provision of this Chapter shall be punished in accordance with the provisions of Section 1-4-20 of this Code. 
(45) Sec. 10-4-20. Trespassing. (Chapter 10, General Offenses; Article 4, Public, Private and Personal Property) 
(a)  Definitions . The following definitions shall apply to this Section: 
    Premises means any public or private real property, buildings or other improvements thereon located within the City. 
    Trespass means when a person: 
(1)  Unlawfully enters or remains in or upon premises which are enclosed in a manner designed to exclude intruders or are fenced. 
(2)  Knowingly and unlawfully enters or remains upon the premises of a hotel, motel, condominium or apartment building. 
(3)  Enters or remains upon premises clearly and conspicuously posted with no trespassing signs; 
(4)  In the case of a solicitor, hawker, itinerant merchant or salesman, enters or remains upon premises and knocks on doors or rings doorbells of any entrance thereto upon which are clearly posted signs prohibiting solicitation or sale. 
(5)  Refuses or fails to leave the premises when asked to do so by the owner or person in charge of the premises, whether the premises are a private residence or a building or business open to the public. 
(6)  Returns to any premises, public or private, from which he or she has been barred by the owner or person in charge of the premises after having been advised by the owner or person in charge that he or she shall no longer be permitted on the premises. 
    Unlawfully enters or remains means when a person enters or remains in or upon premises when he or she is not licensed, invited or otherwise privileged to do so. 
(b)  It is illegal and unlawful for any person to trespass, knowingly enter or remain in or upon any premises of another without the permission of the owner or person entitled to the possession thereof. 
(c)  Any person who is found to have violated any provision of this Section shall be punished by imposition of a fine not to exceed $1,000.00 and imposition of a sentence to useful public service. There is hereby imposed a minimum mandatory fine of $50.00 for a first offense hereunder. 
(46) Sec. 10-4-40. Theft. (Chapter 10, General Offenses; Article 4, Public, Private and Personal Property) 
(a)  Definitions . The following definitions shall apply to this Section: 
    Knowingly or willfully. A person acts knowingly or willfully with respect to conduct or to a circumstance described by this Section when he or she is aware that his or her conduct is of such nature or that such circumstance exists. A person acts knowingly or willfully with respect to a result of his or her conduct when he or she is aware that his or her conduct is practically certain to cause the result. 
    Thing of value includes real property, tangible and intangible personal property, contract rights, choses in action, services, confidential information, medical records information, and any rights of use or enjoyment connected therewith. 
    Unpurchased means that the item was not paid for in monies or consideration of payment by any other means. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to commit the offense of theft. It is the intent of this Section to define one offense of theft and to incorporate therein the offenses of larceny, stealing, embezzlement, false pretenses, confidence games and shoplifting, thereby removing distinctions and technicalities which previously existed in the pleading and proof of such offenses. A person commits theft when he or she knowingly obtains or exercises control over anything of value of another without authorization or by threat or deception when the value of the thing is less than $1,000.00 and: 
(1)  Intends to deprive the other person permanently of the use or benefit of the thing of value. 
(2)  Knowingly uses, conceals or abandons the thing of value in such manner as to deprive the other person permanently of its use or benefit. 
(3)  Uses, conceals or abandons the thing of value, intending that such use, concealment or abandonment will deprive the other person permanently of its use and benefit; or 
a.  If any person willfully conceals unpurchased goods, wares or merchandise owned or held by and offered or displayed for sale by any store or other mercantile establishment, whether the concealment is on his or her person or otherwise and whether on or off the premises of said store or mercantile establishment, such concealment constitutes prima facie evidence that the person intended to commit the offense of theft. 
b.  If any person conceals upon his or her person or otherwise carries away any unpurchased goods, wares or merchandise held or owned by any store or mercantile establishment, the store owner, merchant or any employee thereof, or any police officer, acting in good faith and upon probable cause, may detain and question any person in a reasonable manner for the purpose of ascertaining whether a person has committed the offense of theft. Such detention and questioning shall not render the store owner, merchant, employee or police officer liable civilly or criminally for slander, libel, false arrest, false imprisonment, malicious prosecution or unlawful detention. 
(4)  Demands any consideration to which he or she is not legally entitled as a condition of restoring the thing of value to the other person. 
(c)  Penalties . Any person who is found to have violated any provision of this Section shall be punished by imposition of a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, and imposition of a sentence to useful public service. There is hereby imposed a minimum mandatory fine of $50.00 for a first offense hereunder. 
(47)  Sec. 10-4-200. Violation. (Chapter 10, General Offenses; Article 4, Public, Private and Personal Property) 
(a)  Any person convicted of violating this Division shall be subject to a penalty and fine of up to $1,000.00. The Municipal Court shall have the authority to order the violator to perform useful public service up to and including 100 hours. 
(b)  The City may elect to place all or a part of the fines collected into a separate account to be used for the removal and eradication of graffiti within the City. 
(48) Sec. 10-6-60. Sale of cigarettes and tobacco products. (Chapter 10, General Offenses; Article 6, Minors) 
(a)  For purposes of this Section, the following words shall have the meanings ascribed hereafter: 
    Cigarettes means premanufactured cigarettes and/or hand-rolled cigarettes. 
    Minor means a person under the age of 18 years. 
    Tobacco products means cigars, cheroots, stogies, periques, granulated, plug cut, crimp cut, ready rubbed and other smoking tobacco, snuff, snuff flour, Cavendish, plug and twist tobacco, fine cut and other chewing tobaccos, shorts, refuse scraps, clippings, cutting and sweepings of tobacco, and other kinds and forms of tobacco, prepared in such a manner as to be suitable for chewing or smoking in a pipe or otherwise, or both for chewing and smoking. 
(b)  Any person who knowingly furnishes to a minor, by gift, sale or any other means, any cigarettes or tobacco products commits an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of $200.00. It shall be an affirmative defense to a prosecution under this Subsection that the person furnishing the cigarettes or tobacco products was presented with and reasonably relied upon a valid state driver's license or other government-issued form of identification which identified the person receiving the cigarettes or tobacco products as being 18 years of age or older. 
(c)  Any minor who purchases or attempts to purchase any cigarettes or tobacco products, and/or is found to be in possession of any cigarettes or tobacco products commits an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of $100.00; except that, following a conviction or adjudication for a first offense under this Subsection, the Court in lieu of the fine may sentence the person to participate in a tobacco education program. The Court may allow such person to perform community service and be granted credit against the fine and court costs at the rate of $5.00 for each hour of work performed, for up to 50 perecent of the fine and court costs. 
(d)  No retailer shall sell or permit the sale of cigarettes or tobacco products by use of a vending machine or other coin-operated machine; except that cigarettes may be sold at retail through vending machines only in: 
(1)  Factories, businesses, offices or other places not open to the general public; 
(2)  Places to which minors are not permitted access at any time during the day or night; or 
(3)  Places where the vending machine is under the direct supervision of the owner of the establishment or an adult employee of the owner, including but not limited to establishments holding a valid liquor license issued pursuant to Article 47 of Title 12, C.R.S. 
(e)  Any person who sells or offers to sell any cigarettes or tobacco products shall display a warning sign as specified in this Subsection. Said warning sign shall be displayed in a prominent place in the building and on such machine at all times, shall have a minimum height of three inches and a width of six inches, and shall read as follows: 
    WARNING 
    IT IS ILLEGAL FOR ANY PERSON UNDER 18 YEARS OF AGE TO PURCHASE CIGARETTES AND TOBACCO PRODUCTS AND, UPON CONVICTION, A $100.00 FINE MAY BE IMPOSED. 
(f)  Any violation of Subsection (e) above shall not constitute a violation of any other provision of this Section. 
(49) Sec. 10-6-70. Protection of minors from tobacco. (Chapter 10, General Offenses; Article 6, Minors) 
(a)  Purpose and intent . 
(1)  The City Council hereby finds that: 
a.  The City recognizes the dangers associated with youth access to tobacco products; 
b.  Research shows that most adult smokers began using tobacco products before reaching the legal age at which they could purchase tobacco products; 
c.  Regulating the sale of tobacco products is an appropriate proven deterrent to protect the health, safety and welfare of young people in the City; and 
d.  The requirement of retail sellers of tobacco products to comply with the foregoing regulations will not unduly burden legitimate business activities of retailers who sell tobacco products to youth and will not burden the revenue received by the City for the cigarette excise tax. 
(2)  It is the intent of the City Council to prohibit the sales of tobacco products to youth; to encourage responsible tobacco retailing and discourage violations of tobacco-related laws, especially those laws that prohibit or discourage the sale or distribution of tobacco products to minors; and to reduce the impact of tobacco and nicotine product use by youth in the City. 
(b)  Definitions . As used in this Section, the following words shall have the following meanings unless the context clearly requires otherwise: 
    Retail tobacco business means a sole proprietorship, corporation, limited liability company, partnership or other enterprise engaged primarily in the sale, manufacture or promotion of tobacco, tobacco products or smoking devices or accessories, either at wholesale or retail, and in which the sale, manufacture or promotion of other products is less than five percent gross sales receipts. For purposes of enforcement of this Section, retail tobacco business includes, but is not limited to, a sole proprietorship, corporation, limited liability company or other enterprise engaged primarily in the sale or manufacture of hookah or shisha products and related smoking products, including but not limited to any plant or other organic matter packaged for smoking or held out as a smoking product, or any sole proprietorship, corporation, limited liability company, partnership or other enterprise engaged in the promotion of hookah or shisha smoking, sometimes referred to as a hookah bar, cafe or lounge. 
    Self-service display means the open display or storage of tobacco products in a manner that is physically accessible in any way to the general public without the assistance of the retailer or employee of the retailer and a direct person-to-person transfer between the purchaser and the retailer or employee of the retailer. A vending machine is a form of self-service display. 
    Tobacco paraphernalia means cigarette papers or wrappers, pipes, holders of smoking materials of all types, cigarette rolling machines and any other item designed for the smoking, preparation, storing or consumption of tobacco products. 
    Tobacco product means and includes: 
(1)  Any product that contains tobacco or nicotine, or is made or derived from tobacco that is intended or expected to be ingested, smoked, inhaled, placed in oral or nasal cavities or applied to the skin; or 
(2)  Any electronic device that can be used to deliver nicotine or tobacco to the person using the device, including but not limited to an electronic cigarette, cigar, cigarillo or pipe. 
The term tobacco product does not include any product specifically approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration for use in reducing, treating or eliminating nicotine or tobacco dependence, or for other medical purposes, when such product is being marketed and sold solely for such an approved purpose. 
(c)  Minimum age for persons selling and handling tobacco products . No person in the course of employment who is younger than the minimum age established by the laws of the State for the purchase of tobacco products shall sell, stock, retrieve or otherwise handle tobacco products. 
(d)  Positive identification required . No person shall sell or transfer a tobacco product to another person who appears to be under the age of 30 years without first examining the identification of the recipient to confirm that the recipient is at least the minimum age under the laws of the State to purchase and possess tobacco products. 
(e)  No minors permitted in a retail tobacco business . 
(1)  No person who is younger than the minimum age established by the laws of the State for the purchase of tobacco products shall be admitted to or be on the premises of a retail tobacco business unless accompanied by his or her parent or guardian. The presence of an unaccompanied minor in or on the premises of a retail tobacco business shall result in a violation of this Section by the minor and the owner of the business establishment. 
(2)  The owner of a retail tobacco business shall post and keep at all times visible to the public, in a conspicuous place on the premises, a sign to be provided by the City Clerk's office, which shall read as follows: 
    WARNING: 
    IT IS ILLEGAL FOR ANY PERSON UNDER 18 YEARS OF AGE TO BE ADMITTED TO OR BE ON THE PREMISES OF THIS BUSINESS, UNLESS ACCOMPANIED BY A PARENT OR GUARDIAN, AND UPON CONVICTION, A FINE MAY BE IMPOSED. 
(f)  Possession of tobacco paraphernalia by minors prohibited . No person who is younger than the minimum age established by the laws of the State for the purchase of tobacco products shall possess tobacco paraphernalia. 
(g)  Prohibition of sale of tobacco products by self-service display . The sale of tobacco products through the use of a self-service display is prohibited. 
(h)  Penalty for violations . 
(1)  Any retail establishment or adult found to be in violation of any provision of this Section shall be subject to a fine of up to $300.00. 
(2)  Any minor found to be in violation of any provision of this Section shall be subject to a fine of up to $100.00. Within the discretion of the Court, this fine may be made payable at a rate of $5.00 per hour for services provided to the City by the offending minor. 
(50) Sec. 10-6-80. Juvenile curfew. (Chapter 10, General Offenses; Article 6, Minors) 
(a)  It is unlawful for any juvenile to be, remain or loiter upon any public street, sidewalk, alley, public place, right-of-way, park, playground, school yard or any other public place or any establishment open to the public generally after the hour of 11:00 p.m. or before the hour of 5:00 a.m. on any day within the City. 
(b)  Exceptions . It shall not be a violation of Subsection (a) above under the following circumstances: 
(1)  When the juvenile is accompanied by a parent, guardian or other person having legal care or custody of such juvenile. 
(2)  When the juvenile is in the care, custody and control of and is accompanied by a person who is over the age of 18 years and possesses the written consent of such parent, guardian or other person having legal care or custody of the juvenile. 
(3)  When the juvenile is in the care, custody and control of and is accompanied by a person who has reached 21 years of age. 
(4)  During the period of time when the juvenile is lawfully employed and for a period of 30 minutes before and after said employment hours when commuting directly to and directly from said employment. 
(5)  When the juvenile is performing or conducting an errand, which errand was directed and requested by the juvenile's parent, guardian or legal custodian. 
(6)  When the juvenile is attending, traveling to or returning from such events as movies, school-sponsored activities or sporting events, theater performances or religious services, provided that such attendance at these events was approved by the parent, guardian or legal custodian. 
(7)  When the juvenile is on private residential property or a sidewalk directly adjacent to the building in which the juvenile resides. 
(c)  Penalty . In the event any person violates the provisions of this Section, he or she shall be subject to a fine of not less than $25.00 nor more than $1,000.00. 
(51) Sec. 10-6-90. Curfew; parental responsibility. (Chapter 10, General Offenses; Article 6, Minors) 
(a)  Permitting violation of curfew . It is unlawful for any parent, guardian, legal custodian or other individual having the legal care, custody or control of a juvenile to knowingly permit or allow such juvenile to be, remain upon or loiter upon any public street, sidewalk, alley, playground, park, school yard or any other public place or establishment after the hour of 11:00 p.m. and before the hour of 5:00 a.m. on any day within the City. 
(b)  Exceptions . It shall not be a violation of Subsection (c) above under the following circumstances: 
(1)  When the juvenile is accompanied by a parent, guardian or other person having legal care or custody of such juvenile. 
(2)  When the juvenile is in the care, custody and control and is accompanied by a person who is over the age of 18 years and possesses the written consent of such parent, guardian, or other person having legal care or custody of the juvenile; 
(3)  When the juvenile is in the care, custody and control and being accompanied by a person who has reached 21 years of age; 
(4)  During the period of time when the juvenile is lawfully employed and for a period of one-half hour before and after said employment hours when commuting directly to and directly from said employment; 
(5)  When the juvenile is performing or conducting an errand, which errand was directed and requested by the juvenile's parent, guardian or legal custodian; 
(6)  When the juvenile is attending, traveling to or returning from such events as movies, school-sponsored activities or sporting events, theater performances or religious services, provided that such attendance at these events was approved by the parent, guardian or legal custodian; and 
(7)  When the juvenile is on private residential property or a sidewalk directly adjacent to the building in which the juvenile resides. 
(c)  Penalty . In the event any person violates the provisions of this Section, he or she shall be subject to a fine of not less $25.00 nor more than $1,000.00. 
(52) Sec. 10-7-120. Possession of marijuana. (Chapter 10, General Offenses; Article 7, Alcoholic Beverages and Drugs) 
(a)  Any person who knowingly possesses two ounces or less of marijuana commits an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $100.00. 
(b)  Whenever a person is arrested or detained for a violation of Subsection (a) above, the arresting or detaining officer shall prepare a written notice or summons for such person to appear in court. The written notice or summons shall contain the name and address of such arrested or detained person, the date, time and place where such person shall appear and a place for the signature of such person indicating the person's written promise to appear on the date and at the time and place indicated on the notice or summons. One copy of said notice or summons shall be given to the person arrested or detained, one copy shall be sent to the Municipal Court and such other copies as may be required by the Sheriff's Department shall be sent to the places designated by the Sheriff's Department. The date specified in the notice or summons to appear shall be at least five days after such arrest or detention unless the person arrested or detained demands an earlier hearing. The arrested or detained person, in order to secure release from arrest or detention, shall promise in writing to appear in court by signing the notice or summons prepared by the arresting or detaining officer. 
(c)  Any person who openly and publicly displays, consumes or uses two ounces or less of marijuana commits an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished, at a minimum, by a fine of not less than $100.00 or, at a maximum, by a fine of not more than $100.00 and, notwithstanding the provisions of Section 18-1.3-503, C.R.S., by 15 days in jail. 
(53) Sec. 10-7-130. Possession of drug paraphernalia. (Chapter 10, General Offenses; Article 7, Alcoholic Beverages and Drugs) 
(a)  A person commits possession of drug paraphernalia if he or she possesses drug paraphernalia and knows or reasonably should know that the drug paraphernalia could be used under circumstances in violation of state law. 
(b)  Any person who commits possession of drug paraphernalia commits an offense and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $100.00. 
(54) Sec. 10-7-140. Abusing toxic vapors. (Chapter 10, General Offenses; Article 7, Alcoholic Beverages and Drugs) 
(a)  As used in this Section, the term toxic vapors means the following substances or products containing such substances: alcohols, including methyl, isopropyl, propyl or butyl; aliphatic acetates, including ethyl, methyl, propyl or methyl cellosolve acetate; acetone; benzene; carbon tetrachloride; cyclohexane; Freons, including Freon 11 and Freon 12; hexane; methyl ethyl ketone; methyl isobutyl ketone; naphtha; perchlorethylene; toluene; trichloroethane; or xylene. 
(b)  No person shall knowingly smell or inhale the fumes of toxic vapors for the purpose of causing a condition of euphoria, excitement, exhilaration, stupefaction or dulled senses of the nervous system. No person shall knowingly possess, buy or use any such substance for the purposes described in this Section. This Subsection shall not apply to the inhalation of anesthesia for medical or dental purposes. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person knowingly to sell, offer for sale, deliver or give away to any other person any substance or product releasing toxic vapors, where the seller, offeror or deliverer knows or has reason to believe that such substance will be used for the purpose of inducing a condition of euphoria, excitement, exhilaration, stupefaction or dulled senses of the nervous system. 
(d)  Any person who knowingly violates the provisions of Subsection (b) or (c) above commits the offense of abusing toxic vapors. Upon conviction thereof, such person shall be punished by a fine of not more than $500.00 for a first offense; and upon conviction of a second or third offense, by a fine of not more than $500.00 and by not more than six months in jail. 
(e)  In a prosecution for a violation of this Section, evidence that a container lists one or more of the substances described in Subsection (a) above as one of its ingredients shall be prima facie evidence that the substance in such container contains toxic vapors and emits the fumes thereof. 
(55) Sec. 10-7-230. Penalty. (Chapter 10, General Offenses; Article 7, Alcoholic Beverages and Drugs) 
    In addition to any other penalties that may exist under federal, state and local law, any person charged with a violation of this Division, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to the standard penalty as proscribed in Section 1-4-20 of this Code. Each and every day during any portion of which any violation is committed, continued or permitted shall be a separate violation, and the violator shall be punished accordingly. 
(56) Sec. 10-8-60. Penalty. (Chapter 10, General Offenses; Article 8, Weapons) 
    Any person who violates the provisions of this Article shall be subject to a fine in accordance with the provisions of Section 1-4-20 of this Code and imposition of community or useful public service. 
(57) Sec. 10-9-100. Penalties. (Chapter 10, General Offenses; Article 9, Noise) 
    The following penalties may be imposed for violation of this Article: 
(1)  First offense. Upon conviction for a first offense for violating this Article, the Municipal Court shall impose a fine of not less than $75.00 nor more than $500.00. The minimum fine imposed by this Paragraph shall be mandatory, and the Municipal Court shall not suspend or waive any portion of such minimum fine. 
(2)  Second offense. Upon conviction for a second offense for violating this Article, the Municipal Court shall impose a fine of not less than $150.00 nor more than $500.00. The minimum fine imposed by this Paragraph shall be mandatory, and the Municipal Court shall not suspend or waive any portion of such minimum fine. 
(3)  Third or subsequent offense. Upon conviction for a third or subsequent offense for violating this Article, the Municipal Court shall impose a fine of not less than $300.00 nor more than $500.00. The minimum fine imposed by this Paragraph shall be mandatory, and the Municipal Court shall not suspend or waive any portion of such minimum fine. 
(58) Sec. 10-10-110. Penalty. (Chapter 10, General Offenses; Article 10, Fireworks) 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this Article, other than Section 10-10-40 above, upon conviction, shall be punished by revocation of the permit or license issued to such person if the same has been issued to such person. In addition, such person shall be subject to a mandatory minimum fine of not less than $250.00 and not more than $1,000.00. Any person violating Section 10-10-40, upon conviction, shall be punished by a minimum fine of not less than $25.00 and not more than $1,000.00. 
(59) Sec. 10-10-120. Ban on fireworks. (Chapter 10, General Offenses; Article 10, Fireworks) 
(a)  When the Fire Chief determines that conditions are such that the use of fireworks, firecrackers, torpedoes, Roman candles, skyrockets and other pyrotechnic displays within the City limits are hazardous, he or she may ban the use of the same and announce said ban, which shall be in effect until he or she lifts the ban. 
(b)  Each firework, firecracker, torpedo, Roman candle, skyrocket or other pyrotechnic display used shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  Any person who is convicted of a violation of this Section shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 and not more than $300.00. 
(60) Sec. 11-2-30. Penalties. (Chapter 11, Streets, Sidewalks and Public Property; Article 2, Excavations) 
    Any person convicted of violating the provisions of this Article shall be punished in accordance with the provisions of Section 1-4-20 of this Code. 
(61) Sec. 11-4-40. Authority of City to remove obstruction. (Chapter 11, Streets, Sidewalks and Public Property; Article 4, Other Regulations) 
    The Mayor, any Councilmember or the City Manager is hereby authorized to order any article or thing which may encumber or obstruct any street, alley or other public place to be removed; and, if such article or thing is not removed within one day after notice to the owner of the article, or his or her agent, to remove the same, to cause the same to be removed to some suitable place. The owner of any article or thing so removed shall be fined, in addition to the sums named, the amount of the expenses of such removal, which expenses shall also be recoverable in the same manner as expenses for the removal of nuisances, as set forth in Chapter 7 of this Code. 
(62) Sec. 11-4-60. Placing building in streets and alleys prohibited. (Chapter 11, Streets, Sidewalks and Public Property; Article 4, Other Regulations) 
    Every person who erects or places any building in whole or in part upon any street, alley, sidewalk or other public grounds within the City shall, upon conviction, be fined in accordance with the provisions of Section 1-4-20 of this Code. 
(63) Sec. 11-4-80. Violation of notice to remove obstruction. (Chapter 11, Streets, Sidewalks and Public Property; Article 4, Other Regulations) 
    Whenever the owner of any building, fence or other obstruction standing or encroaching upon any street, alley, sidewalk or other public ground in this City refuses or neglects to remove the same after notice as provided in Section 11-4-70 above, the cause shall be deemed a nuisance and it shall be lawful for the Mayor to cause the same to be taken down at his or her discretion. The expense thereof shall be recoverable from the owner in an action of debt or by assessment on the premises in the manner provided for other municipal charges and assessments, and every person who opposes or resists the execution of the order of the Mayor made in pursuance hereof shall be fined in accordance with the provisions of Section 1-4-20 of this Code. 
(64) Sec. 11-5-40. Penalties. (Chapter 11, Streets, Sidewalks and Public Property; Article 5, Park Regulations) 
(a)  Any person found entering into or upon the park facilities above described other than at the time permitted by this Article shall be deemed guilty of a breach of the peace. 
(b)  Any person found guilty of committing injury to public property in violation of the terms of this Article, if over the age of 18 years, shall be subject to a mandatory fine of not less than $50.00 nor more than $300.00. 
(c)  All parents of minors under the age of 18 years, which minors have been found committing injury to public property in the park systems described by this Article, shall be individually and collectively liable in an amount not to exceed $300.00 for such injury committed, and the City shall have full authority to commence a civil action at law against said parents for the recovery of all damages resulting from injury to the public property and disorderly conduct by said minors, plus all court costs and reasonable attorney fees. Such actions may be commenced in the name of the City in any court of record of competent jurisdiction within the State. 
(65) Sec. 13-2-110. Uncontrolled cross-connection prohibited. (Chapter 13, Municipal Utilities; Article 2, Water Regulations) 
(a)  Definitions. 
    Backflow preventer means a device accepted by the Department of Public Health and Environment for a specified type of cross-connection that prevents backflow and that is approved for installation at a specific location by the Superintendent of Water and Wastewater. 
    Cross-connection , in this Section, means any point in the water distribution system where chemical, biological or radiological contaminants may come into contact with potable water. 
(b)  Cross-connection without installation of an approved backflow preventer for the specific type of cross-connection is prohibited. 
(c)  Each installed backflow preventer shall be tested annually by a certified backflow prevention technician. 
(d)  Backflow preventer testing and maintenance records shall be kept for three years from the date of testing or maintenance. 
(e)  The water supply to any cross-connection without an approved backflow preventer shall be shut off where the cross-connection is not disconnected or a backflow preventer installed, and shall not be reconnected until the cross-connection is disconnected or an approved backflow preventer is installed and the corrective measure is inspected by the Superintendent of Water and Wastewater. 
(f)  The City Manager shall inform the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment of the uncontrolled cross-connection and the corrective action being taken. 
(g)  Any person who violates this Section shall be subject to a minimum fine of $100.00 and not more than $300.00, and each day that such violation continues shall be deemed a separate offenses. 
(66) Sec. 13-2-360. Penalties. (Chapter 13, Municipal Utilities; Article 2, Water Regulations) 
    It is unlawful, after water service has been discontinued by shutting off the water supply, or in any other manner for the person to re-connect the same without the consent of the City. Any person violating this Subsection shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not less than $25.00 nor more than $50.00 for each offense, and an additional penalty of not less than $25.00 for each day said violation continues. 
(67) Sec. 13-2-440. Penalties. (Chapter 13, Municipal Utilities; Article 2, Water Regulations) 
(a)  Penalty . Any person found guilty of violating this Article or any part thereof shall be fined in accordance with the provisions of Section 1-4-20 of this Code. 
(b)  Additional penalty . The water of any person charged with a violation of this Division shall be disconnected forthwith by the Superintendent of Water Works pending the ultimate disposition of those charges. Any person whose water has been so disconnected may have the same reconnected by posting with the Municipal Judge a bond running to the City, with a surety to be approved by the Municipal Judge, of not less than $300.00, conditioned upon the appearance of such person for trial hereon and payment of any penalties and charges arising therefrom. 
(68) Sec. 13-3-170. Penalties. (Chapter 13, Municipal Utilities; Article 3, Sewer Regulations) 
    The violation of the provisions of this Article shall be punishable in accordance with the provisions of Section 1-4-20 of this Code. 
(69) Sec. 13-6-120. Authorization for collection of fees. (Chapter 13, Municipal Utilities; Article 6, Garbage and Refuse Collection) 
(a)  The City Council shall by resolution establish charges for collection service for removal and hauling of garbage and refuse in the City, prescribe the time and manner of payment of such charges and adopt measures or regulations designed to enforce the payment thereof as, in its discretion, are necessary or desirable. Such resolution, when adopted, shall be of the same force and effect as if incorporated in this Section. 
(b)  Charges for garbage and refuse removed shall be a lien on the property served until paid in full. If payment of any such charge is not made within 90 days after the same is due, the City Clerk shall cause a notice of such charge to be given to the owner of such property by publishing the same for two consecutive weeks in a local newspaper, stating the amount of the charges. If the same are not paid within ten days thereafter, along with publication charges, the City Clerk shall certify such charges as assessed to the County Treasurer, to be placed on the tax rolls for the current year, to be collected in the same manner as taxes are collected, with a penalty of ten percent to defray the cost of collection as provided by state law. 
(70) Sec. 13-6-210. Penalties. (Chapter 13, Municipal Utilities; Article 6, Garbage and Refuse Collection) 
    It is unlawful for any persons to violate any provision of this Article. Any person violating the same shall, upon conviction, be punished in accordance with the provisions of Section 1-4-20 of this Code. 
(71) Sec. 16-10-20. Penalties for violations. (Chapter 16, Zoning; Article 10, Violations and Penalties) 
(a)  Any person who violates this Chapter or fails to comply with any of its requirements, shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in accordance with the provisions of Section 1-4-20 of this Code; and, in addition, shall pay all costs and expenses involved in the case, including reasonable attorney fees. 
(b)  The owner or tenant of any building, structure, premises or part thereof, and any architect, builder, contractor, agent or other person who commits, participates in, assists in or maintains such violation may each be found guilty of a separate offense and suffer the penalties herein provided. 
(c)  Nothing herein contained shall prevent the City from taking such other lawful action as is necessary to prevent or remedy any violation. 
(72) Sec. 17-1-30. Authority. (Chapter 17, Subdivisions; Article 1, General Provisions) 
(a)  The Rocky Ford Subdivisions Regulations are authorized by state statutes, and are hereby declared to be in accordance with all provisions of these statutes. 
(b)  Any person, being the owner or agent of any land located within a subdivision, who transfers, sells, agrees to sell or negotiates to sell any land by reference to, exhibition of or use of a plat of a subdivision, before such plat has been approved by the Planning Commission and recorded or filed in the office of the County Clerk and Recorder, shall forfeit and pay a penalty of $100.00 for each lot or parcel so transferred, sold or agreed or negotiated to be sold. The description of such lot or parcel by metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer or other document used in the process of selling or transferring shall not exempt the transaction from such penalties or from the remedies provided in this Chapter. The City may enjoin such transfer of sale or agreement by action for injunction brought in any court of equity jurisdiction or may recover the penalty by civil action in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(73) Sec. 18-1-90. Violation; penalty. Chapter 18, Building Regulations; Article 1, Building Code) 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to erect, construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, improve, remove, convert or demolish, equip, use, occupy or maintain any building or structure in the City, or cause or permit the same to be done, contrary to or in violation of any of the provisions of this Chapter. 
(b)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this Chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. Each such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof during which any violation of any of the provisions of this Chapter is committed, continued or permitted. Upon conviction of any such violation, such person shall be punished by a fine not more than $300.00 or by imprisonment for not more than 90 days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(74) Sec. 18-10-140. Supervision; penalties. (Chapter 18, Building Regulations; Article 10, Mobile Home Parks and Campgrounds) 
(a)  The person to whom a license for a mobile home park, transient mobile home park or campground is issued shall at all times operate the park or campground in compliance with this Article and shall provide adequate supervision to maintain the park or campground, its facilities and equipment in good repair and in a clean and sanitary condition at all times. 
(b)  The City Council may revoke any license to maintain and operate a mobile home park, transient mobile home park or campground when the licensee has been found guilty by a court of competent jurisdiction of violating any provisions of this Article. After such conviction, the license may be reissued if the circumstances leading to conviction have been remedied and the park is being maintained and operated in full compliance with the law. 
(c)  Any person who violate any provision of these regulations shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than $5.00 nor more than $100.00; and each day's failure of compliance with any such provision shall constitute a separate violation. 
INTRODUCED this 12th day of January, 2016. 
CITY OF ROCKY FORD, COLORADO

CHAPTER 1 - General Provisions 
ARTICLE 1 - Code 

Sec. 1-1-10. - Adoption of Code. 
    The published code known as the Rocky Ford Municipal Code , published by Municipal Code Corporation, of which one copy is now on file in the office of the City Clerk and may be inspected during regular business hours, is enacted and adopted by reference as a primary code and incorporated herein as if set out at length. This primary code has been promulgated by the City of Rocky Ford, Colorado, as a codification of all the ordinances of the City of Rocky Ford of a general and permanent nature through Ordinance No. 914, 2016, for the purpose of providing an up-to-date code of ordinances, properly organized and indexed, in published form for the use of the citizens and officers of the City. 
(Prior code 1.02.080; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-1-20. - Title and scope. 
    This Code constitutes a compilation, revision and codification of all the ordinances of the City of Rocky Ford, Colorado, of a general and permanent nature, and shall be known as the Rocky Ford Municipal Code . It shall be sufficient to refer to this Code as the Rocky Ford Municipal Code in any prosecution for the violation of any provision hereof or in any proceeding at law or equity. It shall be sufficient to designate any ordinance adding to, amending, correcting or repealing all or any portion hereof as an addition to, amendment to, correction of or repeal of the Rocky Ford Municipal Code . Further reference may be had to the titles, chapters, articles, sections and subsections of this Code, and such references shall, apply to that numbered title, chapter, article, section or subsection as it appears in this Code. 
(Prior code,  1.02.090; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-1-30. - Code supersedes prior ordinances. 
    This Code shall supersede all other municipal codes consisting of compilations of general and permanent ordinances and parts of ordinances passed by the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-1-40. - Adoption of secondary codes by reference. 
    Secondary codes may be adopted by reference, as provided by state law. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-1-50. - Repeal of ordinances not contained in Code. 
    All existing ordinances and portions of ordinances of a general and permanent nature, which are inconsistent with any ordinance included in the adoption of this Code, are hereby repealed. 
(Prior code,  1.02.150; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-1-60. - Matters not affected by repeal. 
    The repeal of ordinances and parts of ordinances of a permanent and general nature by Section 1-1-50 above shall not affect any offense committed or act done, any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract, right or obligation established prior to the time said ordinances and parts of ordinances are repealed. 
(Prior code,  1.02.150; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-1-70. - Ordinances saved from repeal. 
    The continuance in effect of temporary and/or special ordinances and parts of ordinances, although omitted from this Code, shall not be affected by such omission therefrom, and the adoption of this Code shall not repeal or amend any such ordinance or part of any such ordinance. Among the ordinances not repealed or amended by the adoption of this Code are ordinances: 
(1)  Promising, guaranteeing or authorizing the payment of money by or for the City. 
(2)  Authorizing or relating to the issuance of general obligation bonds or other evidences of indebtedness. 
(3)  Levying taxes, making appropriations or adopting a budget. 
(4)  Relating to the compensation of City officers or employees. 
(5)  Calling or providing for a specific election. 
(6)  Vacating, closing, accepting, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, dedicating, naming or renaming a specific street, alley or other public way. 
(7)  Establishing the grades or lines of specific streets, sidewalks and other public ways. 
(8)  Creating specific sewer and paving districts and other local improvement districts. 
(9)  Making special assessments for local improvement districts and authorizing refunds from specific local improvement district bond proceeds. 
(10)  Annexing territory to or excluding territory from the City. 
(11)  Dedicating or accepting any specific plat or subdivision. 
(12)  Authorizing specific contracts for purchase of beneficial use of water by the City. 
(13)  Approving or authorizing specific contracts with the State, with other governmental bodies or with others. 
(14)  Authorizing a specific lease, sale or purchase of property. 
(15)  Granting rights-of-way or other rights and privileges to specific railroad companies or other public carriers. 
(16)  Granting a franchise to a specific public utility company or establishing rights for or otherwise regulating a specific public utility company. 
(17)  Amending the Official Zoning Map. 
(Prior code,  1.02.150; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-1-80. - Changes in previously adopted ordinances. 
    In compiling and preparing the ordinances of the City for adoption and revision as part of this Code, certain grammatical changes and other changes were made in one or more of said ordinances. It is the intention of the City Council that all such changes be adopted as part of this Code as if the ordinances so changed had been previously formally amended to read as such. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 2 - Definitions and Usage 

Sec. 1-2-10. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, whenever used in this Code or the ordinances of the City, shall be construed as defined in this Section unless a different meaning is intended from the context or unless a different meaning is specifically defined and more particularly directed to the use of such word or phrase: 
    City means the City of Rocky Ford, Colorado, or the area within the territorial limits of the City of Rocky Ford, and such territory outside of the City over which the City has jurisdiction or control by virtue of any constitutional or statutory provision. 
    City Council means the City Council of the City of Rocky Ford, Colorado. All its members means the total number of Council Members provided by the general laws of the State of Colorado. 
    Code means the Rocky Ford Municipal Code as published and subsequently amended, unless the context requires otherwise. 
    County means the County of Otero, Colorado. 
    C.R.S. means the Colorado Revised Statutes, including all amendments thereto. 
    Law denotes applicable federal law, the Constitution and statutes of the State of Colorado, the ordinances of the City and, when appropriate, any and all rules and regulations which may be promulgated thereunder. 
    May is permissive. 
    Misdemeanor means and is to be construed as meaning violation and is not intended to mean crime or criminal conduct. 
    Month means a calendar month. 
    Oath shall be construed to include an affirmation or declaration in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath; and in such cases the words swear and sworn shall be equivalent to the words affirm and affirmed . 
    Ordinance means a law of the City; provided that a temporary or special law, administrative action, order or directive may be in the form of a resolution. 
    Owner , applied to a building, land, motorized vehicle, animal or other real or personal property, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant, tenant by the entirety or any other person with a possessory interest in the whole or a part of said building, land, motor vehicle, animal or other real or personal property. 
    Person means a natural person, joint venture, joint stock company, partnership, association, club, company, firm, corporation, business, trust, organization or other entity, or the manager, lessee, agent, servant, officer or employee of any of them. 
    Personal property includes money, goods, chattels, things in action and evidences of debt. 
    Preceding and following mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Property includes real and personal property. 
    Real property includes lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Shall and must are both mandatory. 
    Sidewalk means that portion of a street between the curb line and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    State means the State of Colorado. 
    Street includes all streets, highways, avenues, lanes, alleys, courts, places, squares, curbs or other public ways in the City which have been or may hereafter be dedicated and open to public use, or such other public property so designated in any law of this State. 
    Tenant and occupant , applied to a building or land, includes any person who occupies all or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
    Written or in writing includes any representation of words, letters, symbols or figures; however, this definition does not affect any law relating to signatures. 
    Year means a calendar year. 
(Prior code,  1.02.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-2-20. - Computation of time. 
    Except as provided by applicable state law, the time within which an act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last day; but if the time for an act to be done shall fall on Saturday, Sunday or a legal holiday, the act shall be done upon the next regular business day following such Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday. 
(Prior code,  1.02.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-2-30. - Title of office. 
    Use of the title of any officer, employee, department, board or commission means that officer, employee, department, board or commission of the City, or his or her designated representative. 
(Prior code,  1.02.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-2-40. - Usage of terms. 
    All words and phrases shall be construed and understood according to the common and approved usage of the language; but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning. 
(Prior code,  1.02.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-2-50. - Grammatical interpretation. 
    The following grammatical rules shall apply to this Code and to City ordinances: 
(1)  Gender. Any gender includes the other genders. 
(2)  Singular and plural. The singular number includes the plural and the plural includes the singular. 
(3)  Tenses. Words used in the present tense include the past and future tenses and vice versa, unless manifestly inapplicable. 
(4)  Use of words and phrases. Words and phrases not specifically defined shall be construed according to the context and approved usage of the language. 
(Prior code,  1.02.040; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 3 - General 

Sec. 1-3-10. - Titles and headings not part of Code. 
    Chapter, article and section headings contained herein shall not be deemed to govern, limit, modify or any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any chapter, article or section hereof. Chapter and Article titles, headings, numbers and titles of sections and other divisions in this Code or in supplements made to this Code are inserted in this Code, may be inserted in supplements to this Code for the convenience of persons using this Code, and are not part of this Code. 
(Prior code,  1.02.120; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-3-20. - Authorized acts. 
    When this Code requires an act to be done by any officer, employee, department, board or commission of the City which may be done as well by an agent, designee or representative as by the principal, such requirement shall be construed to include all such acts performed when done by an authorized agent, designee or representative. 
(Prior code,  1.02.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-3-30. - Purpose of Code. 
    The provisions of this Code, and all proceedings under them, are to be construed with a view to effect their objectives and to promote justice. 
(Prior code,  1.02.060; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-3-40. - Repeal of ordinances. 
    The repeal of an ordinance shall not repeal the repealing clause of such ordinance or revive any ordinance which has been repealed thereby. 
(Prior code,  1.02.070; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-3-50. - Publication of ordinances. 
    All ordinances, as soon as possible after their passage, shall be recorded in a book kept for that purpose and authenticated by the signature of the Mayor and City Clerk. All ordinances of a general or permanent nature, and those imposing any fine or forfeiture, shall be published in a newspaper published within the City or, if there is none, in a newspaper of general circulation in the City. Such ordinances shall not take effect until 30 days after such publication, except for ordinances calling for special elections or necessary for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health and safety and containing the reasons making the same necessary in a separate section. The excepted ordinances shall take effect upon their final passage and adoption and the approval and signature of the Mayor, if they are adopted by an affirmative vote of two-thirds of the members of the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-3-60. - Amendments to Code. 
(a)  Ordinances and parts of ordinances of a permanent and general nature, passed or adopted after the adoption of this Code, may be passed or adopted either in the form of amendments to this Code or without specific reference to this Code. However, in either case, all such ordinances and parts of ordinances shall be deemed amendments to this Code, and all of the substantive, permanent and general parts of said ordinances and changes made thereby shall be inserted and made in this Code as provided in Section 1-3-70 below. 
(b)  In compiling and preparing the ordinances of the City for adoption and revision as part of this Code, certain grammatical changes and other changes may be made in one or more of said ordinances. It is the intention of the City Council that all such changes be adopted as part of this Code as if the ordinances so changed had been previously formally amended to read as such. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-3-70. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  The City Council shall cause supplementation of this Code to be prepared and printed from time to time as it may see fit. All substantive, permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the City Council or adopted by initiative and referendum, and all amendments and changes in temporary and special ordinances or other measures included in this Code prior to the supplementation and since the previous supplementation, shall be included. 
(b)  The City Clerk is hereby directed to certify and forward to the codifier of this Code all ordinances enacted by the City Council since the most recent codification of ordinances, to coincide with chapters, articles, divisions, sections and subsections as they currently exist within this Code and to resolve any inconsistencies regarding capitalization, grammar and numbering or placement of chapters, articles, divisions, sections and subsections in this Code. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the City Clerk to keep up to date one certified copy of the book containing this Code required to be filed in the office of the City Clerk for the use of the public. 
(Prior code,  1.02.160; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-3-80. - Examination of Code. 
    The Mayor and City Clerk shall carefully examine at least one copy of the Code adopted by this ordinance to see that it is a true and correct copy of this Code. Similarly, after each supplement has been prepared, printed and inserted in this Code, the Mayor and City Clerk shall carefully examine at least one copy of this Code as supplemented. The copy of this Code as originally adopted or amended shall constitute the permanent and general ordinances of the City and shall be so accepted by the courts of law, administrative tribunals and all others concerned. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-3-90. - Copy of Code on file. 
(a)  At least one copy of this Code as examined and any secondary code adopted by the City shall be kept on file in the office of the City Clerk at all times, and such Code may be inspected by any interested person at any time during regular office hours, but may not be removed from the City Clerk's office except upon proper order of a court of law. 
(b)  One copy of each adopted secondary code may also be kept in the office of the Chief Enforcement Officer in addition to the office of the City Clerk. 
(Prior code,  1.02.160; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-3-100. - Sale of Code books. 
    Copies of this Code book may be purchased from the City Clerk upon the payment of a fee as set forth in the City's Fee Schedule adopted by resolution of the City Council. 
(Prior code,  1.02.160; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-3-110. - Public record. 
    Records of the City shall be open to inspection at reasonable times and under reasonable regulations established by the City, as provided by Article 72 of Title 24, C.R.S. 
(Ord. No. 773,  12, 12-11-2001; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-3-120. - Severability. 
    The provisions of this Code are declared to be severable, and if any section, provision or part thereof is held unconstitutional or invalid, the remainder of this Code shall continue in full force and effect, it being the legislative intent that this Code would have been adopted even if such unconstitutional matter had not been included therein. It is further declared that, if any provision or part of this Code, or the application thereof to any person or circumstances, is held invalid, the remainder of this Code and the application thereof to other persons shall not be affected thereby. 
(Prior code,  1.02.180; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 4 - General Penalty 

Sec. 1-4-10. - Violations. 
    It is a violation of this Code for any person to do or perform any act which is forbidden or declared to be unlawful or to fail to do or perform any act required in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-4-20. - General penalty for violation. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code or any other ordinance of this City hereafter enacted or any section, rule or regulation prorogated under the provisions of this Code, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful in offense or misdemeanor or the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an offense or misdemeanor. Any person who violates or fails to comply with any provision of this Code, for which a different penalty is not specifically provided, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 or by imprisonment not exceeding one year, or by both such fine and imprisonment, except as hereinafter provided in Section 1-4-30. Such person may also be directed to serve community service in addition to such penalty and/or imprisonment. In addition, such person shall pay all costs and expenses in the case, including attorney fees. 
(b)  Every day such violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Prior code,  1.02.170; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-4-30. - Application of penalties to juveniles. 
    Every person who, at the time of commission of the offense, was at least ten but not yet 18 years of age, and who is subsequently convicted of or pleads guilty or nolo contendere to a violation of any provision of this Code shall be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 per violation or count. Any voluntary plea of guilty or nolo contendere to the original charge or to a lesser or substituted charge shall subject the person so pleading to all fines and/or penalties applicable to the original charge. Nothing in this Section shall be construed to prohibit incarceration in an appropriate facility, at the time of charging, of a juvenile violating any section of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-4-40. - Altering or tampering with Code; penalty. 
    Any person who alters, changes or amends this Code, except in the manner prescribed in this Chapter, or who alters or tampers with this Code in any manner so as to cause the ordinances of the City to be misrepresented thereby, shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided by Section 1-4-20 hereof. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-4-50. - Penalty for violation of ordinances adopted after adoption of Code. 
    Any person who violates any provision of any ordinance of a permanent and general nature passed or adopted after adoption of this Code, either before or after it has been inserted in this Code by a supplement, shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided by Section 1-4-20 unless another penalty is specifically provided for the violation. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-4-60. - Prohibited acts. 
    Whenever any act or omission is made unlawful in this Code, it is also unlawful to cause, allow, permit, aid, abet or suffer such unlawful act or omission. Concealing or in any manner aiding in the concealing of any unlawful act or omission is similarly unlawful. 
(Prior code,  1.02.050; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 5 - Inspections 

Sec. 1-5-10. - Entry. 
    Whenever necessary to make an inspection to enforce any provision of this Code or any ordinance, or whenever there is probable cause to believe that there exists an ordinance violation in any building or upon any premises within the jurisdiction of the City, any public inspector of the City may, upon presentation of proper credentials and upon obtaining permission of the occupant or, if unoccupied, the owner, enter such building or premises at all reasonable times to inspect the same or to perform any duty imposed upon him or her by ordinance. In the event the occupant or, if unoccupied, the owner, refuses entry to such building or premises, or the public inspector is unable to obtain permission of such occupant or owner to enter such building or premises, the public inspector is empowered to seek assistance from any court of competent jurisdiction in obtaining such entry. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-5-20. - Authority to enter premises under emergency. 
    Law enforcement officers certified with the State, members of the Fire Department, other fire departments operating under a mutual assistance agreement or automatic aid agreement with the City, certified emergency medical technicians and paramedics during the course of employment with a governmental agency are hereby granted the authority to enter private residences within the City without invitation from the occupant of the residence at any time such persons have reasonable grounds to believe a medical emergency is in progress within the subject premises and the occupant of such premises is incapable of consenting to the entry because of such medical emergency. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 1-5-30. - Announcement of purpose and authority to enter premises. 
    Unauthorized entry pursuant to Section 1-5-20 shall be permissible only after the individuals seeking entry have announced both their purpose and authority in a loud and conspicuous voice and have waited a reasonable period of time for the occupant to respond before making entry. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 6 - Seal 

Sec. 1-6-10. - Corporate seal. 
    A seal, not exceeding two inches in diameter, having in the center the impression of a shock of wheat and surrounding this the inscription "City of Rocky Ford, Colorado," shall be the Seal of the City. 
(Prior code,  2.04.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
CHAPTER 2 - Administration 
ARTICLE 1 - Elections 

Sec. 2-1-10. - Conduct of elections. 
(a)  The City hereby adopts the Uniform Election Code of 1992 in lieu of the Colorado Municipal Election Code of 1965, for the purpose of participating in coordinated elections with Otero County, in accordance with the provisions of Section 31-10-102.7, C.R.S. 
(b)  The City Clerk is hereby directed to work with the County Clerk and Recorder and to take all necessary actions to conduct regular municipal elections in accordance with the provisions of Subsection (a) above and all other appropriate statutes. 
(Prior code,  2.10.010, 2.10.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-1-20. - Write-in candidate affidavit. 
    No write-in vote for any municipal election shall be counted unless an affidavit of intent has been filed with the City Clerk by the person whose name is written in prior to 20 days before the day of the election, indicating that such person desires the office and is qualified to assume the duties of that office if elected. 
(Prior code,  2.02.112; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-1-30. - Cancellation of election. 
(a)  If the only matter before the voters in a City election is the election of persons to office and if, at the close of business on the nineteenth day before the election, there are not more candidates than offices to be filled at such election, including candidates filing affidavits of intent as set forth in Section 2-1-20 above, the City Clerk if instructed by resolution of the City Council either before or after such date, shall cancel the election and the candidates, by resolution of the City Council, shall be declared to be elected. 
(b)  Notice of such cancellation shall be published, if possible, and notice of such cancellation shall be posted at each polling place and in not less than one other public place. 
(Prior code,  2.02.112; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-1-40. - Election wards. 
    The City is hereby divided into three wards for municipal purposes, at any and all municipal elections held by the City. The wards shall be as follows: 
(1)  First Ward. All that part of the City of Rocky Ford lying West and North of a line described as follows: Beginning at the intersection of the center line of North Eighth Street with the City Limit line; thence South along the center line of North Eighth Street to the intersection with the center line of Ash Avenue; thence West along the center line of Ash Avenue to the intersection with the center line of Seventh Street; thence Southerly along the center line of Seventh Street to the intersection with the North line of Lot 1, Swink's Second Subdivision; thence East along said line to the Northeast corner of said Lot 1; thence South along the East line of said Lot 1 to the Southeast corner of said Lot 1; thence West along the South line of said Lot 1 to the Southwest corner of said Lot 1; thence South along the West lines of Lots 8, 13 and 20 of Swink's Second Subdivision to the center line of Washington Avenue; thence West along the center line of Washington Avenue to the intersection with the center line of Meloneer Lane; thence Southerly along said center line of Meloneer Lane to the Southerly City Limit line. 
(2)  Second Ward. All that part of the City of Rocky Ford described as follows: Beginning at the intersection of the center line of North Eighth Street with the City Limit line; thence South along the center line of North Eighth Street to the intersection with the center line of Ash Avenue; thence West along the center line of Ash Avenue to the intersection with the center line of Seventh Street; thence Southerly along the center line of Seventh Street to the intersection with the North line of Lot 1, Swink's Second Subdivision; thence East along said line to the Northeast corner of said Lot 1; thence South along the East line of said Lot 1 to the Southeast corner of said Lot 1; thence West along the South line of said Lot 1 to the Southwest corner of said Lot 1; thence South along the West lines of Lots 8, 13 and 20 of Swink's Second Subdivision to the center line of Washington Avenue; thence West along the center line of Meloneer Lane to the Southerly City Limit line; thence following the City Limit line to the East to the intersection with the East line of Lot 30, Swink's Second Subdivision; thence North along the East lines of Lots 30, 27, 22 and 11, Swink's Second Subdivision, to the intersection with the center line of Spruce Avenue; thence East along said center line to Tenth Street; thence Northeasterly along the center line of Tenth Street to the City Limit line; thence following the City Limit line in a counterclockwise direction to the point of beginning. 
(3)  Third Ward. All that part of the City of Rocky Ford lying East of a line described as follows: Beginning at the intersection of the center line of North Tenth Street with the Northerly City Limit line; thence Southerly along the center line of Tenth Street to the intersection with the center line of Spruce Avenue; thence West along the center line of Spruce Avenue to the South along the East line of Lots 11, 22, 27 and 30, Swink's Second Subdivision, to the Southerly City Limit. 
(Prior code,  2.02.114; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 2 - Mayor and City Council 

Sec. 2-2-10. - City Council; terms, authority, qualifications and vacancies. 
(a)  Term of office. At the November 7, 1989 election, six Council Members shall be elected. The candidate for Council Member from each election ward receiving the highest number of votes shall be elected for a four-year term, and the candidate for Council Member from each election ward receiving the next highest number of votes shall be elected for a two-year term. At the next subsequent regular election and at each regular election thereafter, three Council Members shall be elected to serve four-year terms. 
(b)  Authority. The City Council shall constitute the legislative body of the City, shall have the power and authority, except as otherwise provided by statute, to exercise all power conferred upon or possessed by the City, and shall have the power and authority to adopt such laws, ordinances and resolutions as it shall deem proper in the exercise thereof. 
(c)  Qualifications. Each Council Member shall be a resident of the City and a registered elector who has resided within the City limits for a period of at least 12 consecutive months immediately preceding the date of the election. He or she shall also be at least 18 years of age. However, in case of annexation of property, any person who has resided within the annexed territory for the time prescribed in this Subsection shall be deemed to have met the residence requirements for the City. 
(d)  Removal from office. Any Council Member who willfully absents himself or herself from two consecutive meetings of the City Council, one of which is a regular meeting, may be removed from office by a quorum of all the members elected to City Council. When any officer ceases to reside within the City limits, he or she may be removed from office pursuant to this Subsection. 
(e)  Vacancies. In case of the death, resignation, vacation or removal of any Council Member during his or her term of office, the City Council, by a majority vote of all remaining members thereof, may select and appoint, from among the duly qualified electors of the City, a suitable person to fill the vacancy in the City Council or in any other elected office. The person so appointed shall hold office until the next regular election and until his or her successor is elected and qualified. If the term of the person creating the vacancy in any election ward was to extend beyond the next regular election, the person elected to fill the vacancy in such election ward shall be elected for the unexpired term. Where vacancies exist in any election ward in the office of Council Members and successors are to be elected at the next election to fill the unexpired terms, the candidate for Council Member from such election ward receiving the highest number of votes shall be elected to a four-year term and the candidate from such election ward receiving the next highest number of votes shall be elected to fill the unexpired term. 
(Prior code,  2.02.080, 2.02.110; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-2-20. - Mayor. 
(a)  The Mayor shall be elected to serve a term of two years. The Mayor shall meet the same qualifications as a Council Member and, in the event of a vacancy in the office of Mayor, such vacancy shall be filled in the same manner as a vacancy in the office of Council Member, as set forth in Section 2-2-10 above. 
(b)  The Mayor shall be the presiding officer of the City Council and shall have the same voting powers as any Council Member. 
(c)  The Mayor shall be considered a member of the City Council and shall be recognized as the head of the City government for all ceremonial purposes. 
(d)  The Mayor shall execute and authenticate by his or her signature all bonds, warrants, contracts and instruments of and concerning the business of the City, as the Council members or any statutes or ordinances may require. The Mayor may authorize the City Manager to perform any of the duties listed herein. 
(e)  The Mayor shall exercise all powers and perform such other duties as are conferred upon him or her by state statutes and this Code. 
(Ord. No. 773,  1, 12-11-2001; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-2-30. - Mayor Pro Tem. 
    At its first meeting following each biennial election, the City Council shall choose one of the Council Members to serve as Mayor Pro Tem. In the absence of the Mayor from any meeting of the City Council, during the absence of the Mayor from the City or during the inability of the Mayor to act, the Mayor Pro Tem shall perform the duties of the Mayor. 
(Prior code,  2.02.090; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-2-40. - Acting Mayor. 
    In the event of the absence or disability of both the Mayor and the Mayor Pro Tem, the Council Members may designate another Council Member to serve as acting Mayor during such absence or disability. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-2-50. - Compensation. 
(a)  The Mayor shall receive such compensation for his or her services as set by ordinance of the City Council. 
(b)  Each Council Member shall receive such compensation for his or her services as set by ordinance of the City Council. 
(c)  The compensation paid to any member of the City Council, including the Mayor, shall not be increased or diminished for the term of office for which he or she has been elected or appointed. Any Mayor or Council Member who has resigned or vacated an office prior to the end of his or her elective or appointed term shall not be eligible to election or reappointment to the same during such term if the rate of compensation has been increased. 
(Prior code,  2.02.100; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-2-60. - Regular meetings. 
    The regular meetings of the City Council shall be held two times per month at the Rocky Ford City Hall, and the date and time of the meetings shall be established at the first meeting of the newly elected City Council. No meeting shall be held on any legal holiday. 
(Prior code,  2.02.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-2-70. - Special meetings. 
(a)  Any four members of the City Council are hereby authorized to call special meetings of the City Council for the transaction of all corporate business when in their judgment special meetings shall be deemed necessary. 
(b)  Whenever a special meeting of the City Council is deemed necessary, a written notice of the time and place of such special meeting shall be given to each member of the City Council, which notice shall be personally served or left at the member's usual place of residence by the City Clerk, at least two hours in advance of the meeting. 
(c)  The City Council at any duly convened meeting may, by majority vote, call a special meeting for a future date. Notice of such meeting shall be given to any member of the City Council not in attendance. 
(d)  Should the City Council convene for a special meeting pursuant to a request of an interested party for the purpose of accommodating time constraints of said interested party, the City Council may, in its discretion, assess fees for the special meeting against the interested party. The City Council may from time to time by resolution adopt a Fee Schedule which may be assessed for special meetings. Said fees shall reasonably compensate the staff of the City and the City Attorney for time spent in preparation for attendance at special meetings. 
(Prior code,  2.02.020, 2.02.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-2-80. - Meeting rules. 
    In accordance with Section 31-4-108, C.R.S., the City Council shall determine its own rules of procedure and order of business, and shall keep a journal of its proceedings. The City Council may compel attendance of Council Members and may punish any Council Member for misconduct. 
(Ord. No. 773,  2, 12-11-2001; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-2-90. - Adjourned meetings. 
(a)  The City Council may at any regular or special meeting adjourn the meeting to any other evening prior to the evening for the next regular meeting. In such cases, notice thereof shall be given to each member of the City Council by the City Clerk, by mail or otherwise. 
(b)  Three members shall be a quorum for adjourning a meeting, as provided in Subsection (a) above. 
(Prior code,  2.02.040, 2.02.050; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-2-100. - Boards and commissions. 
    The following boards and commissions are responsible to the City Council, and the Mayor may establish formal lines of communication with the boards and commissions: 
(1)  Arts Commission. 
(2)  Board of Adjustment. 
(3)  Library Board. 
(4)  Museum Board. 
(5)  Planning Commission. 
(6)  Rocky Ford Country Club. 
(7)  Swimming Pool Commission. 
(8)  Tree Board. 
(Prior code,  2.02.071; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 3 - Officers and Employees 
Division 1 - General 

Sec. 2-3-10. - Appointed officers. 
(a)  The following officers of the City shall be appointed by a majority vote of all the members of the City Council: 
(1)  City Manager; 
(2)  City Attorney; and 
(3)  Municipal Judge. 
(b)  Said officers shall hold their respective offices until their successors are duly appointed and qualified. Vacancies shall be filled by appointment of the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-3-20. - Powers and duties of officers. 
    Appointed officers of the City shall have such powers and perform such duties as are now or hereafter may be prescribed by state law and the ordinances of the City. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-3-30. - Oath of office; bond. 
(a)  When required by the City Council, each officer or employee, before entering upon the duties of his or her office, shall take and subscribe to an oath to support the Constitutions and laws of the United States and the State and the ordinances of the City.
