(b)  The City Manager, the City Clerk and such other officers and employees as the City Council may require shall give bonds in such amounts and with such sureties as may be approved by the City Council, conditioned upon the faithful performance of all duties pertaining to such office, the proper care of all money or property of the City coming into his or her hands and the proper accounting for or delivery of the same. The premiums on such bonds shall be paid by the City. The City Council may waive the requirements of such bonds. 
(Ord. No. 773,  14, 12-11-2001; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-3-40. - Compensation. 
    The salary or compensation of officers and employees shall be established by ordinance of the City Council, which shall provide uniform compensation for like services. Such schedules of compensation may fix the minimum and maximum for any grade. An increase in compensation, within the limits provided for the grade, may be granted at any time by the City Manager or other appointing authority upon the basis of efficiency and seniority. 
(Ord. No. 773,  13, 12-11-2001; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-3-50. - Removal of City officers. 
(a)  Cause for removal. By a majority vote of all members of the City Council, any appointed officer of the City may be removed from office. No such removal shall be made without a charge in writing and an opportunity of hearing being given unless the officer against whom the charge is made has moved out of the limits of the City. Appointed officers or employees of the City need not reside within the limits of the City. A Municipal Judge may be removed during his or her term of office only for cause, as set forth in Section 13-10-105(2), C.R.S. 
(b)  Specification of charges. All charges preferred against any such officer of the City, for any cause or causes specified in the foregoing subsection for the removal of such officer, shall be made in writing to the City Council and shall clearly specify any such cause or causes of removal. 
(c)  Service of charges and notice of hearing. A copy of such charges and specifications, together with a notice of the time and place of hearing, shall be served upon the accused at least 15 days before the day of hearing. 
(d)  Hearing. At the time and place so set, the City Council shall meet and proceed according to its rules to hear the evidence against the accused officer, as well as the evidence offered in his or her behalf, adjourning from time to time as may be necessary, until all the evidence has been given. 
(e)  Decision. Within three days after the evidence has been given, the City Council shall vote by yeas and nays upon each charge and specification separately. The question upon each charge shall be "Is the accused guilty?" If the City Council, by a lawful number, finds the accused officer guilty of any specified charge aforesaid, it shall resolve that the accused be removed from office and his or her office declared vacant. 
(f)  Appearance by counsel. Upon the trial as aforesaid, the accused shall be heard by himself or herself or by counsel in his or her defense, and the City may also be represented by counsel in the prosecution of such charges. The Chief of Police, the Mayor or the City Clerk may serve any paper required to be served by any provisions of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-3-60. - City Attorney. 
(a)  The City Council shall appoint a City Attorney, who, upon taking office, shall be an attorney at law licensed to practice law in the State. The City Attorney shall serve at the pleasure of the City Council. The City Attorney shall advise the City Council and City officials in matters relating to their official powers and duties, and perform such other duties as the City Council may prescribe by ordinance or resolution. 
(b)  The City Council may provide the City Attorney with such assistants as the City Council may deem necessary and may, on its own motion or upon request of the City Attorney in special cases, employ special counsel. 
(c)  The City Council shall establish compensation for the City Attorney, his or her assistants and special counsel. Any agreement for compensation to special counsel shall be made only upon approval of the City Council and prior to the service being rendered. 
(Ord. No. 773,  3, 12-11-2001; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-3-70. - Social Security. 
    In the opinion of the City Council, the extension of the Social Security system to employees and officers of the City will be of great benefit, not only to the employees and officers by providing that said employees and officers may participate in the provision of the Old Age and Survivors Insurance System, but also to the City by enabling it to attract and retain in employment the best of personnel and thus increase the efficiency of its government. 
(Prior code,  2.20.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Division 2 - City Manager 

Sec. 2-3-110. - Qualifications. 
(a)  The City Council shall appoint a City Manager, who shall be the chief administrative officer of the City. The City Manager shall be chosen solely on the basis of his or her executive and administrative qualifications and need not, when appointed, be a resident of the City or the State. 
(b)  No member of the City Council shall be chosen as City Manager during his or her term of office. 
(c)  The City Manager shall be appointed for an indefinite term. However, the City Manager may be removed at the pleasure of the City Council for cause. 
(1)  Before the City Manager may be removed, he or she must be given, if he or she so demands, a written statement of the reasons alleged for his or her removal. The City Manager has the right to be heard thereon at a public meeting of the City Council prior to the final vote on the question of his or her removal. Pending and during such hearing, the City Council may suspend him or her from office. 
(2)  The action of the City Council in suspending or removing the City Manager shall be final. It is the intent of this Section to vest all authority and to fix all responsibility for such suspension or removal in the City Council. 
(d)  In case of the absence or disability of the City Manager, the City Council may designate a qualified person to perform the duties of the office during such absence or disability. 
(Ord. No. 773,  5, 12-11-2001; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-3-120. - Powers and responsibilities. 
(a)  The City Manager is responsible to the City Council for the proper administration of all affairs of the City placed in his or her charge and, to that end and except as otherwise provided in Subsection (b) below, he or she shall have the power to appoint and remove all officers and employees in the administrative service of the City except the City Attorney and the Municipal Judge. Appointments made by the City Manager shall be on the basis of executive and administrative ability, training and experience of such appointees in the work which they are to perform. All such appointments shall be without definite term. 
(b)  Officers and employees appointed by the City Manager may be removed by him or her at any time for cause. The decision of the City Manager in any such case shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 773,  6, 12-11-2001; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-3-130. - City Council not to interfere. 
(a)  Neither the City Council nor any of its committees or members shall direct or request the appointment of any person to or his or her removal from office by the City Manager or in any other manner take part in the appointment or removal of employees in the administrative service of the City. 
(b)  The City Council and its members shall deal with that portion of the administrative service for which the City Manager is responsible solely through the City Manager, and neither the City Council nor any member thereof shall give orders to any subordinate of the City, either publicly or privately. Any violation of the provisions of this Section by a member of the City Council constitutes misconduct and is punishable in such manner as may be determined by the other members of the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 773,  7, 12-11-2001; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-3-140. - Duties of City Manager. 
    It is the duty of the City Manager to perform the following actions: 
(1)  Act as chief conservator of the peace within the City. 
(2)  Supervise the administration of the affairs of the City. 
(3)  See that the ordinances of the City and the applicable laws of the State are enforced. 
(4)  Make such recommendations to the City Council concerning the affairs of the City as seem desirable to him or her. 
(5)  Keep the City Council advised of the financial conditions and future needs of the City. 
(6)  Prepare and submit to the City Council the annual budget estimate. 
(7)  Prepare and submit to the City Council such reports as are required by the City Council. 
(8)  Prepare and submit each month to the City Council a detailed report covering all activities of the City, including a summary statement of revenues and expenditures for the preceding month, detailed as to appropriations and funds in such a manner as to show the exact financial condition of the City and of each department and division thereof as of the last day of the previous month. 
(9)  Perform such other duties as may be required by him or her by ordinance or resolution of the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 773,  8, 12-11-2001; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-3-150. - Responsibilities at meetings. 
    The City Manager shall attend and participate in all City Council meetings, but shall have no vote therein. The City Manager has the right to take part in the discussion of all matters coming before the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 773,  9, 12-11-2001; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-3-160. - Administrative plan. 
(a)  The City Council, upon the report and recommendation of the City Manager, has the power to create and establish by ordinance administrative departments of City administration. 
(b)  It is the duty of the City Manager to propose a plan of administrative organization to the City Council within 60 days after his or her appointment, which plan, if approved by the City Council, shall be adopted by ordinance. 
(c)  The administrative plan shall provide for the establishment of the office of City Clerk. The City Clerk shall be ex officio Finance Director and Clerk of the City Council. Subject to the supervision and control of the City Manager in all matters, the City Clerk shall issue licenses, collect license fees, make and keep a journal of proceedings of the City Council, have custody of all public records of the City not specifically entrusted to any other office, and perform such other duties pertaining to such offices as are by ordinance required or assigned to the City Clerk by the City Manager. 
(d)  The administrative plan shall also provide for a Chief of Police, Fire Chief, Finance Director and such other officers as are deemed necessary for the efficient administration of the City, and such plan may or may not include, in the discretion of the City Council, all of the officers named in Sections 31-4-105 and 31-4-107, C.R.S. All such officers shall be appointed by the City Manager as provided in Section 31-4-211, C.R.S. 
(e)  The plan of the City Manager shall be placed on file and shall be a matter of public record open to the examination by the public at all reasonable times. The City Council, upon recommendation of the City Manager, may change or abolish, by ordinance, any department or office established by ordinance; prescribe, distribute or discontinue the functions and duties of departments and offices so established; or assign additional functions and duties to departments and offices. 
(Ord. No. 773,  10, 12-11-2001; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Division 3 - Code Enforcement Officer 

Sec. 2-3-210. - Position created. 
    There is hereby created within the City a position to be called and referred to as the Code Enforcement Officer. 
(Ord. No. 709,  2, 1-22-1996; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-3-220. - Duties and requirements. 
    The primary duties of the Code Enforcement Officer shall be to investigate and enforce this Code and the ordinances of the City, to sign, issue and serve summonses and complaints into Municipal Court for violations of this Code and City ordinances, and to otherwise perform those functions as indicated and directed by the City Manager and the Chief of Police. The Code Enforcement Officer shall be under the direct supervision of the City Manager and the Chief of Police, and the City Manager and the Chief of Police shall outline the duties, responsibilities and requirements of the job. 
(Ord. No. 709,  3, 1-22-1996; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-3-230. - Status of employment. 
    The Code Enforcement Officer may be employed on a full-time or a part-time basis, as determined by the Chief of Police, and shall be subject to all of the provisions, conditions, benefits and obligations of the City personnel system. The Code Enforcement Officer shall serve at the pleasure and will of the Chief of Police. This Section does not create any express or implied right of employment or continued employment. 
(Ord. No. 709,  4, 1-22-1996; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-3-240. - Requirements and prohibitions. 
(a)  The Code Enforcement Officer shall not be required to be a certified law enforcement officer. 
(b)  The Code Enforcement Officer shall not be authorized to participate in the investigation or prosecution of criminal matters. 
(Ord. No. 709,  5, 1-22-1996; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 4 - Municipal Court 
Division 1 - Generally 

Sec. 2-4-10. - Creation of Municipal Court. 
    A qualified Municipal Court of record in and for the City is hereby created and established pursuant to and governed by the provisions of state law. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-4-20. - Original jurisdiction. 
    The Municipal Court shall have original jurisdiction of all cases arising under the provisions of this Code and ordinances of the City, with full power to punish violators thereof by the imposition of such fines and penalties as are prescribed in this Code or by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-4-30. - Appointment of Municipal Judge. 
    The Municipal Court shall be presided over by a Municipal Judge, appointed by the City Council in accordance with Section 13-10-105(1), C.R.S. The Municipal Judge may be removed during his or her term of office only for cause, as provided in Section 13-10-105(2), C.R.S. In the absence of the Municipal Judge so appointed, the City Council shall designate one or more substitute Judges to serve. 
(Ord. No. 773,  4, 12-11-2001; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-4-40. - Compensation of Judge. 
    The Municipal Judge shall receive such fixed compensation as may be established by resolution of the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 773,  4, 12-11-2001; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-4-50. - Oath of office. 
    Before entering upon the duties of his or her office, the Municipal Judge shall take an oath or affirmation that he or she will support the Constitution of the United States, the Constitution of the State and the laws of the City, and will faithfully perform the duties of his or her office. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-4-60. - Municipal Court Clerk. 
    The City Manager, with the approval of the City Council, may appoint a person to serve as Municipal Court Clerk, whose duties shall be those assigned by the Municipal Judge. The Municipal Judge may also act as Municipal Court Clerk in accordance with state statutes. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-4-70. - Sessions generally. 
(a)  There shall be regular sessions of the Municipal Court for the trial of cases as may be fixed by the Municipal Judge. The Municipal Judge may hold special sessions of court at any time, including Sundays, holidays and evenings. All sessions shall be open to the public. 
(b)  Where the nature of the case is such that it would be in the best interest of justice to exclude persons not directly connected with the proceedings, the Municipal Judge may order that the courtroom be cleared. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-4-80. - Rules of procedure. 
    In addition to other powers, the Municipal Judge shall have full power and authority to make and adopt rules and regulations for conducting the business of the Municipal Court, consistent with the Municipal Court Rules of Procedure promulgated by the Colorado Supreme Court. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-4-90. - Contempt power. 
(a)  When the Court finds any person to be in contempt, the Court may vindicate its dignity by imposing on the contemnor a fine not to exceed $300.00 and imprisonment not to exceed a term of ten days. 
(b)  In cases of indirect contempt, the alleged contemnor shall have all the rights, privileges, safeguards and protections of a defendant in a petty offense case, including but not limited to a formal written complaint, arraignment and trial by jury. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-4-100. - Notice to appear or pay fine. 
(a)  Tender by a peace officer or the Code Enforcement Officer of a summons and complaint or a penalty assessment notice shall constitute notice to that person to appear in Municipal Court at the time and date specified or to pay the required fine and surcharge thereon. 
(b)  It is a violation of this Section for any person to fail to appear before the Municipal Court at the time and date specified in the summons and complaint or at any subsequent time and date to which the matter is continued or otherwise set by the Municipal Court, or to fail to pay the required fine, surcharge or costs. 
(c)  Any person convicted of violating this Section may be incarcerated for a period of time not to exceed 90 days or fined an amount not to exceed $300.00, or both. 
(Ord. No. 789,  1-3, 9-23-2003; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-4-110. - Court fees and surcharges. 
(a)  Surcharge. A flat surcharge as set forth in the City's Fee Schedule on all violations of the Model Traffic Code and this Code shall be assessed where the Municipal Court finds a defendant guilty or the defendant enters a plea of guilty or nolo contendere. The surcharge shall be in addition to any penalty assessment and other costs imposed by the Municipal Court. 
(b)  Use of funds. Use of all monies received from the surcharge shall be restricted to the following purposes: 
(1)  The surcharge may be used to pay for the training and any related expense of all Police Department employees, including certified officers and civilian employees. 
(2)  Where available and needed, the surcharge fees may be used to cover the costs of incarcerated offenders. 
(3)  Surcharge funds may be used for training and education of community members with regard to community policing programs, crime prevention programs, community relations programs, community problem-solving programs and other educational programs dealing with community issues and concerns. 
(4)  The surcharge may be used to pay for the acquisition of law enforcement safety equipment as required to ensure the safety of City police officers and citizens. 
(c)  Scheduled payment fee. Upon imposition of a fine or costs by the Municipal Court, a defendant may elect to pay the fines and costs over a period of time pursuant to a schedule established by the Municipal Court from time to time, subject to the following: 
(1)  Where the defendant elects to make payments, a fee as set forth in the City's Fee Schedule shall be imposed by the Municipal Court. This fee shall be in addition to any fine or other costs imposed by the Municipal Court. 
(2)  A late payment fee as set forth in the City's Fee Schedule shall be imposed by the Municipal Court for each late payment. 
(d)  Amendment. The City Council may change or modify all surcharges and fees established in this Section by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 850,  a-c, 9-23-2008; Ord. No. 892, 4-23-2013; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Division 2 - Sentencing Alternatives 

Sec. 2-4-210. - Purpose and intent. 
    The purpose and intent of this Division is to establish, authorize and set forth the terms and conditions of a useful public service program and home detention program as sentencing alternatives to the Municipal Court and the Municipal Judge. 
(Prior code,  7.15.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-4-220. - Definitions. 
    As used in this Division, the following words or phrases are defined as follows: 
    Defendant means any adult or juvenile convicted of or placed on a deferred sentence or deferred prosecution of a Code violation, whether that conviction results following a trial or voluntary plea negotiation. 
    Home detention means an alternative to a sentence to incarceration in any jail, wherein the defendant is allowed to serve his or her sentence or term of incarceration or supervision, or some portion thereof, within his or her home or other appropriate residence. 
(Prior code,  7.15.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-4-230. - Authorization and establishment. 
    There is hereby authorized and established within the City a useful public service program and home detention program as sentencing alternatives, which are available and may be utilized by the Municipal Court. The Municipal Judge shall be authorized and entitled to consider, as alternative sentencing provisions, that any defendant who is convicted of a violation may be required to participate in useful public service within the City, or may be required to participate in home detention as a further requirement of any sentence imposed by the Municipal Court. Said useful public service sentence shall not exceed 75 hours, and said home detention shall not exceed 14 days. 
(Prior code,  7.15.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-4-240. - Specific conditions or requirements for useful public service. 
(a)  For the purpose of this Section, useful public service shall mean any work which is beneficial to the public, which work involves a minimum of direct supervision or other public costs in which work would not, with the exercise of reasonable care, endanger the health or safety of the person required to work. All such work to be performed must be of a public nature, and no work shall generate profit for any individual or have a direct benefit to any private business, organization or individual. 
(b)  No person shall be required to perform community service subject to the terms of this Division; however, any person who fails or refuses to participate in or complete community service as ordered by the Municipal Court shall be subject to further punishment, resentence or incarceration, as deemed appropriate by the Municipal Judge. 
(Prior code,  7.15.040; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-4-250. - Factors to be considered in useful public service. 
    The Municipal Court will take into account the defendant's health and physical condition; the defendant's emotional condition and needs; the defendant's ability to do or complete the work to be assigned based on the capabilities and training of the defendant; and the hazards or dangers associated with any particular type of work. The Municipal Court shall be authorized to appoint a Useful Public Service Coordinator to assist in locating and assigning useful public service to defendants. Any work to be assigned shall not be of a religious nature or encourage or express a particular religious belief, and the work to be done shall not be considered to be political in nature, supporting or opposing any particular candidate for office, referendum or ballot question. 
(Prior code,  7.15.050; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-4-260. - Costs of useful public service. 
    Each individual defendant who is sentenced as an alternative sentence to useful public service shall be required to pay to the Municipal Court as a cost of the useful public service an amount as set forth in the City's Fee Schedule. 
(Prior code,  7.15.060; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-4-270. - Conditions and criteria of in-home detention. 
    The Municipal Court shall be entitled to impose, as a sentence for any violation, nonpayment of a fine or contempt of court, a term of supervision within his or her home or other approved residence. Such sentence or term of supervision shall cause the defendant to remain within such defendant's approved resident at all times, except for approved employment, education or related events, court-ordered activities or medical needs. Supervision of the defendant shall include personal monitoring by an agent of the Municipal Court, or monitoring by electronic devices which are capable of detecting and recording the defendant's absence or presence within the approved residence. 
(Prior code,  7.15.070; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-4-280. - Fees and costs of in-home detention. 
    The defendant shall be required to pay to the Municipal Court any and all fees or costs associated with in-home detention, including but not limited to the costs of any electronic devices to monitor the defendant's whereabouts or the additional costs imposed by supervision of the defendant's in-home detention. 
(Prior code,  7.15.080; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-4-290. - Policies and procedures. 
    The Police Department is hereby authorized to develop specific policies and procedures concerning the useful public service program and the in-home detention program. These policies and procedures would include, but not be limited to, coordinating, listing, contacting and making arrangements for community service at various locations and/or for various nonprofit organizations; handling of the costs and payment of those costs for the useful public service program and in-home detention program; and making arrangements for monitoring performance by defendants in both of these programs. 
(Prior code,  7.15.080; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 5 - Police Department 

Sec. 2-5-10. - Creation; composition. 
    There is hereby created a Police Department for the City, which shall consist of one Chief of Police and as many police officers as may from time to time be deemed necessary for the safety and good order of the City. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-5-20. - Chief of Police; appointment and duties. 
(a)  In accordance with the administrative plan, the City Manager shall appoint a Chief of Police who shall be the head of the Police Department. It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to: 
(1)  See that the Code and ordinances of the City and the laws of the State are duly enforced and the rules and regulations of the Police Department are obeyed. 
(2)  Direct the operations of the Police Department, subject to the rules and regulations thereof. 
(3)  Render such accounts of the Police Department, his or her duties and receipts as may be required by the City Manager, and keep the records of his or her office open to inspection by the City Council at any time. 
(4)  Perform such other duties as may be required by the City Manager. 
(b)  Before entering upon the duties of such office, the Chief of Police shall take and subscribe to an oath that he or she will support the Constitution of the United States, the Constitution and laws of the State and ordinances of the City, and that he or she will faithfully perform the duties of the office upon which he or she is about to enter. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-5-30. - Duties of police officers. 
    All members of the Police Department shall have power and duties as follows: 
(1)  They shall perform all duties required by the Chief of Police. 
(2)  They shall be the enforcement officers of the City and shall see that the provisions of the ordinances of the City and the laws of the State are complied with. 
(3)  They shall execute and return all writs and processes directed to them by the Municipal Judge in any case arising under a City ordinance, and they may serve the same in any part of the County. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-5-40. - Oath of officers. 
    Before entering upon the duties of his or her office, each police officer shall take and subscribe an oath that he or she will support the Constitution of the United States, the Constitution and laws of the State and the ordinances of the City, and that he or she will faithfully perform the duties of the office upon which he or she is about to enter. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 6 - Fire Department 

Sec. 2-6-10. - Purpose. 
    The Fire Department is hereby designated as the official Fire Department of the City, and shall be known as the "Rocky Ford Fire Department." The purpose of the Fire Department shall be to prevent and extinguish fires; to educate the public in all matters pertaining to fires and fire prevention; to engage in first aid and rescue operations; and to care for all fire, first aid, rescue and other City property in its charge. The Fire Department shall at all times be under the supervision and control of the City Manager. 
(Prior code,  2.06.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-6-20. - Organization. 
(a)  New members shall be elected by the consent of the current members of the Fire Department. All compensation of firefighters shall be as provided by the City Council. 
(b)  The Fire Department shall adopt suitable bylaws, subject to the approval of the City Council, for the government of the Fire Department, such as are not in conflict with this Code, City ordinances or state and national laws. A copy of such bylaws and this Article shall be posted and maintained in a conspicuous place in the Fire Station. 
(Prior code,  2.06.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-6-30. - Officers. 
    Officers of the Fire Department shall be a Fire Chief, Assistant Fire Chief and Captain, who shall be appointed by the City Manager, to serve at the will of the City Manager, and such other officers elected by a majority vote of members of the Fire Department as may be provided for in the bylaws of the Fire Department, to serve for such time as the bylaws may provide. 
(Prior code,  2.06.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-6-40. - Duties of officers and members. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of each officer and member of the Fire Department to obey without question the orders of his or her superior officer in the line of duty. Each member of the Fire Department shall wear at all times when on duty such distinctive uniform or insignia as shall be prescribed in the bylaws. 
(b)  The Fire Chief or officers of the Fire Department shall be responsible for the discipline, good order and proper conduct of the whole Fire Department, for the enforcement of all ordinances and regulations pertaining thereto, and for the care and condition of the Fire Station, fire apparatus, first aid and rescue equipment and all other property of the Fire Department or in its charge. The Fire Chief shall have command and control of all officers and members of the Fire Department and all hoses, fire apparatus, first aid and rescue equipment and other property of the Department or in its charge. The Fire Chief shall have control of all persons present at fires and shall have the power, if need be, to summon any and all able-bodied persons present to aid in extinguishing any fire, in removing property from any burning and exposed building and in guarding the same. Any able-bodied person refusing to obey such summons shall be liable to penalties contained in this Code. 
(c)  In the absence of the Fire Chief, Assistant Fire Chief, Captain or senior member present, in order of rank and seniority, a firefighter who is present shall assume the duties and full authority of the Fire Chief until the arrival of a superior officer. After responding to an alarm, no member shall leave the scene of a fire or the apparatus until the fire has been extinguished and the apparatus returned to the station and properly cared for, except by permission of the commanding officer. 
(Prior code,  2.06.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-6-50. - Authority. 
    The Fire Chief and members acting under his or her orders shall have full and complete police power and authority at all fires. The Chief of Police and all members of the Police Department present shall be subject to his or her orders at fires and shall cooperate with him or her in the maintenance of order and safety. The Fire Chief may prescribe limits at fires within which no person shall be permitted except by his or her orders. 
(Prior code,  2.06.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-6-60. - Records and reports. 
(a)  The Fire Chief shall keep or cause to be kept a complete record of the activities of the Fire Department, and shall make a thorough investigation of each fire and make a report annually, and at such other times as may be directed by the Mayor, to the Mayor and the City Council, giving in detail the following information in regard to each fire, if available: cause, location, time, owner, tenant, occupancy, type of building, insurance carried, insurance paid, building loss, contents loss, how extinguished, apparatus used, firefighters present, firefighters absent, adequacy of water supply and pressure, and any other information of value. 
(b)  The Fire Chief, immediately after assuming office and annually thereafter, shall make an inventory of all property owned by the Fire Department or in its charge, (including first aid and rescue equipment), noting the condition of each article, which inventory shall be submitted to the Mayor and City Council, together with recommendations for the purchase of additional equipment needed and any other recommendations he or she may desire to submit affecting the Fire Department. 
(c)  The Fire Chief shall maintain in the office of the City Clerk an accurate list of the members of the Fire Department and shall report promptly any additions to or withdrawals from the membership. 
(Prior code,  2.06.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-6-70. - Loaning of apparatus. 
    Fire apparatus and other City property in charge of the Fire Department shall not be loaned or rented, except by permission of the Fire Chief. 
(Prior code,  2.06.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-6-80. - Interfering with Fire Department. 
(a)  No person shall be allowed to enter the fire station unless accompanied by a member of the Fire Department or by permission of the Fire Chief or officer in charge. No person shall interfere in any way with the Fire Department in the performance of its duties. No person not a member of the Fire Department shall use any of the fire apparatus unless acting under orders of the commanding officer or firefighter in charge of the apparatus. 
(b)  No person shall knowingly give a false alarm of fire except those for test purposes given or caused to be given by the Fire Chief or the Fire Department. No person shall interfere with any part of the fire alarm system. 
(Prior code,  2.06.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-6-90. - Right of entry. 
    The Fire Chief and members acting under orders shall have authority to enter any building in the proper performance of their duties. 
(Prior code,  2.06.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-6-100. - Cooperation of Water Department. 
    The Water Department shall cooperate with the Fire Department in every way possible to provide an adequate supply of water at pressure suitable for firefighting and shall supply the Fire Department with one or more accurate maps of the distributing system, showing the size and location of all mains, valves and fire hydrants, which maps shall be posted and maintained in a conspicuous place in the Fire Station. The Water Department shall promptly report to the Fire Department the opening and closing of all valves in street mains and any other information relative to the water supply to any and all parts of the City, which information shall also be posted for the information of firefighters and others. 
(Prior code,  2.06.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-6-110. - Emergency response authority. 
    The Fire Department is hereby designated as the emergency response authority for hazardous material incidents occurring within the corporate limits of the City. 
(Prior code,  2.06.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 7 - Recreation Department 

Sec. 2-7-10. - Department established. 
    There is hereby created and established a Recreation Department for the use and benefit of the inhabitants of the City and vicinity. 
(Prior code,  2.06.060; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-7-20. - Duties of employees. 
    The City Manager may employ such persons to perform the duties as the City Manager may consider necessary or advisable in furtherance of any recreation program of the City. All employees shall serve at the pleasure of the City Manager and shall perform such duties as required by the City Manager. 
(Prior code,  2.06.060; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-7-30. - Acquisition and disposal of property. 
    The City Council shall have the sole power to lease, purchase, acquire, hold and dispose of real or personal property for recreational purposes and shall have the sole power to contract any indebtedness for such purposes. The City may receive real or personal property by gift, grant or devise for use by the Recreation Department. 
(Prior code,  2.06.060; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-7-40. - Budget. 
    The City Manager shall prepare a budget for recreation each year. 
(Prior code,  2.06.060; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 8 - Arts Commission 

Sec. 2-8-10. - Purpose and intent. 
    The purpose and intent of this Article is to set up, establish and create the Rocky Ford Arts Commission. 
(Prior code,  2.06.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-8-20. - Creation. 
    There is hereby set up, established and created the Rocky Ford Arts Commission for the benefit of the inhabitants of the City and vicinity. 
(Prior code,  2.06.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-8-30. - Directors. 
    The Arts Commission shall consist of not less than five nor more than eleven Directors, which Directors shall be appointed by the City Council. Directors need not be residents of the City. 
(Prior code,  2.06.010; Ord. No. 802,  2, 8-10-2004; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-8-40. - Terms. 
    Each Director shall be appointed for a term of three years. Vacancies in the membership shall be appointed by the City Council to fill the unexpired term of a resigning Director. Directors shall not receive any salary or compensation. A Director may be removed by the City Council at any time. 
(Prior code,  2.06.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-8-50. - Powers and duties. 
    The Arts Commission shall meet and organize by election of a Chairperson, Vice Chairperson, Secretary and Treasurer, and such other officers as deemed appropriate. The Arts Commission shall have the authority to establish bylaws to regulate its activities. 
(Prior code,  2.06.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-8-60. - Annual report. 
    At the close of each year, the Chairperson shall make a report to the City Council concerning the activities of the Arts Commission during the year, sums of money received and expended, and all other matters deemed appropriate by the Arts Commission and City Council. 
(Prior code,  2.06.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-8-70. - Title to property. 
    The title to property given to or for the benefit of the Arts Commission shall be held in the name of the City of Rocky Ford. 
(Prior code,  2.06.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 9 - Board of Adjustment 

Sec. 2-9-10. - Creation. 
    A Board of Adjustment is hereby created by the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 799,  1, 3-9-2004; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-9-20. - Membership. 
    The Board of Adjustment shall consist of all members of the Planning Commission, except that the Board of Adjustment shall not include the Mayor or any member of the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 799,  2, 3-9-2004; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-9-30. - Term of office. 
    The term of office of a member shall be the same as each member's term of office as a member of the Planning Commission, and shall commence upon the appointment of a person to the Planning Commission without further action by the Mayor or City Council. 
(Ord. No. 799,  3, 3-9-2004; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-9-40. - Removal from office. 
    The City Council may, upon an affirmative vote of five members, remove a member of the Board of Adjustment for inefficiency, neglect of duty or malfeasance in office. The City Council shall give written notice to the member by certified mail, return receipt requested, 20 days prior to any action to remove that member. The member may make a written demand for a hearing and, upon receipt of the demand, the City Council shall conduct a hearing on the removal. Removal from the Board of Adjustment shall automatically terminate that member's term of office on the Planning Commission. 
(Ord. No. 799,  4, 3-9-2004; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-9-50. - Duties. 
(a)  The Board of Adjustment shall hear and decide appeals from and review any order, requirement, decision or determination made by any administrative official charged with the enforcement of Chapter 16 of this Code. 
(b)  The Board of Adjustment shall hear and decide all matters referred to it or upon which it is required to pass under the provisions of Chapter 16 of this Code. 
(c)  The concurring vote of two-thirds of the members of the Board of Adjustment shall be necessary to reverse any order, requirement, decision or determination of any such administrative official or to decide in favor of the applicant any matter upon which it is required to pass under any such zoning regulation, or to effect any variation in Chapter 16 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 799,  5, 3-9-2004; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-9-60. - Appeal from decision. 
(a)  Every decision of the Board of Adjustment shall be subject to review by certiorari by the Otero County District Court. 
(b)  Any appeal shall be filed with the District Court not later than 30 days from the final action taken by the Board of Adjustment. 
(Ord. No. 799,  6, 3-9-2004; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-9-70. - Appeal to Board of Adjustment. 
(a)  Any appeal to the Board of Adjustment shall be taken within 30 days of the final action taken by the administrative official. 
(b)  The appeal shall be commenced by filing with the administrative official from whom the appeal is taken to the Board of Adjustment a notice of appeal specifying the grounds for the appeal. The administrative official shall forthwith transmit to the Board of Adjustment all the papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. 
(Ord. No. 799,  7, 3-9-2004; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-9-80. - Stay of appeal. 
    An appeal stays all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from unless the administrative official from whom the appeal is taken certifies to the Board of Adjustment after the notice of appeal has been filed with him or her that, by reason of facts stated in the certificate, a stay would, in his or her opinion, cause imminent peril to life or property. In such case, proceedings shall not be stayed other than by a restraining order, which may be granted by the Board of Adjustment or by the District Court on application, on notice to the officer from whom the appeal is taken and on due cause shown. 
(Ord. No. 799,  8, 3-9-2004; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-9-90. - Hearing. 
(a)  The Board of Adjustment shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeal, give due notice thereof to the parties and decide the same within a reasonable period of time. 
(b)  At the hearing, any party may appear in person or by agent or attorney. 
(c)  The Board of Adjustment may reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or modify the order, requirement, decision or determination appealed from and shall make such order, requirement, decision or determination as in its opinion ought to be made in the premises and, to that end, has all the powers of the administrative official from whom the appeal is taken. 
(d)  Where there are practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships in the way of carrying out the strict letter of Chapter 16 of this Code, the Board of Adjustment has the power, in passing upon appeals, to vary or modify the application of the regulations or provisions of Chapter 16 or any other provision of this Code relating to the use, construction or alteration of buildings or structures or the use of land, so that the spirit of the regulations is observed, public safety and welfare secured and substantial justice done. 
(Ord. No. 799,  9, 3-9-2004; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 10 - Library Board 

Sec. 2-10-10. - Creation. 
    Pursuant to state statutes, the establishment of a public library in the City for the use and benefit of the inhabitants thereof is hereby created. The library shall be forever free for the use of the inhabitants of the City. 
(Prior code,  2.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-10-20. - Funds. 
    The City Council may appropriate, levy and collect annually, in the same manner that the general taxes of the City are levied and collected, a tax upon real and personal property for the maintenance of the public library, said tax not to exceed one and one-half mills on each dollar of assessed valuation within the City, the same to be kept separate and apart in a special fund entitled the "Public Library Fund." The City may further appropriate property and sales tax for the maintenance and operation of the public library. The Finance Director shall be the custodian of all funds appropriated, collected or donated for the public library, and all such funds may be used to pay the cost of operation and maintenance of the library. All expenditures will be approved by the Library Board and the City Council and paid by the Finance Director. 
(Prior code,  2.06.030; Ord. No. 749,  1, 2-9-1999; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-10-30. - Members. 
    A Library Board consisting of seven Trustees shall be appointed by the Mayor with the consent of the City Council. A Trustee shall be appointed to serve for three years. Vacancies in the Library Board shall be filled for unexpired terms as soon as possible and in the same manner in which members of the Library Board are regularly chosen. A Trustee shall not receive a salary or other compensation for services as a Trustee, but necessary traveling and subsistence expenses actually incurred may be paid from the library fund. A Trustee may be removed only by vote of the City Council. 
(Prior code,  2.06.030; Ord. No. 749,  2, 2-9-1999; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-10-40. - Organization, powers and duties. 
    The Library Board, immediately after appointment and annually thereafter, shall meet and organize by the election of a Chairperson, Secretary and Treasurer, and such other officers as may be deemed necessary. The Library Board, with the consent and approval of the City Council, shall have the power to: 
(1)  Adopt such laws, rules and regulations for its own guidance and for the government of the library as it deems expedient. 
(2)  Recommend a librarian for employment. 
(3)  Recommend the purchase of books, periodicals, maps, supplies and materials for the library on the recommendation of the librarian. 
(4)  Perform all other acts necessary for the orderly and efficient use of the library. 
(Prior code,  2.06.030; Ord. No. 749,  3, 2-9-1999; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-10-50. - Annual report. 
    At the close of each year, the Library Board or the librarian shall make a report to the City Council showing the condition of the library's trust during the year, the sums of money expended and the purpose of the expenditures, the number of books and periodicals on hand, the number added during the year, the number retired, the number loaned out, and such other statistics, information and suggestions as the Library Board deems of public interest. A copy of this report shall be filed with the City Clerk and the State Librarian. 
(Prior code,  2.06.030; Ord. No. 749,  4, 2-9-1999; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-10-60. - Nonresidents and inter-library exchanges. 
    The Library Board, under such rules and regulations as it may deem necessary and upon such terms and conditions as may be agreed upon, may allow nonresidents of the City to use the books and other materials thereof, and make exchanges of books or other materials with any other library, either permanently or temporarily. 
(Prior code,  2.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-10-70. - Willful retention of books. 
    A person who willfully retains any book, newspaper, magazine, pamphlet, manuscript or other property belonging in or to the public library or other educational institution for 30 days after notice in writing to return the same, given at the expiration of the time that, by the rules of such institution, such article or other property may be kept, shall be guilty of a violation and, upon conviction, shall be punished in accordance with the provisions of Section 1-4-20 of this Code. 
(Prior code,  2.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-10-80. - Title to property. 
    The title to property given to or for the use and benefit of the public library shall be in the name of the City of Rocky Ford and shall be held and used according to the terms of the gift. 
(Prior code,  2.06.030; Ord. No. 749,  5, 2-9-1999; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 11 - Museum Board 

Sec. 2-11-10. - Creation. 
    There is hereby established and created a public museum in the City for the use and benefit of the inhabitants of the City. 
(Prior code,  2.06.040; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-11-20. - Custodian of funds. 
    The Finance Director shall be custodian of all funds for the museum. All expenditures shall be approved by the Museum Board and the City Council and paid by the Finance Director. 
(Prior code,  2.06.040; Ord. No. 749,  7, 1999; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-11-30. - Management and control. 
    The Museum Board shall consist of five Trustees. The Trustees shall be appointed by the Mayor with the consent of the City Council. The appointment of the Trustees shall be for a term of four years. The terms of each Trustee may be staggered. Vacancies in the Museum Board shall be filled for unexpired terms as soon as possible in the same manner in which members of the Museum Board are regularly chosen. A Trustee shall not receive salary or other compensation for services as a Trustee, but a Trustee may be reimbursed by the City for necessary traveling and subsistence expenses actually incurred on behalf of museum affairs. A Trustee may be removed only by the vote of the City Council. 
(Prior code,  2.06.040; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016; Ord. No. 919, 9-13-2016 ) 
Sec. 2-11-40. - Powers and duties. 
    The Museum Board, immediately after appointment, shall meet and organize by the election of a Chairperson and Secretary, and such other officers as may be deemed necessary. The Museum Board, with the consent and approval of the City Council, shall have the power to: 
(1)  Adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations for its own guidance and for the welfare of the museum. 
(2)  Recommend a museum curator for employment by the City and, upon recommendation of the museum curator and approved by the Museum Board, such other employees as the Museum Board deems necessary, and prescribe the duties and fix the compensation of the museum curator and all employees. 
(3)  Participate in the preparation of an annual budget. 
(4)  Perform all other acts necessary for the orderly and efficient use of the museum. 
(Prior code,  2.06.040; Ord. No. 749,  8, 1999; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-11-50. - Annual report. 
    At the close of each year, the Museum Board shall make a report to the City Council showing the condition of the museum's trust during the year, including the sums of money expended and the purpose of the expenditures, the condition of the museum facilities, the condition of the contents of the museum and such other statistics, information and suggestions as the Museum Board deems of public interest. A copy of this report shall be filed with the City Clerk. 
(Prior code,  2.06.040; Ord. No. 749,  9, 1999; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-11-60. - Title to property. 
    The title to the property given to or for the use of or benefit of the public museum shall be in the City of Rocky Ford, to be held and used according to and subject to the terms of the gift. 
(Prior code,  2.06.040; Ord. No. 749,  10, 1999; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 12 - Planning Commission 

Sec. 2-12-10. - Creation. 
    A Planning Commission for the City is hereby created pursuant to state statutes. 
(Prior code,  2.06.050; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-12-20. - Members. 
    The Planning Commission shall consist of five members, elected for five-year staggered terms. All members of the Planning Commission shall be bona fide residents of the City. If any member ceases to reside in the City, his or her membership on the Planning Commission shall immediately terminate. All members of the Planning Commission shall serve without compensation, and the non-Council appointed members shall hold no other municipal office. 
(Prior code,  2.06.050; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-12-30. - Term of office; removal and vacancies. 
(a)  The terms of the City Council Members shall correspond to their respective official tenures. 
(b)  Members may be removed, after public hearing, by the Mayor for inefficiency, neglect of duty or malfeasance in office. The Mayor shall file a written statement of the reasons for such removal. 
(c)  Vacancies occurring other than through the expiration of a term shall be filled for the remainder of the unexpired term by the City Council. 
(Prior code,  2.06.050; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-12-40. - Voting privileges. 
    All members of the Planning Commission shall be entitled to vote. 
(Prior code,  2.06.050; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-12-50. - Organization and rules. 
    The Planning Commission shall, at its first meeting, elect a Chairperson from among the members of the Planning Commission, with all members being eligible. The Planning Commission shall create and fill such other of its offices as it may determine, with all members being eligible for such other offices. The term of the Chairperson shall be one year, with eligibility for re-election. The Planning Commission shall hold at least one regular meeting each month. It shall adopt rules for transaction of business and shall keep a record of its resolutions, transactions, findings and determinations, which record shall be a public record. 
(Prior code,  2.06.050; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-12-60. - Powers. 
    The Planning Commission shall have all of the powers and perform all of the duties specified by Parts 2 and 3 of Article 23 of Title 31, C.R.S., together with any other duties or authorities which may hereafter be conferred upon it by the laws of the State. The performance of such duties and the exercise of such authority shall be subject to the limitations expressed in said state statutes. 
(Prior code,  2.06.050; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-12-70. - Master Plan. 
    In the preparation of a Master Plan, the Planning Commission shall make careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of present conditions and future growth of the City, with due regard to its relation to neighboring territories. The Master Plan shall be made with the general purposes of guiding and accomplishing a coordinated, adjusted and harmonious development of the City and its environs, which will, in accordance with present and future needs, best promote health, safety, morals, order, convenience, prosperity and general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development, including, among other things, the following: adequate provision for traffic; the promotion of safety from fire and other dangers; adequate provision for light and air; the promotion of healthful and convenient distribution of population; the promotion of good civil design and arrangement; wise and efficient expenditures of public funds; and an adequate provision of public utilities and other public requirements. 
(Prior code,  2.06.050; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 13 - Swimming Pool Commission 

Sec. 2-13-10. - Purpose and intent. 
    The purpose and intent of this Article is to set up, establish and create the Rocky Ford Swimming Pool Commission, which will provide and encourage citizen participation in the development of swimming pool policies and swimming pool operations to the fullest extent possible under the laws of the State, provisions of City insurance carriers and this Code. 
(Ord. No. 872, 5-24-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-13-20. - Creation. 
    The City Council hereby sets up, establishes and creates the Swimming Pool Commission for the benefit of the inhabitants of the City and vicinity. 
(Ord. No. 872, 5-24-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-13-30. - Members. 
(a)  Appointment. The Swimming Pool Commission shall consist of not less than five and not more than eleven appointed members and two ex officio members. The appointed members shall include at least one City Council Member. The City Manager and/or the Superintendent of Public Works shall serve as ex officio members, to advise and support the Swimming Pool Commission, and shall have no vote. All appointed members shall have voting privileges. The City Council shall appoint all appointed members, including the City Council Member. Members need not be residents of the City. 
(b)  Terms. Each member shall be appointed for a term of three years. However, during the initial year, the terms for members on the Swimming Pool Commission shall be either for one year, two years or three years, as needed to establish and maintain, to the extent possible, staggered terms of office. All terms shall terminate at midnight on December 31 in the year the term concludes. 
(c)  Vacancies. Where an appointed member vacancy occurs, the City Council shall appoint a new member recommended by the Swimming Pool Commission, to fill the unexpired portion of the term. 
(d)  Removal of members. An appointed member may be removed by the City Council on recommendation of the Swimming Pool Commission, for unexcused absences at three or more consecutive meetings. 
(Ord. No. 872, 5-24-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-13-40. - Compensation. 
    Members shall not receive any wage, salary or compensation. 
(Ord. No. 872, 5-24-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-13-50. - Meetings and officers. 
    The Swimming Pool Commission shall meet as necessary and shall elect a Chairperson, Vice Chairperson, Secretary and Treasurer at its first meeting each calendar year. The Swimming Pool Commission may elect such other officers as deemed appropriate. Ex officio members shall not serve as officers. 
(Ord. No. 872, 5-24-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-13-60. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  Policies and operations. The Swimming Pool Commission shall advise the City Council regarding swimming pool policies and shall assist and advise the City Manager with the day-to-day operation of the municipal swimming pool to the extent allowable under state regulations and law, City insurance policies and requirements and this Code. 
(b)  Standards. The Swimming Pool Commission and the City administration shall follow the standards set forth below: 
(1)  The swimming pool shall remain in compliance with all applicable Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment regulations, state law, this Code, requirements of the City insurance carrier and all safety rules established by or required by the City Safety Officer. 
(2)  In a calendar year, swimming pool operational expenses shall not exceed swimming pool revenues from all sources. 
(3)  The City administration shall take steps to assure that the Swimming Pool Commission receives sufficient financial information in a timely enough fashion to make decisions to avoid a deficit. 
(4)  Swimming pool revenues shall be deposited with the City, which shall use said revenues for the sole purpose of operating the swimming pool. 
(5)  The City shall pay swimming pool operational costs from swimming pool revenues, except where the City Council explicitly authorizes by motion or resolution the use of other assets or the transfer of other revenues to offset operational costs. 
(Ord. No. 872, 5-24-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-13-70. - Employees. 
    All swimming pool employees shall be employees of the City, subject to the City personnel rules and regulations, and shall work under the direction and supervision of the Swimming Pool Manager, who shall report to the City Manager. The Swimming Pool Commission and Swimming Pool Manager shall interview and recommend to the City Manager individuals to be hired as lifeguards. The Swimming Pool Commission shall interview and recommend to the City Manager individuals to be hired as the Swimming Pool Manager. 
(Ord. No. 872, 5-24-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-13-80. - Contracts for purchase. 
    All contracts for goods or services shall be approved by the City Council pursuant to state law. 
(Ord. No. 872, 5-24-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-13-90. - Reports. 
(a)  Monthly reports. The Swimming Pool Commission shall submit a verbal report to the City Council monthly when the swimming pool is operational. 
(b)  Annual reports. In addition, the Swimming Pool Commission shall provide the City Council with an annual written report following the seasonal closing of the swimming pool, and no later than October 15. The report shall provide information on the activities of the Swimming Pool Commission, sums of money received and expended, number of community members served and all other matters deemed appropriate by the Swimming Pool Commission and City Council. 
(Ord. No. 872, 5-24-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-13-100. - Title to property. 
    The title to property given to or for the benefit of the Swimming Pool Commission or swimming pool shall be held in the name of the City of Rocky Ford. 
(Ord. No. 872, 5-24-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 14 - Tree Board 

Sec. 2-14-10. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created and established a Tree Board for the City, which shall consist of seven members. Each member shall be a resident of the City and shall be appointed by the Mayor with the approval of the City Council. 
(Prior code,  2.06.070; Ord. No. 839, 9-25-2007; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-14-20. - Terms and vacancies. 
    Each Tree Board member shall be appointed for a five-year term; provided, however, that the first appointments to the Tree Board shall be for terms of one, two, three, four and five years respectively. The sixth and seventh members shall be appointed for initial terms whose lengths are determined by the City Council, so that not more than two terms shall end in the same year. Tree Board vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired portion of the term following the same procedure used for the regular appointment of Tree Board members. 
(Prior code,  2.06.070; Ord. No. 839, 9-25-2007; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-14-30. - Compensation. 
    Tree Board members shall serve without compensation. 
(Prior code,  2.06.070; Ord. No. 839, 9-25-2007; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-14-40. - Duties and responsibilities. 
(a)  The Tree Board shall study, investigate, counsel, develop and update annually a written plan for the care, preservation, trimming, planting, replanting, removal and disposition of trees and shrubs in public ways, streets and alleys. The plan will be presented to the City Council annually and, upon acceptance and approval by the City Council, shall constitute the official comprehensive City Tree Plan for the City. 
(b)  The Tree Board shall consider, investigate, make findings and recommendations and report upon any special matter or question coming within the scope of its work when requested by the City Council or City Manager. 
(c)  The Tree Board may assist with planting, pruning, trimming and other care of trees and shrubs located on all City-owned or City-controlled land, including but not limited to street trees and park trees. 
(d)  The Tree Board shall serve as a community resource to assist private land owners within the City who have questions or desire information regarding trees or proposed trees located on private property by providing information directly or by referral to other government or private sources of information and assistance. 
(Prior code,  2.06.070; Ord. No. 839, 9-25-2007; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-14-50. - Operation. 
    The Tree Board shall choose its own officers and shall keep a journal of its proceedings. The Tree Board may adopt bylaws, rules and regulations concerning the discharge of the Tree Board's duties and responsibilities under the terms of this Article. A majority of the members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(Prior code,  2.06.070; Ord. No. 839, 9-25-2007; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 2-14-60. - Interference. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the Tree Board or any of its agents or any City employees while engaging in and about the planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying, removing or replanting of any street trees, park trees or trees on private grounds as authorized in this Article or by any other section of this Code. 
(Prior code,  2.06.070; Ord. No. 839, 9-25-2007; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
CHAPTER 4 - Revenue and Finance 
ARTICLE 1 - Fiscal Year 

Sec. 4-1-10. - Fiscal year established. 
    The fiscal year of the City shall commence on January 1 of each year and shall extend through December 31 of the same year. The financial business of the City shall be conducted and executed in accordance with the fiscal year. 
(Prior code,  2.12; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 2 - General and Special Funds 

Sec. 4-2-10. - Custody and management of funds. 
(a)  The following funds and associated activities within these funds are hereby declared and determined to be enterprises or excluded for purposes of the calculations required under Article 10, Section 20 of the Colorado Constitution, also known as the TABOR Amendment: 
(1)  Water Fund. 
(2)  Sewer Fund. 
(3)  Garbage Fund. 
(4)  Conservation Trust Fund. 
(b)  Moneys in the funds created in this Article shall be in the custody of and managed by the Finance Director. The Finance Director shall maintain accounting records and account for all of said moneys as provided by law. Moneys in the funds of the City shall be invested or deposited by the Finance Director in accordance with the provisions of law. All income from the assets of the General Fund or a special fund shall become a part of the fund from which derived and shall be used for the purpose for which such fund was created; provided that, except as otherwise provided in this Code or by other ordinances or laws, the Finance Director may transfer out of any fund, other than any enterprise funds, any amount at any time to be used for such purpose within the appropriated budget unless a supplemental budget is required, which must be approved by the City Council. 
(Prior code,  3.08; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-2-20. - General Fund created. 
    There is hereby created a fund, to be known as the General Fund, which shall consist of the following: 
(1)  All cash balances of the City not specifically belonging to any existing special fund of the City. 
(2)  All fixed assets of the City (to be separately designated in an account known as the General Fund Fixed Assets) not specifically belonging to any existing special fund of the City. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-2-30. - Capital Improvement Fund created. 
    There is hereby created a special fund, to be known as the Capital Improvement Fund, and the funds therein shall be used only for the purposes allowed by law. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-2-40. - Conservation Trust Fund created. 
    There is hereby created and established a separate fund of the City, to be known as the Conservation Trust Fund, which fund shall be held, maintained and expended only for the purposes allowed by law. 
(Prior code,  3.04.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-2-50. - Public Library Fund created. 
    There is hereby created a special fund, to be known as the Public Library Fund, and the funds therein shall be used only for the purposes allowed by law. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-2-60. - Utility accounts. 
    Accounts shall be kept for each public utility owned or operated by the City, distinct from other City accounts, and in such manner as to show the true and complete financial result of such City ownership and operation, including all assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses, and in accordance with the uniform classification of accounts as may be prescribed by the Public Utilities Commission of the State. 
(Ord. No. 773,  11, 12-11-2001; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 3 - Sales Tax 

Sec. 4-3-10. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this Article is to impose a sales tax upon the sale at retail of tangible personal property and the furnishing of certain services in the City pursuant to the authority granted to incorporated towns and cities of the State by Article 2 of Title 29, C.R.S. This Article shall be so construed and interpreted as to effectuate the general purpose of making it uniform with the sales tax of the State levied by Article 26 of Title 39, C.R.S. 
(Prior code,  3.14.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-3-20. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this Article, the definitions of words herein contained shall be as said words are defined in Section 39-26-102, C.R.S., except the definition of food in Section 39-26-102(4.5), C.R.S., and said definitions are incorporated herein by reference. 
(Prior code,  3.14.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-3-30. - Property and services taxed. 
(a)  There is hereby levied and there shall be collected and paid a sales tax on the sale of tangible personal property at retail or the furnishing of services, as provided in Section 4-3-50 below. 
(b)  For the purpose of this Article, all retail sales are consummated at the place of business of the retailer unless the tangible personal property sold is delivered by the retailer or his or her agent to a destination outside the limits of the City, or to a common carrier for delivery to a destination outside the limits of the City. The gross recipients from such sales and use tax shall include delivery charges when such charges are subject to the state sales and use tax imposed by Article 26 of Title 39, C.R.S., regardless of the place to which delivery is made. If a retailer has no permanent place of business in the City or has more than one place of business, the place at which the retail sales are consummated for the purpose of a sales tax imposed by this Article shall be determined by the provisions of Article 26 of Title 39, C.R.S., and by rules and regulations promulgated by the Colorado Department of Revenue. 
(c)  The amount subject to tax shall not include the amount of any sales or use tax imposed by Article 26 of Title 39, C.R.S. 
(Prior code,  3.14.030; Ord. No. 812, 3-8-2005; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-3-40. - Exemptions. 
(a)  The tangible personal property and services taxable pursuant to this Chapter shall be the same as the tangible personal property and services taxable pursuant to Section 39-26-104, C.R.S., except as otherwise provided in Subsection (b) below. 
(b)  The tangible personal property and services taxable pursuant to this Chapter are subject to the same sales tax exemptions as those specified in Part 7 of Article 26 of Title 39, C.R.S., including but not limited to the exemption for sales and purchases of farm equipment under lease or contract specified in Sections 39-26-716(2)(b) and 39-26-716(2)(c), C.R.S., except: 
(1)  The exemption allowed by Section 39-26-709(1), C.R.S., for purchases of machinery or machine tools; 
(2)  The exemption of sales and purchases of those items in Section 39-26-715(1)(a)(II), C.R.S.; 
(3)  The exemption for sales of food specified in Section 39-26-707(1)(e), C.R.S.; 
(4)  The exemption for vending machine sales of food set forth in Section 39-26-714(2), C.R.S.; 
(5)  The exemption for occasional sales by a charitable organization set forth in Section 39-26-718(1)(b), C.R.S.; and 
(6)  The exemption for sales of low-emitting motor vehicles, power sources or parts used for converting such power sources, as specified in Section 39-26-719(1), C.R.S. 
(c)  All sales of personal property on which a specific ownership tax has been paid or is payable shall be exempt from City sales tax when such sales meet both of the following conditions: 
(1)  The purchaser is a nonresident of or has his or her principal place of business outside of the City; and 
(2)  Such personal property is registered or required to be registered outside the limits of the City under the laws of the State. 
(d)  In the event the limitation provided in Section 29-2-108, C.R.S., is to be exceeded in the City by a proposed county sales or use tax, such limitation shall be exceeded by a stated one percent in the City. 
(e)  The sales tax imposed pursuant to Section 39-26-104(1)(c), C.R.S., on a mobile telecommunications service is imposed in accordance with the provisions of the Act; and, pursuant to Section 117(b) of the Act, mobile telecommunications service taxable by the City is subject to sales tax or other charge imposed by the City on the service only if the customer's place of primary use is within City limits. As used in this Subsection, unless the context otherwise requires: 
    Act means the federal "Mobile Telecommunications Sourcing Act," 4 U.S.C.,  116 to 126, as amended. 
    Customer means a customer as defined in Section 124(2) of the Act. 
    Mobile telecommunications service means mobile telecommunications service as defined in Section 124(7) of the Act. 
    Place of primary use means the place of primary use as defined in Section 124(8) of the Act. 
(f)  No sales tax shall apply to the sale of construction and building materials, as the term is used in Section 29-2-109 C.R.S., if such materials are picked up by the purchaser and if the purchaser of such materials presents to the retailer a building permit or other documentation acceptable to the City evidencing that a local use tax has been paid or is required to be paid. 
(g)  No sales tax shall apply to the sale of tangible personal property at retail or the furnishing of services if the transaction was previously subjected to a sales or use tax lawfully imposed on the purchaser or user by another statutory or home rule city, city or town equal to or in excess of that sought to be imposed subsequently by the City. A credit shall be granted against the sales tax imposed by the City subsequently with respect to such transaction equal in amount to the lawfully imposed local sales or use tax previously paid by the purchaser or user to the previous statutory or home rule city, city or town. The amount of the credit shall not exceed the sales tax imposed by the City. 
(h)  No sales or use tax shall apply to the sale of food purchased with food stamps. For the purposes of this Subsection, food shall have the same meaning as provided in 7 U.S.C.,  2012(g). 
(i)  No sales or use tax shall apply to the sale of food purchased with funds provided by the special supplemental food program for women, infants and children, 42 U.S.C.,  1786. For the purposes of this Subsection, food shall have the same meaning as provided in 42 U.S.C.  1786. 
(j)  This Section shall not be interpreted as adopting any new tax or increasing any existing tax. 
(Prior code,  3.14.040; Ord. No. 812, 3-8-2005; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-3-50. - Amount and schedule of sales tax. 
(a)  There is hereby imposed upon all sales of tangible personal property and the furnishing of certain services, as specified in Section 4-3-30 above, a sales tax of three percent upon the sale at retail of tangible personal property and the furnishing of certain services as provided herein. 
(b)  Effective January 1, 2018, there is hereby imposed upon all sales of tangible property and the furnishing of certain services, as specified in Section 4-3-30 above, a sales tax of one percent upon the sale at retail of tangible personal property and the furnishing of certain services as provided herein. The use of revenues from the sales tax shall be utilized for the repair of streets, sidewalks and other physical improvements in the City according to a Council-approved repair schedule. Said sales tax of one percent shall expire on December 31, 2020. 
(c)  Reserved. 
(d)  The imposition of the tax on the sale at retail of tangible personal property and the furnishing of certain services subject to this tax shall be in accordance with schedules set forth in the Rules and Regulations of the Colorado Department of Revenue. 
(Prior code,  3.14.050-3.14.090; Ord. No. 896, 7-23-2013; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016; Ord. No. 928,  1, 2, 3-13-2018 ) 
Sec. 4-3-60. - Collection, administration and enforcement. 
    The collection, administration and enforcement of the sales tax imposed by this Article shall be performed by the Executive Director of the Department of Revenue in the same manner as the collection, administration and enforcement of the state sales tax. Accordingly, the provisions of Articles 26 and 21 of Title 39 and Article 2 of Title 29, C.R.S., and all rules and regulations promulgated by the Executive Director of the Department of Revenue pertaining to such collection, administration and enforcement are incorporated herein by reference. 
(Prior code,  3.14.100; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-3-70. - Vendor's fee. 
(a)  At any time of making his or her return of the tax as required by this Article, every retailer shall be entitled to subtract from the tax as remitted a State-approved percentage of said tax as his or her fee, said fee to be known as the "vendor's fee." 
(b)  If the retailer is delinquent in remitting said tax, he or she shall forfeit the vendor's fee unless good cause can be shown to the State for such delinquent remittance. 
(Prior code,  3.14.100; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 4 - Use Tax 

Sec. 4-4-10. - Use tax imposed. 
    There is hereby imposed a use tax of three percent for the privilege of storing, using or consuming in the City any construction and building materials, and motor and other vehicles on which registration is required, purchased at retail. 
(Prior code,  3.14.120; Ord. No. 716,  1, 6-24-1996; Ord. No. 891,  1, 3-26-2013; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-4-20. - Purpose; applicability.
