    The purpose of this Article is to raise revenues and provide a companion tax to the sales tax. The tax imposed herein of three percent is a use tax on the use, storage or consumption within the City of construction and building materials purchased at retail outside the City for use, storage or consumption within the City. The legal authority for this Article is contained in state statutes. 
(Ord. No. 891,  1, 3-26-2013; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-4-30. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this Article, the definitions of words herein contained are as defined in state statutes. 
(Ord. No. 891,  1, 3-26-2013; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-4-40. - Exemptions. 
    Pursuant to state statutes, this tax, known as a use tax, shall not apply to: 
(1)  The storage, use or consumption of any tangible personal property, the sale of which is subject to a retail sales tax collected for the City. 
(2)  The storage, use or consumption of any tangible personal property purchased for resale in the City, either in its original form or as an ingredient of a manufactured or compounded product, in the regular course of business. 
(3)  The storage, use or consumption of tangible personal property brought into the City by a nonresident thereof for his or her own storage, use or consumption while temporarily within the City; however, this exemption does not apply to the storage, use or consumption of tangible personal property brought into the State by a nonresident to be used in the conduct of a business within the State. 
(4)  The storage, use or consumption of tangible personal property by the U.S. government, the State or its institutions or political subdivisions, or the City in its governmental capacities only, or by religious or charitable corporations in the conduct of their regular religious or charitable functions. 
(5)  The storage, use or consumption of tangible personal property by a person engaged in the business of manufacturing or compounding for sale, profit or use any article, substance or commodity, which tangible personal property enters into the processing of or becomes an ingredient or component part of the product or service which is manufactured, compounded or furnished and the container, label or furnished shipping case thereof. 
(6)  The storage, use or consumption of any article of tangible personal property, the sale or use of which has already been subjected to a legally imposed sales tax of another statutory or home rule city, town or city or county equal to or in excess of that imposed by this Article. A credit shall be granted against the use tax imposed by this Article with respect to a person's storage, use or consumption in the City of tangible person property purchased by him or her elsewhere. The amount of the credit shall be equal to the tax paid by him or her by reason of the imposition of a sales or use tax of another city, town, city or county on his or her purchase or use of the property. The amount of the credit shall not exceed the tax imposed by this Article. 
(7)  The storage, use or consumption of tangible personal property and household effects acquired outside of the City and brought into the City by a nonresident acquiring residency. 
(8)  The storage, use or consumption of any construction and building materials required or made necessary in the performance of any construction contract that was bid, let or entered into at any time prior to the effective date of the use tax ordinances imposing use tax. 
(9)  Any sales which the City is prohibited from taxing under the Constitution or laws of the U.S. or the Constitution of the State. 
(Ord. No. 891,  1, 3-26-2013; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-4-50. - Motor and other vehicle use tax collection. 
(a)  The use tax of three percent provided for herein shall be applicable to every motor vehicle for which registration is required by the laws of the State. No registration shall be made of any motor vehicle or other vehicle for which registration is required, and no certificate of title shall be issued for such vehicle by the Colorado Department of Revenue or its authorized agents, until any tax due upon the use, storage or consumption thereof pursuant to this Article has been paid. 
(b)  The use tax imposed by this Article shall be collected by the authorized agent of the Colorado Department of Revenue in the County. 
(c)  The proceeds of such tax shall be paid to the City periodically in accordance with an agreement entered into by and between the City and the Colorado Department of Revenue. 
(Prior code,  3.14.130; Ord. No. 716,  2, 6-24-1996; Ord. No. 891,  1, 3-26-2013; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-4-60. - Construction and building materials use tax collection. 
(a)  For construction and building materials, the use tax imposed by this Article shall be collected in full prior to issuance of a building permit or zoning compliance permit. The use tax shall be collected by the Building Department and/or the City Clerk. The City Clerk is hereby authorized to adopt all rules and regulations that may be necessary or appropriate for the collection, administration and enforcement of the use tax on construction and building materials. 
(b)  For purposes of determining the use tax for construction and building materials, the total valuation, including general contract costs and mechanical, electric and plumbing contract costs and delivery fees, shall be deemed to be the purchase price of such construction and building materials. 
(c)  If sales tax paid on construction and building materials to be used has been demonstrated as paid prior to commencing construction, and has been shown as acceptable proof to the City, no use tax shall be due at the time of permitting. 
(d)  For activities specifically requiring a building permit, a zoning compliance permit shall be pulled prior to the commencement of any activity. No final inspection on any permitted activity shall be given unless all use tax has been collected. 
(e)  For activities where no building permit is pulled or necessary as required by the current building code adopted by the City, i.e., re-roofing, remodeling, etc., a separate no-fee/no-permit zoning application shall be used to calculate applicable use tax at no cost to the applicant. 
(Prior code,  3.14.140; Ord. No. 716,  3, 6-24-1996; Ord. No. 891,  1, 3-26-2013; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-4-70. - Credit for use taxes previously paid to another municipality. 
    The City's use tax shall not apply to the storage, use or consumption of any article of tangible personal property the sale or use of which has already been subjected to a legally imposed sales or use tax of another statutory or home rule municipality equal to or in excess of three percent. A credit shall be granted against the City's use tax with respect to a person's storage, use or consumption in the City of tangible personal property purchased by him or her in another statutory or home rule municipality. The amount of the credit shall not exceed three percent. 
(Prior code,  3.14.200; Ord. No. 891,  1, 3-26-2013; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-4-80. - Refunds for overpayment. 
    Upon completion of the construction or building project, the taxpayer may apply to the Finance Director for a refund for any overpayment of the use tax for construction and building materials, the tax having been computed upon an estimation of value, such application to be supported by a documented itemization of the actual purchases made for construction and building materials actually used or consumed in the project for which the building permit was issued and upon which the tax was paid. 
(Ord. No. 891,  1, 3-26-2013; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-4-90. - Appeal. 
    After exhausting all local remedies, a taxpayer may elect to appeal a use tax assessment or claim for a refund to the Colorado Department of Revenue pursuant to Section 29-2-106.1(3), C.R.S. A notice of this right shall be included in any notice of assessment or denial of refund in clear and conspicuous type. 
(Ord. No. 891,  1, 3-26-2013; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-4-100. - Lien on property. 
    If any person fails to pay the use tax within 30 days after it is due, the City Clerk shall issue a notice setting forth the name of the taxpayer, the amount of the use tax owed and the date of the accrual thereof, and that the City claims a first and prior lien therefor on the real and personal property of the taxpayer, except as to preexisting liens of a bona fide mortgagee, pledgee, judgment creditor or purchaser, which right has attached prior to the filing of the notice as hereinafter provided. The notice shall be on forms prepared by the Finance Director, and, when filed in the office of the clerk and recorder of any county in the State in which the taxpayer owns real or personal property, such notice shall create a lien as aforesaid on such property in that county and constitute a notice thereof. 
(Ord. No. 891,  1, 3-26-2013; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-4-110. - Funds deposited. 
    All funds received pursuant to this Article shall be deposited in the City's General Fund. 
(Ord. No. 891,  1, 3-26-2013; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-4-120. - Amendments. 
    Except as to the use tax rate provided for in this Article and the items taxed and exempted from the use tax hereunder, the City Council may amend, alter, delete or change the provisions of its use tax regulations by the adoption of an amending ordinance in accordance with law. Such amendment, alteration, deletion or change need not be submitted to the electors of the City for their approval. 
(Ord. No. 891,  1, 3-26-2013; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-4-130. - Violation; penalty. 
    It is a violation of this Article for any person who, by this Article, is required to make any return or pay any tax to fail or refuse to make any return or pay any tax required to be made or paid by this Article; to make any false or fraudulent return or any false statements in any return; to fail or refuse to make payment to the Finance Director, City Clerk or County Clerk of any taxes collected or due the City; or in any manner to evade the collection of any payment of the tax, or any part thereof, imposed by this Article; or for any person or purchaser to fail or refuse to pay such tax or evade the payment thereof or to aid or abet another in any attempt to evade the payment of the tax imposed by this Article. Any corporation or officer thereof making a false return or a return containing a false statement shall be guilty of a violation of this Article and shall be punished as set forth in Section 1-4-20 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 891,  1, 3-26-2013; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 5 - Occupational Tax 

Sec. 4-5-10. - Declaration of policy and purpose. 
    Considering the nature of the business of selling products, commodities or services, the sale of which is regulated by the Public Utilities Commission of the State, and the relation of such business to the municipal welfare, as well as the relation thereof to the expenditures required of the City and a proper, just and equitable distribution of the tax burdens within the City, and all other matters proper to be considered thereto, the City Council finds that the classification of the business as separate occupations is reasonable, proper, uniform and nondiscriminatory and necessary for a just and proper distribution of tax burdens within the City. 
(Prior code,  3.10.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-5-20. - Levy and schedule. 
    There is hereby levied on and against any and all businesses selling products, commodities or services, the sale of which is regulated by the Public Utilities Commission, operating in the City without a franchise an occupation tax equal to three percent of the gross revenue arising from the sale of which is regulated by the Public Utilities Commission within the corporate limits of the City as now or hereafter fixed. 
(Prior code,  3.10.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-5-30. - Filing statement and payment of tax. 
    Within 45 days after the end of each calendar quarter, there shall be filed with the City Clerk a statement showing the total gross revenue as prescribed in Section 4-5-20 above during the preceding calendar quarter. Such statement shall be accompanied by payment to the City of the tax due for the period covered by the statement. 
(Prior code,  3.10.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-5-40. - Failure to pay. 
    If any of said businesses fails to pay the taxes as herein provided, the full amount thereof, with an addition of ten percent, shall be due and collected from such business, and the same shall be, and hereby is declared to be, a debt due and owing from such businesses to the City. The City Attorney shall commence to prosecute to final judgment and determination in any court of competent jurisdiction an action at law to collect said debt in the name of the City. 
(Prior code,  3.10.040; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-5-50. - Penalty clause. 
    If any officer, agent or manager of a telephone utility company which is subject to the provisions of this Article fails, neglects or refuses to make or file the annual statement of accounts provided in Section 4-5-30 above, said officer, agent, manager or person shall, on conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not less than $25.00 nor more than $300.00; provided that each day after said statement becomes delinquent, during which said officer, agent, manager or person fails, neglects or refuses to make and file such statement, shall be considered a separate and distinct offense. 
(Prior code,  3.10.050; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-5-60. - Inspection of records. 
    The City and its officers, agents or representatives shall have the right, after notice, at all reasonable hours and times to examine the books and records of such businesses and to make copies of the entries or contents thereof. Said books and records shall be made available in the City. The notice required by this Section shall be in writing, directed to the owners, officers, managers or agents of the business having general control, management or supervision of the business within the State or the City, and shall be mailed by certified mail, return receipt requested, which receipt shall be conclusive evidence of the receipt of said notice by the addressee. 
(Prior code,  3.10.060; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-5-70. - Franchised businesses not liable. 
    The provisions of this Article shall not apply to any business selling products or commodities, the sale of which is regulated by the Public Utilities Commission, with a franchise granted by the City, requiring the payment of a franchise tax in the City. The liability of any business selling products or commodities, the sale of which is regulated by the Public Utilities Commission within the City, to pay the tax hereby levied shall cease during the effective period of any franchise granted by the City to such business which requires the payment of a franchise tax. 
(Prior code,  3.10.070; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-5-80. - Successors. 
    The provision of this Article shall apply to the successors and assigns of any and all businesses as set out in Section 4-5-20 of this Article and to any and all corporations, partnerships, persons or others furnishing and supplying, operating, engaging in or carrying on any business of the same nature as set out in Section 4-5-20. 
(Prior code,  3.10.080; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-5-90. - Single purpose not diverted. 
    The purpose of this Section being to raise revenue for the City and to secure a proper distribution of the moneys to be raised under this Article, this Article shall be void in case the Supreme Court of the State shall hold that any part of the moneys to be raised under this Article must be used for any other purpose. 
(Prior code,  3.10.090; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-5-100. - Local purpose. 
    The tax herein provided is upon occupations and businesses in their performance of local functions and is not a tax upon those functions relating to interstate commerce. 
(Prior code,  3.10.100; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 6 - Telephone Utility Occupation Tax 

Sec. 4-6-10. - Levy of tax. 
    There is hereby levied on and against each telephone utility company operating within the City a tax on the occupation and business of maintaining a telephone exchange and lines connected therewith in the City, and of supplying local exchange telephone service to the inhabitants of the City. The annual amount of tax levied shall be equal to $5.50 per telephone account for which local exchange service is provided within the corporate limits of the City. 
(Prior code,  3.12.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-6-20. - Payment schedule. 
    The tax levied by this Article shall be due and payable quarterly in four equal installments, which shall be paid 30 days after the due date. 
(Prior code,  3.12.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-6-30. - Filing statement. 
    Each telephone utility company subject to this Article shall file with the City Clerk, in such form as the City Clerk may require, a statement showing the total telephone accounts for which local exchange telephone service was provided within the corporate limits of the City. Such statement shall be filed within 30 days after June 15 of each year, showing such accounts existing on June 15. 
(Prior code,  3.12.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-6-40. - Failure to pay. 
    If any telephone utility company subject to the provisions of this Article fails to pay the taxes as herein provided, the full amount thereof shall be due and collected from such company, and the same, together with an addition of ten percent of the amount of taxes due, shall be and hereby is declared to be a debt due and owing from such company to the City. The City Attorney, upon direction of the City Council, shall commence and prosecute to final judgment and determination in any court of competent jurisdiction an action at law to collect the debt in the name of the People of the City. 
(Prior code,  3.12.040; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-6-50. - Penalty clause. 
    If any officer, agent or manager of a telephone utility company which is subject to the provisions of this Article fails, neglects or refuses to make or file the annual statement of accounts provided in Section 4-6-30 above, said officer, agent, manager or person shall, on conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not less than $25.00 nor more than $300.00; provided that each time the officer, agent, manager or person fails, neglects or refuses to make and file such statement shall be considered a separate and distinct offense. 
(Prior code,  3.12.050; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-6-60. - Inspection of records. 
    The City and its officers, agents or representatives shall have the right at all reasonable hours and times to examine the books and records of the telephone utility company which are subject to the provisions of this Article and to make copies of the entries or contents thereof. 
(Prior code,  3.12.060; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-6-70. - Local purpose. 
    The tax herein provided is upon occupations and businesses in the performance of local functions and is not a tax upon those functions relating to interstate commerce. It is expressly understood that none of the terms of this Article shall be construed to mean that any telephone utility company is issued a franchise by the City. 
(Prior code,  3.12.070; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-6-80. - Tax in lieu of other taxes. 
    The tax herein provided shall be in lieu of all other payments by or fees and taxes on any telephone utility company subject to the provisions of this Article, other than ad valorem taxes, and in addition shall be in lieu of any free service furnished to the City by said telephone utility. 
(Prior code,  3.12.080; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 7 - Liquor Regulation and Occupational Tax 

Sec. 4-7-10. - Definitions. 
    As used in this Article, the following words or phrases shall have the following meanings: 
    3.2 beer means malt liquor as herein defined containing not more than 3.2% of alcohol by weight. 
    Malt liquor shall include beer and shall be construed to mean any beverage obtained by the alcoholic fermentation of any fusion or decoction of barley, malt, hops or any other similar products, or any combination thereof, in water, containing more than 3.2% of alcohol by weight. 
    Medicinal liquors means any liquor sold by a duly licensed pharmacist or drug store solely on a doctor's bona fide prescription. 
    Operator means a person licensed by law to sell malt, vinous and spirituous liquors, other than medicinal liquors, for beverage purposes at retail and who is engaged at any time during the calendar year in such operation within the City. 
    Person shall include persons, partnerships, associations, organizations or corporations. 
    Spirituous liquors shall be construed to mean any alcohol beverage obtained by distillation, mixed with water and other substances in solution, and includes among other things brandy, rum, whiskey, gin and every liquor or solid, patented or not, containing alcohol and which is fit for use for beverage purposes. Any liquid or solid containing beer or wine in combination with other liquor, except as above provided, shall not be construed to be malt or vinous liquors, but shall be construed to be spirituous liquor. 
    Vinous liquors shall include wine and fortified wines not exceeding 21 percent of alcohol by volume and shall be construed to mean alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of the natural sugar contents of fruits or other agricultural produce containing sugar. 
(Prior code,  3.13.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-7-20. - Classification of businesses. 
    The business of selling at retail any malt, vinous or spirituous liquor, other than medicinal liquors, for beverage purposes is hereby defined and separately classified as such occupation for the purpose of this Article, as follows: 
(1)  Class "A" operators are all operators who are licensed to sell beer, wine and spirituous liquors for consumption on the premises, either as hotel or restaurants. 
(2)  Class "B" operators are all operators licensed to sell malt or vinous liquors only by the drink for consumption on the premises. 
(3)  Class "C" operators are all operators licensed as retail liquor stores to sell malt, vinous or spirituous liquors in original containers for consumption off the premises. 
(4)  Class "D" operators are all operators licensed as drug stores to sell malt, vinous or spirituous liquors in original containers for consumption off the premises. 
(5)  Class "E" operators are all operators licensed to sell only 3.2% beer and who sell the same for consumption on the premises. 
(6)  Class "F" operators are all operators licensed to sell only 3.2% beer and who sell the same solely in the original package or container for consumption off the premises. 
(7)  Class "G" operators are all operators licensed to sell malt, vinous or spirituous liquors as clubs. This Class shall not include clubs which are classified and identified as fraternal clubs and benevolent organizations which operate the same as a wholly nonprofit organization. 
(8)  Class "H" operators are all operators licensed to sell malt, vinous or spirituous liquors as fraternal and benevolent organizations on a nonprofit basis. 
(Prior code,  3.13.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-7-30. - Declaration of policy and purpose. 
    Considering the nature of the business of selling at retail 3.2% beer, malt, vinous and spirituous liquors for beverage purposes, and the relation of such business to the municipal welfare, as well as the relation thereof to the expenditures required of the City and a proper, just and equitable distribution of tax burdens within the City, and all other matters proper to be considered in relation thereto, the City Council finds, determines and declares that the classification of said business as a separate occupation is reasonable, proper, uniform and nondiscriminatory and necessary for a just and proper distribution of tax burdens within the City. 
(Prior code,  3.13.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-7-40. - Amount of tax assessed. 
    There is hereby levied and assessed for the calendar year an annual occupational tax upon the business of selling 3.2% beer, malt, vinous or spirituous liquors, except medicinal liquors, in the City, as said occupation has been herein classified as follows: 
Operator Tax Class "A" $200.00 Class "B" 200.00 Class "C" 200.00 Class "D" 200.00 Class "E" 200.00 Class "F" 200.00 Class "G" 200.00 Class "H" 200.00  
(Prior code,  3.13.040; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-7-50. - Due date of taxes. 
(a)  The occupational tax shall be due and payable to the City Clerk on January 1 of each year and shall be delinquent on February 1 of the same year. Prepayment of said tax may be made in the month of December preceding the due date. 
(b)  Upon receipt of such tax, it shall be the duty of the City Clerk to execute and deliver to the operator paying the tax a receipt showing the name of the operator paying the tax, the date of payment, the annual period for which said tax is paid and the place at which the operator conducts business. 
(c)  The operator shall, at all times, keep the receipt posted in a conspicuous place in his or her place of business. 
(Prior code,  3.13.050; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-7-60. - Proration for new businesses. 
    If any operator begins business subsequent to January 1 of any year, the tax required shall be prorated on a monthly basis for the remaining portion of the year, but no refund shall be made to any person who discontinues said business during the year. All prorated taxes provided for in this Section shall be due and payable upon the beginning of business and shall be delinquent ten days thereafter. 
(Prior code,  3.13.050; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-7-70. - Delinquent taxes; interest due. 
    Interest shall accrue on all delinquent taxes from the date of delinquency until paid or collected, at the rate of one and one-half percent per month. 
(Prior code,  3.13.050; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-7-80. - Delinquency not grounds for license suspension. 
    No delinquency in payment of the tax herein provided for shall be grounds for suspension or revocation of any license granted to an operator by any licensing authority pursuant to state statutes. In the performance of any duties imposed upon the City Council as a licensing authority by state statutes, the City Council shall exclude from consideration any delinquency in payment of the tax herein provided for. 
(Prior code,  3.13.060; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-7-90. - City may sue for sums due. 
    The City shall have the right to recover all sums due under the terms of this Article by judgment and execution thereon in a civil action in any court of competent jurisdiction. Such remedy shall be cumulative with all other remedies provided herein for the enforcement of this Article. 
(Prior code,  3.13.070; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 8 - Disposition of Unclaimed Property 

Sec. 4-8-10. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this Article is to provide for the administration and disposition of unclaimed property which is in the possession of or under the control of the City. 
(Prior code,  2.08.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-8-20. - Definitions. 
    Unless otherwise required by context or use, words and terms shall be defined as follows: 
    City Manager means the City Manager of the City or any designee. 
    Owner means a person or entity, including a corporation, partnership, association or governmental entity other than the City, or a duly authorized legal representative or successor in interest of the same, which owns unclaimed property held by the City. 
    Unclaimed property means, except as provided by any other provision of this Code or ordinance of the City, any tangible or intangible property, including any income or increment derived therefrom, less any lawful charges, that is held by or under the control of the City and which has not been claimed by its owner for a period of more than one year after it became payable or distributable. 
(Prior code,  2.08.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 4-8-30. - Procedure for disposition of property. 
(a)  Prior to disposition of any unclaimed property having an estimated value of $50.00 or more, the City Manager shall send a written notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last known address, if any, of any owner of unclaimed property. The last known address of the owner shall be the last address of the owner as shown by the records of the City department or agency holding the property. The notice shall include a description of the property, the amount of estimated value of the property and, when available, the purpose for which the property was deposited or otherwise held. The notice shall state where the owner may make inquiry of or claim the property. The notice shall also state that, if the owner fails provide the City Manager with a written claim for the return of the property within 60 days of the date of the notice, the property shall become the sole property of the City and any claim of the owner to such property shall be deemed forfeited. 
(b)  Prior to the disposition of any unclaimed property having an estimated value of less than $50.00 or having no last known address of the owner, the City Manager shall cause a notice to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the City. The notice shall include a description of the property, the owner of the property, the amount of estimated value of the property and, when available, the purpose for which the property was deposited or otherwise held. The notice shall also state that, if the owner fails to provide the City Manager with a written claim for the return of the property within 60 days of the date of the publication of the notice, the property shall become the sole property of the City and any claim of the owner to such property shall be deemed forfeited. 
(c)  If the City Manager receives no written claim within the above 60-day claim period, the property shall become the sole property of the City and any claim of the owner to such property shall be deemed forfeited. 
(d)  If the City Manager receives a written claim within the 60-day claim period, the City Manager shall evaluate the claim and give written notice to the claimant within 90 days thereof that the claim has been accepted or denied in whole or in part. The City Manager may investigate the validity of a claim and may request further supporting documentation from the claimant prior to disbursing or refusing to disburse the property. 
(e)  In the event that there is more than one claimant for the same property, the City Manager, in the City Manager's sole discretion, may resolve said claims or may resolve such claims by depositing the disputed property with the registry of the District Court in an interpleader action. 
(f)  In the event that all claims filed are denied, the property shall become the sole property of the City and any claim of the owner of such property shall be deemed forfeited. 
(g)  Any legal action filed challenging a decision of the City Manager shall be filed pursuant to Rule 106 of the Colorado Rules of Civil Procedure within 30 days of such decision, or shall be forever barred. If any legal action is timely filed, the property shall be disbursed by the City Manager pursuant to the order of the court having jurisdiction over such claim. 
(h)  The City Manager is authorized to establish and administer procedures for the administration and disposition of unclaimed property consistent with this Article, including compliance requirements for other municipal officers and employees in the identification and disposition of such property. 
(Prior code,  2.08.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 9. - Retail Marijuana and Marijuana Products Tax 

Sec. 4-9-10. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this Article is to impose a separate and additional sales tax on the lawful sale of marijuana and marijuana products within the City. 
( Ord. No. 931,  1, 3-13-2018 ) 
Sec. 4-9-20. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this Article, the following words shall have the following meanings: 
    Consumer shall have the meaning attributed to it in section (2)(b) of Section 16 of Article XVIII of the Colorado Constitution; 
    Lawful retail sale of marijuana and marijuana products shall mean the sale of marijuana and marijuana products by a licensed retail marijuana store to a consumer in compliance with Section 16 of Article XVIII of the Colorado Constitution and Section 12-43.4-101, et seq., C.R.S.; 
    Marijuana shall have the meaning attributed to it in section (2)(f) of Section 16 of Article XVIII of the Colorado Constitution; 
    Marijuana establishment shall have the meaning attributed to it in section (2)(k) of Section 16 of Article XVIII of the Colorado Constitution; 
    Marijuana products shall have the meaning attributed to it in section (2)(k) of Section 16 of Article XVIII of the Colorado Constitution; and 
    Retail marijuana store shall have the meaning attributed to it in section (2)(n) of Section 16 of Article XVIII of the Colorado Constitution 
( Ord. No. 931,  2, 3-13-2018 ) 
Sec. 4-9-30. - Tax imposed. 
(a)  Effective April 1, 2018, there is hereby levied and shall be collected upon the lawful retail sale of marijuana and marijuana products within the City at a rate of six percent of the price paid by the consumer thereof rounded off to the nearest penny. 
(b)  The sales tax imposed by this section shall be in addition to and not in lieu of the sales tax imposed on the retail sale of tangible personal property pursuant to Article 3 of this Chapter. 
( Ord. No. 931,  3, 3-13-2018 ) 
Sec. 4-9-40. - Collections, administration and enforcement. 
    The collection, administration and enforcement of the sales tax imposed by this Article shall be performed by the City of Rocky Ford. 
( Ord. No. 931,  4, 3-13-2018 ) 
CHAPTER 5 - Franchises and Communication Systems 
ARTICLE 1 - Emergency Telephone Service 

Sec. 5-1-10. - Intent and applicability. 
    The City Council finds, determines and declares that it is necessary to protect and preserve the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the City, and that a continuous and adequate emergency telephone service be made available to the citizens of the City through the construction, installation and use of a 911-enhanced emergency telephone service. 
(Prior code,  2.22.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-1-20. - Assessments. 
    The City Council is hereby authorized to impose a charge as set forth and designated in Section 29-11-102, C.R.S., and the proceeds of said charge shall be utilized to pay for emergency telephone service at set forth in Section 29-11-104(2), C.R.S. Said charge shall be imposed on each telephone user within the corporate limits of the City; however, said charge shall not be imposed upon any state or local government entity. 
(Prior code,  2.22.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-1-30. - Imposition of charge. 
    The City Council is hereby authorized to impose said charge by resolution, as amended from time to time; however, said charge shall not exceed the limits imposed by statutes or laws of the State. 
(Prior code,  2.22.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-1-40. - Representative to authority board. 
    The City Council is hereby authorized to appoint by resolution, from time to time as necessary, two representatives to sit on the authority board, said appointments to be made at least annually. 
(Prior code,  2.22.040; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-1-50. - Severability. 
    If any of the various provisions of this Article are determined by a court of law to be invalid, such determination shall not affect the remaining provisions of this Article. 
(Prior code,  2.22.050; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 2 - Railroads 

Sec. 5-2-10. - Rights granted to BNSF Railway Company. 
    There is hereby granted to the BNSF Railway Company, and its successors and assigns, the right, privilege and license to locate, construct and operate, by steam or other motive power, and to maintain a single or double track railway with the necessary switches in the City, over and across that portion of Fourth Street lying between the North line of the right-of-way of the BNSF Railway and the North line of Lot 8 in Block 15A in the second filing of the City, if the said North line of Lot 8 were extended across Fourth Street; and likewise crossing Elm Avenue between Fourth Street and the alley extending North and South through Blocks 15 and 15A and likewise crossing Swink Avenue between Fourth Street and the alley extending North and South through Blocks 15 and 75 and likewise crossing Chestnut Avenue between Fourth Street and the alley extending North and South in Block 75. 
(Prior code,  10.18.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-2-20. - Rights subject to conditions. 
    The rights and privileges hereby granted shall be subject to all reasonable ordinances and police regulations of the City now in force or that may hereafter be adopted, and the Railway Company shall keep the crossing at Fourth Street planked and in condition for travel, to a width of 16 feet in the center of the street, shall keep the crossing over Elm Avenue, Swink Avenue and Chestnut Avenue planked in a similar way to a width of 32 feet, and shall likewise maintain such drains or ditches as may be necessary at said crossings and maintain such culverts or other waterways as may be necessary for the City irrigation ditches, including a syphon under the tracks where they may intersect or cross Fourth Street. 
(Prior code,  10.18.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 3 - Gas Franchise 

Sec. 5-3-10. - Franchise granted. 
(a)  There be and hereby is granted to SourceGas Distribution LLC, its successors and assigns, hereinafter collectively referred to as "Grantee," the sole and exclusive right, authority, privilege and franchise to construct, erect, build, operate and maintain within the City of Rocky Ford, as the same now exists or may hereafter be extended, hereinafter referred to as "Municipality," such mechanical or other appliances and equipment as may be necessary for the manufacture and distribution of manufactured, mixed-manufactured or natural gas, or for the distribution of natural gas, for lighting, power, heating, industrial or other purposes to which gas may be applied, whether manufactured, mixed-manufactured or natural, with the sole and exclusive right and privilege for the period and upon the terms and conditions hereinafter specified, to construct, maintain and operate a transmission line or lines for the purpose of conducting into, from or to the Municipality gas generated there or elsewhere, and to sell or furnish natural or manufactured or mixed gas to the Municipality and the inhabitants thereof, and to distribute the same by means of mains, conduits or pipes laid over, upon, along, under and/or across the streets, alleys, bridges, public ways and public places within the present and future boundaries of the Municipality and upon the extension or continuation of any such streets, alleys, bridges and public ways and places or upon any new streets, alleys, bridges and public ways and places that may hereafter be laid out, opened or constructed. 
(b)  For the purposes aforesaid, the Grantee may enter upon, through or under any street, avenue, alley, viaduct, subway or public place or grounds and take up any pavement or sidewalk then existing therein or thereon and make excavations necessary for the laying of such conduits, mains, pipes and appurtenances, provided that any such use of said streets, avenues, alleys, viaducts, subways and public grounds shall be conducted in accordance with all excavation permit requirements or other regulations of the Municipality and shall be made with the least possible inconvenience to the inhabitants of the Municipality. Such excavations shall be barricaded when necessary and lighted at night, and such sidewalks, pavements or excavations shall be refilled and replaced without unnecessary delay, by and at the expense of the Grantee, in as good condition as they were before said work was commenced. 
(c)  The Grantee shall not have the absolute right to cut into or remove any permanent sidewalks, but shall be required, wherever practicable in laying mains, conduits or pipes, to tunnel under said sidewalks. 
(d)  The Grantee shall not have the right to enter into any public property other than streets, alleys and designated utility rights-of-way in the Municipality for the purpose of laying conduits, pipes or mains until it has first obtained the consent of the Municipality so to do. 
(Ord. No. 880,  1, 2-14-2012; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-3-20. - Location and relocation of facilities. 
(a)  All conduits, pipes and mains shall be placed in alleys wherever practicable, and in any event in such manner as will not unnecessarily interfere with the use of said streets and alleys, and public highways, places and grounds nor with the established grade of streets or gutters, nor with water pipes or sewers or any character of drain pipes which are now installed in said streets or alleys by the Municipality. 
(b)  If at any time it becomes necessary to change the position of any gas main or service connection of the Grantee to permit the Municipality to lay, make or change the grade of a street, alley or public grade, sanitary or storm sewers, water mains or other municipal works, such changes shall be made by the Grantee at its own expense; provided, however, that the Municipality shall provide the Grantee with a notice of any proposed development and seek the Grantee's input during the initial phase of planning and engineering of any municipal project which may require the Grantee to relocate its facilities, in order to explore means of reducing the costs to the Grantee. The Municipality shall make reasonable efforts to mitigate the financial impact of any such project on the Grantee. If the Municipality does not provide said notice to the Grantee during the initial phase of planning and engineering of any municipal project which may require the Grantee to relocate its facilities, the Grantee's relocation expenses shall be paid by the Municipality. 
(c)  If the Municipality and Grantee confer and do not agree on a facilities relocation plan, the Grantee may request and the Municipality's representatives shall participate in good faith mediation before a mutually agreeable third party in an effort to resolve their differences. 
(d)  The Municipality will not oppose in proceedings before the Colorado Public Utilities Commission just and reasonable recovery of costs which the Grantee incurs in complying herewith. 
(Ord. No. 880,  2, 2-14-2012; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-3-30. - Grantee responsibilities. 
    The Grantee shall be and remain solely and exclusively responsible for all damage to persons or property that may arise by reason of any negligence of the Grantee or any of its agents, servants or employees in exercising any of the privileges, rights or franchises herein granted. The Grantee shall hold and save harmless the Municipality from and against any and all loss and damage of any kind or description whatever by reason of the Grantee's negligent exercise of any rights, privilege or franchise hereby granted. 
(Ord. No. 880,  3, 2-14-2012; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-3-40. - Responsibilities. 
    This franchise and the rights, privileges and franchises hereby granted hereunder shall be and remain in full force and effect for the period of 25 years from the final passage date of the ordinance codified herein. Within 60 days from and after final passage of said ordinance, the Grantee shall have filed with the City Clerk its written acceptance of this Article. In case of the failure of the Grantee to file such acceptance within the time so limited, this Article, and the rights, privileges and franchises hereby granted, shall be and become null and void, but the rights and franchises granted by this Article are granted upon the express condition that the Municipality shall have the right and power to purchase or to condemn at the time and under the conditions and in the manner provided by the laws of the State at such time in full force and effect, all works and plants erected hereunder and all property of the Grantee actually used or useful for the convenience of the Municipality. 
(Ord. No. 880,  4, 2-14-2012; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-3-50. - Franchise fee. 
(a)  In consideration of the rights and privileges herein granted, the Grantee shall assess, effective the first billing cycle after this franchise becomes effective, to residential and commercial customers of the Grantee within the Municipality a franchise tax or fee equivalent to three percent of annual gross revenue derived from gas service within the corporate limits of the Municipality that is billed by the Grantee, including the revenue received from the sale of industrial gas and excluding the amount received from the Municipality itself for gas service furnished it and after adjustment for the net write-off of uncollectable amounts and corrections of bills theretofore rendered. The Grantee shall pay to the Finance Director an annual payment for each year of the duration of this franchise, in an amount equal to the franchise fee or tax funds collected by the Grantee hereunder. Payment shall be made on or before April 1 of each year for the preceding year, and each such payment shall be accompanied by a statement supporting the payment. 
(b)  The Municipality reserves the right to renegotiate the franchise fee leasing up to each five-year anniversary of this franchise. In order to exercise the rights to renegotiate the franchise fee, the Municipality must provide to the Grantee written notice of such exercise by a duly authorized representative, no sooner than 180 days and no later than 60 days prior to the applicable annual anniversary date of this franchise. Upon the Grantee receiving a duly authorized notice from the Municipality that complies with the above-stated limitations, the Grantee and the Municipality shall negotiate in good faith, and the Municipality shall select, no later than 30 days prior to the applicable annual anniversary date of this franchise, a reasonable franchise fee to replace the franchise fee then in effect. The replacement franchise fee shall become effective upon the annual anniversary date that immediately follows the year in which the Municipality exercised this right. For illustrative purposes only, if the Municipality were to exercise this right 90 days prior to the fifth annual anniversary date of this Article, the reasonable replacement franchise fee that the Municipality selected would become effective on the fifth annual anniversary date of this franchise. Unless and until the franchise fee is replaced pursuant to this Subsection, the then-current franchise fee shall remain in full force and effect. 
(c)  Such payment shall be in lieu of any and all other fees, charges, licenses, taxes or assessments which the Municipality may impose for the rights and privileges herein granted or for the privilege of doing such business within the Municipality and for the use of the rights-of-way. In the event any such fee, charge, license, tax or assessment is imposed by the Municipality, the payment to be made in accordance with the provisions of this Section shall be refunded in an amount equal to the annual burden of such fee, charge, license, tax or assessment imposed upon the Grantee. Ad valorem property taxes imposed generally upon all real and personal property within the Municipality shall not be deemed to affect the obligation of the Grantee under this Section. 
(d)  If, at any time during the term of this franchise, the manner in which the franchise fee is calculated, collected or paid is changed, whether by action of the Grantee, the PUC or any entity having jurisdiction thereof, the Grantee agrees to cooperate with the Municipality in modifying the franchise to assure that the Grantee collects and the Municipality receives an amount in franchise fees or some other form that is the same amount of franchise fees collected by the Grantee and paid to the Municipality as of the date of such change and required modification, to the extent permitted by law. 
(Ord. No. 880,  5, 2-14-2012; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-3-60. - Severability. 
    If any clause, sentence or section of this Article shall be held void by any court, the same shall not affect the remainder of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 880,  6, 2-14-2012; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-3-70. - Successors and assigns. 
    The rights, privileges, franchises and easements hereby granted shall inure to the benefit of said Grantee, its successors and assigns, and, wherever the term Grantee is used herein, it shall be held to mean and include SourceGas Distribution, LLC, its successors and assigns, and wherever the word Municipality is used herein, it shall be held to mean the City of Rocky Ford, County of Otero, State of Colorado. 
(Ord. No. 880,  7, 2-14-2012; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 4 - Electric Franchise 

Sec. 5-4-10. - Franchise granted. 
    The City (hereinafter referred to as "Grantor") hereby grants a nonexclusive franchise to Black Hills/Colorado Electric Utility Company, LP, d/b/a Black Hills Energy, a Delaware corporation (hereinafter called "Grantee"), its lessees, successors and assigns. The Grantee is hereby granted the right, privilege, permission and authority to construct, install, maintain, operate and extend in, along and across the present and future streets, alleys, avenues, bridges, public rights-of-way and public easements as are now within the present or future limits of the Grantor, an electric distribution system and all facilities necessary for the production, transmission and distribution of electrical power and energy for the purpose of carrying on a general power and light business and other operations connected therewith or incident thereto for all purposes to the inhabitants of the Grantor and consumers in the vicinity thereof, and for the distribution of electric power and energy from or through the Grantor to points beyond the limits thereof. Such facilities shall include, but not be limited to, poles, transmission lines, distribution lines, anchors, guy wires, cables, conduits, street lighting poles, transformers and all other apparatus and appliances necessary or incident thereto for all purposes for which it may be used, and to do all other things necessary and proper in providing electric service to the inhabitants of the Grantor and in carrying on such business. 
(Ord. No. 875, 9-13-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-4-20. - Term. 
    The rights and privileges granted hereunder shall remain in effect for a period of 25 years from the effective date of this franchise. 
(Ord. No. 875, 9-13-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-4-30. - Franchise fees or taxes. 
(a)  The Grantee shall pay to the Grantor three percent of all collected gross earnings derived by the Grantee from all electricity sold by it during the term of this franchise to inhabitants of the Grantor for light, heat and power purposes and any other purposes to which the same may be applicable. Payment shall be made to the Finance Director on or before the first day of February of each year for the percentage due the Grantor; provided always that the income derived from the sale of electricity to the Grantor for street lighting or other purposes shall not be considered part of said earnings or included therein. 
(b)  Said payment shall be in lieu of all pole, wire, meter, occupation, privilege, franchise, license or other similar tax now or hereafter assessed or levied against the Grantee by the Grantor for any purpose whatever; and should the Grantor at any time impose any such tax, then, and in that event, the obligation hereby imposed upon the Grantee to pay the amount of three percent provided in this Section shall cease without affecting the remainder of this franchise. 
(c)  The Grantee shall list the franchise fee collected from customers as a separate item on bills for utility service issued to its customers. If at any time the Colorado Public Utilities Commission or other authority having proper jurisdiction prohibits such recovery, the Grantee will no longer be obligated to collect and pay the franchise fee until an alternate lawful franchise fee can be negotiated and implemented. In addition, with prior approval of the Grantor, the Grantee may reduce the franchise fee payable for electricity delivered to a specific customer when such reduction is required to attract or retain the business of that customer. 
(d)  Within ten days of the effective date of this franchise, the Grantor shall provide the Grantee with a map of its corporate limits (the "Map"). The Map shall be of sufficient detail to assist the Grantee in determining whether its customers reside within the Grantor's corporate limits. The Map shall serve as the sole basis for determining the Grantee's obligation hereunder to collect and pay the franchise fee from customers; provided, however, that, if the Grantor's corporate limits are changed by annexation or otherwise, it shall be the Grantor's sole responsibility to: (1) update the Map so that such changes are included therein; and (2) provide the updated Map to the Grantee. The Grantee's obligation to collect and pay the franchise fee from customers within an annexed area shall not commence until the later of: (1) 60 days after the Grantee's receipt from the Grantor of an updated Map including such annexed area; or (2) such time after the Grantee's receipt from the Grantor of any updated Map including such annexed area as is reasonably necessary for the Grantee to identify the customers in an annexed area obligated to pay the franchise fee. 
(e)  The Grantor shall provide copies of annexation ordinances to the Grantee on a timely basis to ensure appropriate franchise fee collection from customers within the corporate limits of the Grantor as set forth in Subsection (d) above. 
(Ord. No. 875, 9-13-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-4-40. - Governing rules and regulations. 
(a)  The franchise granted hereunder is subject to all conditions, limitations and immunities now provided for or as hereafter amended and applicable to the operations of a public utility by state or federal law. The rates to be charged by the Grantee for service within the present or future corporate limits of the Grantor, and the rules and regulations regarding the character, quality and standards of service to be furnished by the Grantee, shall be under the jurisdiction and control of such regulatory body or bodies as may, from time to time, be vested by law with authority and jurisdiction over the rates, regulations and quality and standards of service to be supplied by the Grantee. However, should any judicial, regulatory or legislative body having proper jurisdiction take any action that precludes the Grantee from recovering from its customers any cost associated with services provided hereunder, then the Grantee and the Grantor shall renegotiate the terms of this franchise in accordance with the action taken. In determining the rights and duties of the Grantee, the terms of this franchise shall take precedence over any conflicting terms or requirements contained in any other ordinance enacted by the Grantor. 
(b)  The right is hereby reserved to the Grantor to adopt, from time to time, in addition to the provisions herein contained, such ordinances as may be deemed necessary in the exercise of its police power, provided that such regulations shall be reasonable and not destructive of the rights herein granted and not in conflict with the laws of the State or with orders of other authorities having jurisdiction in the premises. 
(Ord. No. 875, 9-13-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-4-50. - Provision for inadequate energy supplies. 
    If an energy supplier is unable to furnish an adequate supply of energy due to an emergency, an order or decision of a public regulatory body or other acts beyond the control of the Grantee, then the Grantee shall have the right and authority to adopt reasonable rules and regulations limiting, curtailing or allocating extensions of service or supply of energy to any customers or prospective customers and withholding the supply of energy to new customers, provided that such rules and regulations shall be uniform as applied to each class of customers or prospective customers and shall be nondiscriminatory as between communities receiving service from the Grantee. 
(Ord. No. 875, 9-13-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-4-60. - Construction and maintenance of Grantee's facilities. 
(a)  Any pavements, sidewalks or curbing taken up and any and all excavations made shall be done in such a manner as to cause only such inconvenience to the inhabitants of the Grantor and the general public as is reasonably necessary, and repairs and replacements shall be made promptly by the Grantee, leaving such properties in as good a condition as existed immediately prior to excavation. 
(b)  The Grantee agrees that, for the term of this franchise, it will use its best efforts to maintain its facilities and equipment in a condition sufficient to meet the current and future energy requirements of the Grantor, its inhabitants and industries. While maintaining its facilities and equipment, the Grantee shall obtain permits as required by ordinance and will fix its excavations within a commercially reasonable time period; except that, in emergency situations, the Grantee shall take such immediate unilateral actions as it determines are necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare; in which case, the Grantee shall notify the Grantor as soon as reasonably possible. Within a reasonable time thereafter, the Grantee shall request and the Grantor shall issue any permits or authorizations required by the Grantor for the actions conducted by the Grantee during the emergency situation. 
(c)  The Grantor will give the Grantee reasonable notice of plans for street improvements where paving or resurfacing of a permanent nature is involved that affects the Grantee's facilities. The notice shall contain the nature and character of the improvements and the time when the Grantor will start the work, and, if more than one right-of-way is involved, the order in which the work is to proceed. The notice shall be given to the Grantee as soon as practical in advance of the actual commencement of the work, considering seasonable working conditions, to permit the Grantee to make any additions, alterations or repairs to its facilities. 
(Ord. No. 875, 9-13-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-4-70. - Tree trimming. 
    The Grantor grants the Grantee the right, permission and authority to trim and remove trees upon, over, across and along all of the streets, alleys, avenues, bridges, public rights-of-way and public places of the Grantor. 
(Ord. No. 875, 9-13-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-4-80. - Street lighting. 
(a)  The Grantee will furnish, erect, maintain, clean, repair and operate, in accordance with the street lighting tariffs as approved from time to time by the Colorado Public Utilities Commission, street lights within the corporate limits of the Grantor. The Grantor will pay for the street light service at the rates stipulated in the tariff. 
(b)  The Grantor may, from time to time, cause the number of street lights to be increased by making a written request to the Grantee, stating the number, capacity and location desired. Such request shall be made at least 90 days prior to the time additional street lights are required by the Grantor. 
(c)  Nothing in this franchise shall prohibit the Grantor from constructing and owning all or part of its street lighting equipment and other facilities, nor limit how the Grantor shall accomplish the same. In the event the Grantor elects to purchase, construct, install or operate its street lighting equipment or facilities, the Grantee agrees, at the Grantor's request, to provide electricity to energize these facilities and, if requested by the Grantor, the Grantee will maintain these facilities in accordance with rates, terms and conditions submitted to and approved by the Colorado Public Utilities Commission. 
(Ord. No. 875, 9-13-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-4-90. - Extension of Grantee's facilities. 
    Upon receipt and acceptance of a valid application for service, the Grantee shall, subject to its own economic feasibility criteria, make reasonable extensions of its distribution facilities to serve customers located within the current or future corporate limits of the Grantor; provided, however, that nothing in this Article shall require the Grantee to install new facilities underground. In the event that the Grantor orders or requests the Grantee to install facilities underground along any street, alley, avenue, bridge, public right-of-way or public place, the Grantee shall have the right to recover from the Grantor the difference in cost between placing facilities overhead and placing new facilities underground. No obligation shall extend to, or be binding upon, the Grantee to install new facilities underground unless the Grantee is able to obtain an easement for such facilities on adjoining private property adjacent to the public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 875, 9-13-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-4-100. - Relocation of Grantee's facilities. 
(a)  If the Grantor elects to change the grade or otherwise alter any street, alley, avenue, bridge, public right-of-way or public place for a public purpose unless otherwise reimbursed by federal, state or local legislative act or governmental agency, the Grantee, upon reasonable notice from the Grantor, shall remove and relocate its facilities or equipment situated in the public rights-of-way at the cost and expense of the Grantee, if such removal is necessary to prevent interference. 
(b)  If the Grantor orders or requests the Grantee to relocate its facilities or equipment for the primary benefit of a commercial or private project, or as a result of the initial request of a commercial or private developer or other nonpublic entity, and such removal is necessary to prevent interference, then the Grantee shall receive payment for the cost of such relocation as a precondition to relocating its facilities or equipment. 
(c)  The Grantor shall consider reasonable alternatives in designing its public works projects and exercising its authority under this Section so as to not arbitrarily cause the Grantee unreasonable additional expense. If alternative public right-of-way space is available, the Grantor shall also provide a reasonable alternative location from the Grantee's facilities. The Grantor shall give the Grantee written notice of an order or request to vacate a public right-of-way; provided, however, that its receipt of such notice shall not deprive the Grantee of its right to operate and maintain its existing facilities in such public right-of-way until it: (1) if applicable, receives the reasonable cost of relocating the same; and (2) obtains a reasonable public right-of-way, dedicated utility easement or private easement alternative location for such facilities. 
(d)  Any person or corporation desiring to move a building or other structure along, or to make any unusual use of, any street, alley, avenue, bridge, public right-of-way or public place which shall interfere with the facilities or equipment of the Grantee, shall first give notice to the Grantor and the Grantee and pay a sum sufficient to cover the expense of moving the Grantee's facilities and equipment in such location, and any damages incident thereto. 
(Ord. No. 875, 9-13-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-4-110. - Confidential information. 
    The Grantor acknowledges that certain information it might request from the Grantee pursuant to this franchise may be of a proprietary and confidential nature, and that such requests may be subject to the Homeland Security Act or other confidentiality protections under state or federal law. If the Grantee requests that any information provided by the Grantee to the Grantor be kept confidential due to its proprietary or commercial value, the Grantor and its employees, agents and representatives shall maintain the confidentiality of such information, to the extent allowed by law. If the Grantor is requested or required by legal or administrative process to disclose any such proprietary or confidential information, the Grantor shall promptly notify the Grantee of such request or requirement so that the Grantee may seek an appropriate protective order or other relief. 
(Ord. No. 875, 9-13-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-4-120. - Force majeure. 
(a)  It shall not be a breach or default under this Article if either party fails to perform its obligations hereunder due to force majeure. Force majeure shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Physical events, such as acts of God, landslides, lightning, earthquakes, fires, freezing, storms, floods, washouts, explosions, breakage or accident, or necessity of repairs to machinery, equipment or distribution or transmission lines; 
(2)  Acts of others, such as strikes, workforce stoppages, riots, sabotage, insurrections or wars; 
(3)  Governmental actions, such as necessity for compliance with any court order, law, statute, ordinance, executive order or regulation promulgated by a governmental authority having jurisdiction; and 
(4)  Any other causes, whether of the kind herein enumerated or otherwise not reasonably within the control of the affected party to prevent or overcome. 
(b)  Each party shall make reasonable efforts to avoid force majeure and to resolve such event as promptly as reasonably possible once it occurs in order to resume performance of its obligations hereunder; provided, however, that this provision shall not obligate a party to settle any labor strike. 
(Ord. No. 875, 9-13-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-4-130. - Hold harmless. 
    The Grantee, during the term of this franchise, agrees to save the Grantor harmless from and against all claims, demands, losses and expenses arising directly out of the negligence of the Grantee, its employees or agents, in constructing, operating and maintaining its distribution and transmission facilities or equipment; provided, however, that the Grantee need not save the Grantor harmless from claims, demands, losses and expenses arising out of the negligence of the Grantor, its employees or agents. 
(Ord. No. 875, 9-13-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-4-140. - Successors and assigns. 
    All rights, privileges and authority granted to the Grantee hereunder shall inure to the benefit of the Grantee's lessees, successors and assigns, subject to the terms, provisions and conditions herein contained, and all obligations imposed upon the Grantee hereunder shall be binding upon the Grantee's lessees, successors and assigns. 
(Ord. No. 875, 9-13-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-4-150. - No third party beneficiaries. 
    The ordinance codified herein constitutes a franchise agreement between the Grantor and the Grantee. No provision of this franchise shall inure to the benefit of any third person, including the public at large, so as to constitute any such person as a third party beneficiary of the franchise agreement or of any one or more of the terms hereof, or otherwise give rise to any cause of action from any person a party hereto. 
(Ord. No. 875, 9-13-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-4-160. - Severability. 
    If any clause, sentence or section of this franchise is deemed invalid by any judicial, regulatory or legislative body having proper jurisdiction, the remaining provisions shall not be affected. 
(Ord. No. 875, 9-13-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-4-170. - Nonwaiver. 
    Any waiver of obligation or default under this franchise shall not be construed as a waiver of any future defaults, whether of like or different character. 
(Ord. No. 875, 9-13-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-4-180. - Repeal of conflicting ordinances. 
    The ordinance codified herein, when accepted by the Grantee as provided below, shall constitute the entire agreement between the Grantor and the Grantee relating to the franchise granted by the Grantor hereunder, and the same shall supersede all prior ordinances relating thereto, and any terms and conditions of such prior ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. 
(Ord. No. 875, 9-13-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-4-190. - Effect and interpretation of ordinance. 
    The captions that precede each section of this Article are for convenience and/or reference only and shall not be taken into consideration in the interpretation of any of the provisions of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 875, 9-13-2011; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 5 - Cable Television Franchise 
Division 1 - General Provisions 

Sec. 5-5-10. - Grant of franchise. 
    A nonexclusive right is hereby granted to Bresnan Communications, LLC ("BCI"), its successors and assigns, to establish, construct, operate, maintain, repair, replace, renew, reconstruct and remove a cable television system across public property in the City limits for a term of 20 years, in accordance with the laws and regulations of the United States of America and the State and the ordinances and regulations of the City, including the nonexclusive right, privilege and authority: 
(1)  To sell and supply audio and video communication service to persons within the City; 
(2)  To use public property within the City; and 
(3)  To engage in such further activities within the City as may now or hereinafter be consistent with the generally accepted principles applicable to the operation of a cable television system. 
(Prior code,  10.22.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-5-20. - Effective date of franchise. 
    The franchise shall become effective from and after the effective date of the ordinance codified herein and compliance by BCI with Federal Communications Commission rules and regulations. 
(Prior code,  10.22.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-5-30. - Assignment. 
    BCI shall not assign or transfer any right granted under this franchise to any other person, company or corporation without prior consent to the City Council, which consent shall not be unreasonably withheld; provided that BCI shall have the right to assign this franchise to a corporation wholly owned by BCI or to a limited partnership of which BCI or other wholly owned subsidiary of BCI is a general partner without prior consent of the City. 
(Prior code,  10.22.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-5-40. - Conflicting provisions repealed. 
    All ordinances or parts thereof in conflict with the terms of this franchise are hereby repealed; provided, however, that such repeal shall only be to the extent of such conflict. 
(Prior code,  10.22.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-5-50. - Definitions. 
    The following words or phrases, when used in this Article, have the meanings ascribed to them below: 
    Cable television system means any facility that, in whole or in part, receives directly or indirectly over the air and amplifies or otherwise modifies the signals transmitting programs broadcast by one or more television or radio stations and distributes such signals by wire or cable to subscribing members of the public who pay for such services. 
    Channel means the segment of the electromagnetic spectrum to which a source of television transmission is assigned. 
    City means the City of Rocky Ford, Colorado. When the context so requires, the term City shall mean and include the City, its officers, agents, employees, servants and independent contractors. 
    FCC means the Federal Communications Commission. 
    Franchise means the rights, privileges and authority granted by the City to the Grantee hereunder and shall include all of the terms and conditions of this franchise. 
    Grantee means Bresnan Communications, LLC, its successors and assigns. When the context so requires, the term Grantee shall include the Grantee, its officers, agents, employees and independent contractors. 
    Person means any individual or any corporation, business or mix thereof owned by a private person, including property owned by a public utility not owned or operated by the City. 
    Property of the Grantee means all property, real, personal or mixed, owned or used by the Grantee however arising from or related to or connected with the franchise. 
    Public property shall mean all property, real, personal or mixed, owned or used by the City, including property owned or used by a public utility owned or operated by the City. 
(Prior code,  10.22.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-5-60. - Use of property. 
    The Grantee may use public property within the City and, with the written consent of the owner thereof, private property within the City, in furtherance of such activities within the City as may now or hereinafter be consistent with generally accepted principles applicable to the operation of a cable television system, subject, however, to the following restrictions: 
(1)  The Grantee shall comply with all governmental laws, ordinance, rules or regulations as may now or hereinafter be applicable thereto. 
(2)  The Grantee shall not use or occupy or permit public property or private property to be used or occupied or do or permit anything to be done on or about public property or private property which will in any manner: 
a.  Impair the owner's interest in or title thereto; 
b.  Impair the mortgage or lease as may now or hereinafter be applicable thereto; 
c.  Adversely affect the then value or character thereof; 
d.  Cause or be likely to cause structural damage thereto, or any part thereof; 
e.  Cause or be likely to cause any damage or injury to any utility service available thereto; 
f.  Create a public or private nuisance, cause any offensive or obnoxious vibration, noise, odor or undesirable effect or interfere with the safety, comfort or convenience of the owner thereof and persons lawfully on or about the same; 
g.  Violate the rules, regulations and requirements of any person furnishing utilities or services thereto; 
h.  Violate the rules, regulations and requirements of any person furnishing utilities or services thereto; or 
i.  Make void or voidable any insurance then in force affecting the same, or cause an increase in the rates applicable thereto. 
(Prior code,  10.22.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-5-70. - Taxes. 
    The Grantee shall pay all real estate taxes, special assessments, personal property taxes, license fees, permit fees and other charges of a like nature which may be taxed, charged, assessed, levied or imposed upon the property of the Grantee and upon any services rendered by the Grantee. 
(Prior code,  10.22.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-5-80. - Insurance. 
    The Grantee shall, at all times during the term of this franchise, carry and require its contractors to carry: 
(1)  Insurance in such forms and with such companies as shall be approved by the City to protect the City and the Grantee from and against any and all claims, injury or damage to persons or property, both real and personal, caused by the construction, erection, operation and maintenance of any structure, equipment or appliance in connection with the cable television system. The amount of such insurance shall be not less than $100,000.00 as to any one person, $300,000.00 as to any one occurrence for injury or death to persons, and $100,000.00 for damages to property with, as to Grantee, so-called umbrella coverage of at least $5,000,000.00. 
(2)  Workers' compensation insurance as provided by the laws of the State. 
(3)  Automobile insurance with limits of not less than $100,000.00/$300,000.00 of public liability coverage and automobile property damage insurance with a limit of not less than $100,000.00 covering all automotive equipment, with, as to the Grantee, so-called umbrella coverage of at least $5,000,000.00. 
(4)  All of said insurance coverage shall provide a ten-day notice to the City in the event of material alteration or cancellation of any coverage afforded in said policies prior to the date said material alteration or cancellation becomes effective. 
(5)  Copies of certificates of insurance showing evidence of all insurance coverage required hereunder shall be furnished and filed with the City prior to the commencement of operations or the expirations of prior policies, as the case may be. 
(6)  The Grantee shall pay all reasonable expenses incurred by the City in defending itself with regard to all damages, penalties or other claims resulting from the acts of the Grantee, its assigns, employees, agents, invitees or other persons. Said expenses shall include all out-of-pocket expenses, such as attorney's fees, and shall include the value of any service rendered by the City Attorney or any other officers or employees of the City. 
(Prior code,  10.22.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-5-90. - Repairs. 
(a)  During the terms of the franchise, the Grantee shall, at its own expense, make all necessary repairs and replacements to the property of the Grantee. 
(b)  Such repairs and replacements, interior and exterior, ordinary as well as extraordinary, and structural as well as nonstructural, shall be made promptly as and when needed. 
(Prior code,  10.22.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 5-5-100. - Hold harmless.
