    Inoperable vehicle means any automobile, truck or self-propelled vehicle incapable of moving under its own power or which does not comply with the minimum safety requirements of the Colorado Motor Vehicle Law. 
    Litter means the scattering or dropping of rubbish, trash or other matter, organic or mineral. 
    Nuisance means any substance, act, occupation, condition or use of property declared a nuisance by this Chapter, by the State or by any court or agency thereof, or known as a nuisance at common law, or which is of such a nature and duration as to: 
(1)  Substantially annoy, injure or endanger the comfort, health, repose or safety of the public. 
(2)  In any way render the public insecure in life or in the use of property. 
(3)  Unlawfully and substantially interfere with, obstruct or tend to obstruct or render dangerous for passage any street, alley, highway or other public way. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, corporation, association or other type of organization, or an agent or employee thereof. 
    Refuse means and includes any grass clippings, leaves, hay, straw, manure, shavings, excelsior, paper, ashes, rubbish containers, boxes, glass, cans, bottles, garbage, waste and discarded building and construction materials, including but not limited to plaster, broken concrete, bricks, cinder blocks, stones, wood, roofing material, wire or metal binding, sacks or loose discarded or unused material; all rubbish of any kind or nature whatsoever; and any other materials commonly known as rubbish or refuse of any kind or character or by any means known. 
    Rubbish means any type of debris, trash, waste or rejected matter. 
    Trash means any worn out, broken up or used refuse, rubbish, toppings, twigs, leaves of trees or worthless matter or material. 
    Weed means an unsightly, useless, troublesome or injurious growing herbaceous plant, and includes all rank vegetable growth which exhales unpleasant and noxious odors and high and rank vegetable growth that may conceal filthy deposits. 
(Prior code,  6.06.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-1-30. - Common law nuisances. 
    Any nuisance which has been declared to be such by state courts or statutes or known as such by common law shall constitute a nuisance when the same exists within the City limits or within one mile thereof. Any person causing or permitting any such nuisance shall be in violation of this Chapter. 
(Prior code,  6.06.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-1-40. - Author of nuisances. 
(a)  Where a nuisance exists upon property and is the outgrowth of the usual, natural or necessary use of the property, the owner, tenant or his or her agent and all other persons having control of the property on which such nuisance exists shall be deemed to be authors thereof and shall be jointly and equally liable and responsible. 
(b)  Where any such nuisance arises from the unusual or unnecessary use of such property or from the business conducted thereon, the occupants and all other persons contributing to the continuance of such nuisance shall be deemed the authors. 
(Prior code,  6.06.040; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-1-50. - Prohibition of nuisances. 
    No person, being the owner, agent or occupant of or having under his or her control any building, lot, premises or unimproved real estate within the limits of the City, shall maintain or allow any nuisance to be or remain therein. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-1-60. - Ascertaining nuisances. 
    Whenever the pursuit of any trade, business or the manufacturing or maintenance of any substance or condition of things is, upon investigation, considered by the City Manager to be dangerous to the health of any of the inhabitants of the City, the same shall be considered a nuisance and shall be abated. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-1-70. - Authority of City to declare nuisance. 
    Any act, condition, substance, occupation or use of property which substantially meets the criteria of a nuisance as defined in this Chapter may be so declared by the Code Enforcement Officer, and nothing in this Chapter shall be construed to limit the power of the City to make such declaration. 
(Prior code,  6.06.050; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-1-80. - Filing complaint. 
    In addition to or in lieu of any procedure for abatement, a direct complaint may be filed by any person or police officer against any person who violates any provision of this Chapter with the Code Enforcement Officer. Such complaint shall include, whenever possible, the nature of the public nuisance, the location, including the address, the name of the owner, occupant or manager of the property, the duration of the nuisance and the name and address of the complainant. 
(Prior code,  6.06.060; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-1-90. - Inspection; right of entry; emergencies. 
(a)  Whenever the Code Enforcement Officer has reason to believe that a public nuisance exists and that such public nuisance constitutes an emergency presenting imminent danger of serious injury to persons or property, the Chief of Police may immediately enter into any building or upon any premises within the jurisdiction of the City for purposes of inspection or abatement. 
(b)  Whenever an emergency situation exists in relation to the enforcement of any of the provisions of this Article, the Chief of Police, upon a presentation of proper credentials or identification in the case of an occupied building or premises, may enter into the building or go upon the premises within the jurisdiction of the City. In said emergency situation, the Chief of Police may use such reasonable force as may be necessary to gain entry into said building or upon such premises. 
(c)  Whenever necessary to make an inspection to enforce any of the provisions of this Chapter, or whenever the Chief of Police has reasonable cause to believe that there exists in any building or upon any premises a condition which constitutes a nuisance therein, the Chief of Police may enter such building or premises at all reasonable times to inspect the same or to perform any duty imposed on him or her. If such building or premises are occupied, the Chief of Police shall first make a reasonable effort to locate the owner, occupant or other person having charge or control of the building or premises and, upon locating said owner, occupant or other person, shall present proper credentials and demand entry. If entry is refused, the Chief of Police shall give the owner or occupant or, if the owner or occupant cannot be located after a reasonable effort, shall leave at the building or premises, a 24-hour written notice of intention to inspect. The notice given to the owner or occupant, if left on the premises as aforesaid, shall state that the property owner has the right to refuse entry and that, in the event that such entry is refused, inspection may be made only upon issuance of a search warrant by the Municipal Judge. 
(d)  After the expiration of said 24-hour period from the giving or leaving of notice, the Chief of Police may appear before the Municipal Judge or other state court judge and, upon a showing of probable cause, shall obtain a search warrant entitling him or her to enter said building or go upon such premises. Upon presentation of said search warrant and proper credentials, or possession of the same in the case of an unoccupied building or premises, the Chief of Police may enter into said building or go upon said premises using such reasonable force as may be necessary to gain entry. 
(e)  For the purposes of Subsection (d) above, a determination of probable cause will be based upon reasonableness, and, if a valid public interest justifies the intrusion contemplated, then there is probable cause to issue a search warrant. The person applying for such warrant shall not be required to demonstrate specific knowledge of the condition of the particular structure or premises at issue in order to obtain a search warrant. It shall be unlawful for any owner or occupant of said building or premises to resist reasonable force used by any authorized agent acting pursuant to this Section. 
(Prior code,  6.06.070; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-1-100. - Jurisdiction. 
(a)  An action to abate a public nuisance may be brought in Municipal Court or any other court where appropriate. 
(b)  Except as otherwise may be provided in this Chapter, the practice and procedure in an action to abate a public nuisance shall be governed by the Colorado Rules of Civil Procedure and the Colorado Rules of Municipal Court Procedure. 
(c)  An action to abate a public nuisance may be brought by the City Attorney in the name of the People of the State of Colorado and the City. 
(d)  An action to abate a public nuisance, and any action in which a temporary restraining order, temporary writ of injunction or preliminary injunction is requested, shall be commenced by the filing of a complaint, which shall be verified or supported by an affidavit. A summons shall be issued and served as in civil cases. 
(e)  The respondent or defendant shall not be entitled to a jury trial. 
(Prior code,  6.06.080; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-1-110. - Abatement of nuisance. 
(a)  Each and every nuisance declared or defined by any ordinance of the City or by this Chapter is hereby prohibited, and the Code Enforcement Officer is hereby authorized in his or her discretion to cause the same to be summarily abated in such manner as he or she may direct, subject to the limitations herein provided. If any nuisance is found to exist upon public property, it shall be the duty of the City to abate such nuisance immediately. 
(b)  Whenever a public nuisance exists which constitutes an emergency, imminent danger or serious injury to persons or property, the Code Enforcement Officer may order without notice or judicial action that the public nuisance be summarily abated by removal, destruction or mitigation. 
(c)  Unless a specific provision of this Chapter states otherwise, when a public nuisance does not require summary abatement, the Code Enforcement Officer may prepare and serve a notice to abate on the owner, manager, occupant or possessor of any property which constitutes the public nuisance or the person conducting or maintaining the business, occupation, operation or activity which constitutes the public nuisance. Such notice shall: 
(1)  State that, if the nuisance is not abated within seven days, an action may be brought in the Municipal Court or other state court to abate the nuisance and that all costs of abatement, plus ten percent of such costs for inspection and other additional administrative costs, including but not limited to reasonable attorney fees, may be assessed against the person found by the court to have caused, allowed to be caused or allowed to continue the public nuisance and may become a lien upon any property on which the abatement was performed. 
(2)  Be in writing, signed by the Code Enforcement Officer issuing the notice, and served, either personally or by means of posting on the premises upon which the nuisance exists. If notice is served by posting, a copy of the notice shall also be mailed by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the owner of record of the property at the last known address. 
(d)  When a public nuisance has not been voluntarily abated within the time specified in the notice to abate, the following procedure shall apply: 
(1)  If the person notified in accordance with Subsection (c) above neglects or refuses to comply with the requirements of said notice to abate the nuisance within the time specified, the Code Enforcement Officer may proceed at once, upon the expiration of the time specified in such notice, to commence appropriate legal action to cause such nuisance to be abated; provided that, if the owner is unknown or cannot be found, the Code Enforcement Officer may proceed to abate such nuisance after notice has been posted for the period equal to the time specified to abate said nuisance. In either case, the expense of such abatement shall be collected from the owner of the property upon which said nuisance existed. 
(2)  The City may bring action in the Municipal Court or other state court to have the nuisance declared as such by the court and for an order enjoining the public nuisance or authorizing its restraint, removal, termination or abatement by the owner or the person who allowed the nuisance to be caused or to continue, or by the Code Enforcement Officer or any person under contract with the City to perform such services. 
(3)  The action to declare and abate a public nuisance shall be brought by the City in the name of the People of the City, by the filing of a complaint, which shall be verified or supported by an affidavit. A summons shall be issued and served as in civil cases, and any employee of the City who is over the age of 18 years may serve the summons and verified complaint upon the respondent. Trial shall be to the Municipal Court. 
(4)  A notice of appearance shall be served with the summons and complaint. The appearance date shall be not less than 30 days from the date of service of the summons and complaint. The trial shall be held upon the appearance date unless the court grants a continuance for good cause shown. 
(5)  The respondent shall file a response on or before the appearance date set forth in the notice of appearance. 
(6)  Upon the date and at the time set for appearance and trial, if the respondent has filed no response and fails to appear and if the City proves that proper service was made on the respondent at least 30 days prior to the appearance date, the Municipal Court may grant such orders as are requested by the City. However, the Municipal Court shall order that enforcement by the City be stayed for ten days and that a copy of the Municipal Court's order be mailed to the respondent at his or her last known address. Failure to appear on any other date set for trial shall be grounds for entering a default and judgment thereon against a non-appearing party. For good cause shown, and prior to enforcement, the Municipal Court may set aside any entry of default and the judgment entered thereon. 
(7)  Upon a judicial determination that a nuisance exists, the Code Enforcement Officer may be authorized to abate said nuisance or cause the same to be abated, employing such forces and persons as may be necessary to abate said nuisance or cause the same to be abated, including employees of the City or by contract or otherwise. All other City officials and employees are hereby authorized and directed to render such assistance to the Code Enforcement Officer as may be required for the abatement of such nuisance and in connection with the enforcement thereof. 
(8)  The judgment of the Municipal Court may be appealed. 
(e)  The remedies specified in this Section shall be in addition to all other remedies provided by law. 
(Prior code,  6.06.090; Ord. No. 786,  1, 8-19-2003; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-1-120. - Judgment; relief. 
(a)  The judgment in an action to abate a public nuisance may include a permanent injunction to restrain, abate and prevent the continuance or reoccurrence of the nuisance. The Court may grant declaratory relief, mandatory orders or any other relief deemed necessary to accomplish the purposes of the injunction and enforce the same, and the Court may retain jurisdiction of the case for the purpose of enforcing its order. 
(b)  The judgment in an action to abate a public nuisance may include an order directing the Chief of Police to seize and close the public nuisance and to keep the same effectually closed until further order of the court, not to exceed one year. 
(c)  The judgment in an action to abate a public nuisance may include, in addition to or in the alternative to other injunctive relief, an order requiring the removal, correction or other abatement of a public nuisance, in whole or in part, by the Chief of Police at the expense of the owner or operator of the public nuisance. 
(d)  The judgment in an action to abate a public nuisance may include, in addition to or in the alternative to any other relief authorized by the provisions of this Article, the imposition of a fine of not more than $300.00, conditioned upon failure or refusal of compliance with the orders of the Court within any time limits therein fixed. 
(Prior code,  6.06.100; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-1-130. - Redelivery of seized premises. 
    If the owner or operator of a building or place seized and closed as a public nuisance is not guilty of any contempt of court in the proceedings and demonstrates by evidence satisfactory to the Court that the public nuisance has been abated and will not reoccur, the Court may order the premises delivered to the owner or operator. As a condition of such order, the Court may require the posting of a bond, in an amount fixed by order of the Court, for the faithful performance of the obligation on the owner or operator thereunder to prevent recurrence or continuance of the public nuisance. 
(Prior code,  6.06.110; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-1-140. - Responsibility for costs of abatement. 
    A person found by the Court to have caused a public nuisance or allowed the nuisance to be caused or to continue shall be liable for the costs specified in this Section, including reasonable attorney fees. Such costs may be collected by the City in the civil action to abate the nuisance or assessed and filed as a lien against any property on which the abatement was performed as specified in this Section. 
(Prior code,  6.06.120; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-1-150. - Notice of assessment. 
    If the costs of abatement have not been otherwise collected, the Code Enforcement Officer shall prepare a statement enumerating the actual costs of abatement and collection plus ten percent of the abatement costs for inspection and other additional administrative costs. The costs enumerated in this statement shall be a first and prior lien upon the property relating back to the date upon which the abatement was performed. A copy of this statement shall be mailed by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the owner of such property as shown upon the tax rolls of the County, at the address of such owner as therein shown. 
(Prior code,  6.06.120; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-1-160. - Hearing on assessment. 
    The owner may request a hearing before the City Council to contest the amount of the costs. Such request must be made in writing and be filed with the City within ten days of the date of mailing or service of the first statement to the owner. The owner shall be given at least two weeks' written notice of the date, time and place of any hearing scheduled. The decision of the City Council shall be final. If the statement remains unpaid, the amount shall be certified to the County Treasurer. 
(Prior code,  6.06.120; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-1-170. - Certified assessment. 
(a)  If, after the expiration of the period of time provided for in said notice, or as extended, costs or expenses are incurred by or on behalf of the City in the abatement or in connection with the abatement of the nuisance, and said costs are not otherwise collected, the Finance Director may thereafter certify the legal description of the property upon which such work was done, together with the name of the owner thereof as shown by the tax rolls of the County, together with a statement of the work performed, the date of performance and the costs thereof. 
(b)  The City Clerk shall mail a notice to the owner of said premises as shown by said tax roll, at the address shown upon the tax rolls, by certified mail, return receipt requested, notifying such owner that work has been performed pursuant to this Chapter, stating the date of performance of the work and the nature of the work, and demanding payment of the costs thereof, together with five percent assessment for inspection and other incidental costs in connection therewith. Such notice shall state that, if said amount is not paid within 30 days after mailing the notice, it shall become an assessment on and a lien against the property of the owner, describing the same, and will be certified as an assessment against such property, together with the ten-percent assessment for costs of collection, and the above-mentioned assessments will be collected in the same manner as a real estate tax upon the property. 
(c)  Each such assessment shall be a lien against each lot or tract of land until paid and shall have priority over other liens except general taxes and prior special assessments. 
(Prior code,  6.06.120; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-1-180. - Remedies cumulative and nonexclusive. 
(a)  No remedy provided herein shall be exclusive, but the same shall be cumulative, and the taking of any action hereunder, including charge or conviction of violation of this Chapter in the Municipal Court, shall not preclude or prevent the taking of other action hereunder to abate or enjoin any nuisance found to exist. 
(b)  Whenever a nuisance exists, no remedy provided for herein shall be exclusive of any other charge or action, and, when applicable, the abatement provisions of this Chapter shall serve as and constitute a concurrent remedy over and above any charge or conviction of any municipal offense or any other provisions of law. Any application of this Chapter that is in the nature of a civil action shall not prevent the commencement or application of any other charges brought under this Code or any other provision of law. 
(Prior code,  6.06.130; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-1-190. - Violation and penalties. 
(a)  Whenever the doing of any act is required, prohibited or declared to be unlawful and no definite fine or penalty is provided for a violation of this Chapter, any person who is convicted of a violation shall be subject to such penalties as are provided in Section 7-1-110 of this Article. 
(b)  Any person who has possession or control of any private ground or premises, whether or not he or she is the owner thereof, in or upon which any such nuisance exists or may be found, whether such nuisance has been heretofore or is hereafter created, shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense as the author of a nuisance for every period of 24 hours' continuance of such nuisance after due notice has been given to abate the same. 
(c)  Any violation or disobedience of any injunction or order issued by the Court in an action to abate a public nuisance shall be punished as a contempt of court by a fine of not more than $300.00 and imprisonment of not more than five days; but the Municipal Court may treat each day on which the violation or disobedience of any injunction order continues or recurs as a separate contempt. 
(d)  Fees; costs and fines; liens and collection. 
(1)  For seizing and closing any building or premises as provided in this Chapter, or for performing other duties pursuant to the direction of the Municipal Court pursuant to the provisions of this Chapter, the City shall be entitled to a reasonable sum fixed by the Municipal Court in addition to the actual costs incurred or expended. 
(2)  All fees and costs allowed by the provisions of this Section, the costs of a court action to abate any public nuisance and all fines levied by the Municipal Court in contempt proceedings incidental to any action to abate a public nuisance shall be a first and prior lien upon any real property seized or closed under the provisions of this Chapter, and the same shall be enforceable and collectible, by execution issued by order of the Municipal Court, from the property of any person liable therefor. 
(3)  Nothing in this Chapter shall be construed in such a manner as to destroy the validity of a bona fide lien upon real or personal property appearing of record prior to the recording of court orders involving real estate as authorized under this Chapter. 
(Prior code,  6.06.140; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 2 - Nuisances 

Sec. 7-2-10. - Nuisances generally. 
    Whenever there exists in or upon any lot or piece of ground within the limits of the City any damaged merchandise, litter, trash, rubbish, garbage, wrecked cars, inoperable cars or other wrecked vehicles or an accumulation of junk vehicles or junk of any type upon any private or public property, except in areas specifically zoned in Chapter 16 of this Code for said purposes or otherwise designated by the City for such purposes, the existence of any such material or items shall constitute a nuisance and shall be a violation of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-20. - Posting handbills, posters and placards. 
    Any handbill, poster, placard or painted or printed matter which is stuck, posted or pasted upon any public or private residence or other building or upon any fence, power pole, telephone pole or other structure without the permission of the owner, agent or occupant of the residence shall be deemed a nuisance and may be abated as provided in this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-30. - Open wells, cisterns or excavations. 
    Excavations exceeding five feet in depth, cisterns and wells or an excavation used for storage of water are public nuisances unless the same are adequately covered with a locked lid or other covering weighing at least 60 pounds, or are securely fenced with a solid fence to a height of at least five feet. It is unlawful for any person to permit such nuisance to remain on premises owned or occupied by him or her. Whenever a chemical analysis or other proper test or the location of any well or cistern on any property shows that the water of the well or cistern is probably contaminated, impure or unwholesome, such well or cistern shall be deemed a nuisance. Any abandoned or unused well or cistern shall be filled with dirt and covered. 
(Prior code,  6.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-40. - Streets, streams and water supply. 
(a)  No person shall throw or deposit, or cause or permit to be thrown or deposited, any ashes, putrid meats, decayed vegetables, offal from butcher shops, slops or offal from eating houses or saloons, kitchen offal or slops, manure or stable refuse, dead animals, carrion or any fleshy or vegetable matter subject to decay, contents of privy vaults, garbage, rubbish or any foul or nauseous substance or offensive matter upon any street, avenue, alley, sidewalk or public or private grounds. 
(b)  No person shall throw or deposit or cause or permit to be thrown or deposited in the City anything specified in any foregoing part of this Section, or any other substance that would tend to have a polluting effect, into the water of any stream, ditch, pond, well, cistern, trough or other body of water, whether artificially or naturally created, or so near any such place as to be liable to pollute the water. 
(Prior code,  6.10.020, 6.10.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-50. - Discharge of offensive materials. 
    It is a nuisance for any person to discharge or place any offensive water, liquid waste or refuse of any kind into any street, alley, sidewalk, gutter, stream, wash, natural watercourse, ditch, canal or any vacant lot which, as the result of continued discharge, will render the place of discharge offensive or likely to become so. 
(Prior code,  6.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-60. - Maintenance of water systems. 
    The maintenance of any drainage system, canal, ditch, conduit or other watercourse of any kind or nature, natural or artificial, in a manner so as to become so obstructed as to cause the water to back up and overflow therefrom or to become unsanitary, shall be deemed a nuisance. 
(Prior code,  6.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-70. - Stagnant ponds. 
(a)  Any cellar, vault, sewer, drain, place, property or premises within the City which is damp, unwholesome, nauseous, offensive or filthy, which is covered for any portion of the year with stagnant or impure water, which is in such condition so as to produce unwholesome or offensive odors or which is injurious to the public health, shall be deemed a nuisance. 
(b)  The permitting or maintaining of stagnant water on any lot or piece of ground within the City limits is hereby declared to be a nuisance. Every owner or occupant of a lot or piece of ground within the City is hereby required to drain or fill up said lot or piece of ground whenever the same is necessary so as to prevent stagnant water or other nuisances from accumulating thereon. 
(Prior code,  6.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-80. - Sewer inlet. 
    No person shall deposit in or throw into any sewer (sanitary or storm), sewer inlet or privy vault that has a sewer connection any article that might cause such sewer, sewer inlet or privy vault to become nauseous or offensive to others or injurious to public health. 
(Prior code,  6.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-90. - Polluted water. 
(a)  A swimming pool, pond or other body of water which is abandoned, unattended, unfiltered or not otherwise maintained, resulting in water becoming polluted, is hereby declared a nuisance. For the purposes of this Section, the term polluted water means water contained in a swimming pool, pond or other body of water which contains one or more of the following: bacterial growth, including algae; remains of insects; remains of deceased animals; reptiles; rubbish; feces; refuse; debris; papers; and any other foreign matter or material which, because of its nature or location, constitutes an unhealthy, unsafe or unsightly condition. 
(b)  Any unlawful pollution or contamination of any surface or subsurface waters in the City, of the air or of any water, substance or material intended for human consumption is declared a nuisance; however, no action shall be brought under this Section if the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment or any other agency of the State charged by and acting pursuant to state statute or duly adopted regulation has assumed jurisdiction by the institution of proceedings regarding the pollution or contamination. 
(Prior code,  6.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-100. - Nauseous liquids. 
    No person shall discharge or permit to be discharged out of or from or permit to flow from any house or property any foul or nauseous liquid or substance of any kind into or upon any adjacent ground or lot or into any street, alley or public place. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-110. - Stale matter. 
    No person shall keep, collect or use, or cause to be kept, collected or used, in the City any stale, putrid or stinking fat or grease or other stale matter, other than normal weekly trash accumulation. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-120. - Transporting garbage, manure. 
    Every vehicle or trailer used to transport manure, garbage, swill or offal on any street in the City shall be fitted with a substantially tight enclosed box thereon, so that no portion of such filth will be scattered or thrown into such street. 
(Prior code,  6.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-130. - Dead animal removal. 
    When any animal dies in the City, it shall be the duty of the owner or keeper thereof to promptly remove the body of such animal beyond the City limits If such body is not removed, the same shall be deemed a nuisance, and such owner or keeper will be the author of the nuisance. When the body of any such dead animal is in any street, highway or public grounds in the City, it shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to cause such body to be removed beyond the limits of the City. 
(Prior code,  6.10.050; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-140. - Unwholesome business. 
    Any offensive or unwholesome business or establishment, or any business or establishment carried on in a manner dangerous to the public health, safety or welfare within the City or within one mile beyond the outer limits of the City, is declared a nuisance. 
(Prior code,  6.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-150. - Storage of equipment. 
    The unsheltered storage of old, unused, stripped and junked machinery, implements or personal property of any kind which is no longer safely usable for the purposes for which it was manufactured, for a period of 30 days or more (except in licensed junkyards) within the City, is hereby declared a nuisance. 
(Prior code,  6.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-160. - Junkyards and dumping grounds. 
    All places used or maintained as junkyards or dumping grounds or for the wrecking or disassembling of automobiles, trucks, tractors, or machinery of any kind or for the storing or leaving of worn out, wrecked, inoperable or abandoned automobiles, trucks, tractors, trailers, boats and house trailers or machinery of any kind, or any of the parts thereof, or for the storing or leaving of any machinery or equipment used by contractors or builders or by other persons, which places essentially interfere with the comfortable enjoyment of life or property by others, are deemed a nuisance. 
(Prior code,  6.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-170. - Refuse, waste and junk. 
(a)  Refuse, waste matter and junk which, by reason of its location and character, is dangerous to public health, safety or welfare, is unsightly or interferes with the reasonable enjoyment of property by neighbors, detrimentally affects property values in the surrounding neighborhood community, or which would materially hamper or interfere with the prevention or suppression of fire upon the premises, is hereby declared a nuisance. Refuse, waste and junk include, but are not limited to: rubbish, refuse, debris, rubble, asphalt, concrete, plaster, tile, rocks, bricks, soil, crates, cartons, containers, boxes, inoperable machinery or parts thereof, scrap metal and other pieces of metal, whether ferrous or nonferrous, dead plants and trees, trimmings from plants and trees, cans, bottles, barrels, bones, rags, used rubber or used rope. 
(b)  Junk shall also include any material or object, used or new, which is not presently usable, including but not limited to: scrap metals and their alloys, bones, rags, cloth, rubber pieces, rope, tinfoil, bottles, tools, fixtures, utensils, lumber, boxes, crates, pipe or pipe fittings, automobile or airplane tires, machinery and appliances. Objects or material shall be considered junk if they are so worn, deteriorated or obsolete as to make them unusable in their existing condition, if they are not capable of being used in their present location on the property or if they cannot legally be used due to the absence of legal prerequisites to use. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person to store, keep or allow to be stored or kept any articles or materials which may be classified as junk according to the provisions contained in this Section adjacent to or in close proximity to any schoolhouse, church, public park or residence or in a zoning district prohibiting outdoor storage or processing of junk, unless such junk is kept in a proper enclosure. 
(d)  An enclosure will be considered proper for the storage of junk if it totally and completely encloses its contents on all sides and it effectively shields its contents from view of the public. Junk stored or kept in violation of this Section is declared to be a public nuisance and may be abated pursuant to the provisions specified in this Chapter. 
(Prior code,  6.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-180. - Noisemaking devices. 
(a)  Noisemaking devices on streets. The use of music, noisemakers or loudspeakers on the streets of the City for the sale or vending of products, advertising or other commercial purposes is hereby declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited by the terms of this Chapter. 
(b)  Noisemaking devices to attract children. The use of bells, whistles, sirens, music, horns or any other noisemaking devices for the purpose of attracting children or minors to any vehicle upon the streets, highways, rights-of-way, alleys or public ways of the City for the purpose of selling, distributing or giving away any product whatsoever to such minors is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and hazard, is expressly prohibited and shall be unlawful, except such activities carried on as part of duly authorized public parades or processions. 
(Prior code,  6.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-190. - Barking dogs. 
    Any dog which, by loud or frequent or habitual barking, yelping or howling, causes a serious annoyance to the neighborhood or to persons passing to and fro upon the streets or sidewalks is declared a nuisance. 
(Prior code,  6.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-200. - Junk vehicles on property. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to store, keep or permit to be stored or kept any junk vehicle, or parts thereof, on public or private property, unless in a fully enclosed structure. A fully enclosed structure will be considered proper for the storage of junk vehicles if it totally and completely shields its contents from view of the public, adjacent walkways, alleys or roadways. An example of a fully enclosed structure would be a garage or a privacy fence made of wood or other material approved by the City. For purposes of this Section, the term person means the owner of the vehicle or parts thereof, or the owner, manager, lessee or possessor of the property where the vehicle or parts are stored. 
(b)  The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this Section: 
    Antique vehicle means any vehicle, at least 25 years old, which is valued principally because of its early date of manufacture, design or historical interest or as a collector's item, and licensed as a collector's series or horseless carriage by the State or another state with similar license provisions. 
    Junk or derelict vehicle means any vehicle which is not capable of travel in its existing mechanical condition; any dismantled, partially dismantled, discarded, wrecked, demolished or partially demolished vehicle; any vehicle designed for highway travel not bearing a current registration plate; or any automobile, truck or self-propelled vehicle which does not comply with the minimum safety requirements of the Colorado Motor Vehicle Law. 
    Private property means real property which is owned by a private person or entity. 
    Vehicle means a machine pushed, pulled or propelled by power other than human power, designed to travel along the ground, in the air, through water or on roads or paths by use of wheels, treads, runners, slides, wings or hulls, and to transport persons or property or pull non-self-propelled vehicles or machinery, and includes, without limitation, automobile, airplane, boat, truck, trailer, motorcycle, motor scooter, moped, tractor, buggy or wagon. 
(Prior code,  6.06.030; Ord. No. 766,  A, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-210. - Dangerous structures. 
    Any building, fence, structure or land within the City, the condition of which presents a substantial danger or hazard to public health and safety, is hereby declared a nuisance. 
(Prior code,  6.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-220. - Broken windows in vacant dwellings. 
    It is declared a nuisance for the owner of any vacant building to fail to replace any broken window or fail to secure any other means of entry into such building within 72 hours after notice is given by the City. 
(Prior code,  6.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-230. - Maintenance of property. 
    It is a nuisance to own, lease, occupy, manage or have possession of any premises in the City in such manner that any of the following conditions are found to exist thereon: 
(1)  The premises are a detriment to public health, safety or general welfare. 
(2)  The premises are so defective, unsightly or in such condition of disrepair that they substantially diminish the value of surrounding property or are otherwise substantially detrimental to surrounding properties. Manifestation of this condition shall include, but not be limited to, the keeping on, the disposing of on or the scattering over the premises of any of the following: 
a.  Junk, trash or debris; 
b.  Abandoned, discarded or unusable objects or equipment, such as furniture, stoves, hot water heaters, refrigerators or freezers; 
c.  Stagnant water or an excavation; and 
d.  Any device, decoration, design, fence or structure which is unsightly by reason of its condition or its inappropriate location. 
(3)  The premises are so out of harmony or conformity with the maintenance standards of adjacent properties as to cause substantial diminution of the enjoyment, use or property values of such adjacent properties. 
(4)  The premises are abandoned, boarded up, partially destroyed or left unreasonable in a state of partial construction. 
(5)  Buildings have dry rot, warping or termite infestation. 
(6)  The premises have a substantial number of broken windows which cause hazardous conditions and invite trespassers and malicious mischief. 
(7)  The landscaping on the premises has not been maintained as follows: 
a.  The majority of plant materials have not been adequately irrigated and/or maintained and are dead or dying; 
b.  Lawns have grown over six inches or shrubs have not been trimmed and are overhanging public rights-of-way; 
c.  Noxious weeds have grown over six inches and have not been removed; or 
d.  Dead or diseased plantings have not been removed or replaced. 
(8)  The exterior of commercial establishments or multifamily buildings has not been maintained so as to present a neat and orderly appearance which is compatible with the area as follows: 
a.  A substantial number of windows are cracked or broken; 
b.  Painted surfaces are substantially cracked or peeling, or the paint has deteriorated to the point where the bare surface is substantially exposed; or 
c.  The building has otherwise not been substantially maintained. 
(9)  Parking lots have not been repaired or cracks, potholes or other breaks in the parking lot surface have not been filled. 
(10)  Any dilapidated building of whatever kind which is unused by the owner, or uninhabited because of a deterioration or decay, which condition constitutes a fire hazard or subjects adjoining property to danger of damage by storm, soil erosion or rodent infestation, or which becomes a place frequented by trespassers and transients seeking a temporary hideout or shelter. 
(11)  Permitting any garbage container to remain on a premises when it has become unclean, offensive or is injurious to the public health. 
(12)  Allowing vegetable or animal waste, garbage, litter, filth or refuse of any nature to accumulate within or upon any private alley, yard or area except when it is temporarily deposited for immediate removal. 
(13)  Permitting the accumulation of manure or feces in any stable, stall, corral, feed yard or any other building or area in which any animals are kept, including but not limited to domesticated animals. This provision does not apply to a light spread of manure upon lawns or gardens or which is plowed under the surface of the ground. 
(14)  Permitting any slaughterhouse, market, meat shop, stable, feed yard or other place or building wherein any animals are slaughtered, kept, fed or sold to remain unclean or in any state or condition detrimental to health or creating a nuisance because of odors, or in which flies or rodents breed. 
(15)  Keeping or collecting any stale or putrid grease of other offensive matter. 
(16)  Having or permitting upon any premises any fly-producing or mosquito-producing condition. 
(17)  Keeping any drinking vessels for public use without providing a method of decontamination between uses. 
(18)  Any toilet or sanitary sewer facilities not constructed and maintained in accordance with the ordinances of the City. 
(19)  Neglecting or refusing to discontinue use of, clean out, disinfect and fill up all privy vaults, septic tanks and cesspools or other individual wastewater disposal systems within 20 days after notice from the Code Enforcement Officer or any official of the City. 
(Prior code,  6.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-240. - Hazardous obstructions. 
    An obstacle, landscaping or thing installed or maintained in the sight triangle reaching a height of more than three feet above the adjoining top of curb at the applicable corner of the street intersection, or three feet above the nearest pavement surface where there is no curb, or the existing traveled roadway at the corner in question where there is no curb or pavement, is hereby declared a nuisance. Hazardous obstructions do not include existing or future permanent buildings otherwise constructed or maintained in accordance with applicable zoning and building regulations, public utility poles and trees trimmed at the trunk at least eight feet above the level of the ground surface, provided that such trees are spaced so that trunks do not obstruct the vision of motorists. 
(Prior code,  6.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-250. - Fire hazards. 
    Dry or dead shrubs, dead trees, combustible refuse and waste or any material growing on a street, sidewalk or upon private property within the City which, by reason of its size, manner of growth and location, constitutes a fire hazard to a building, improvement, crop or other property or, when dry, will in reasonable probability constitute a fire hazard, is hereby declared a nuisance. 
(Prior code,  6.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-260. - Public burning. 
(a)  No person shall set on fire or burn any garbage, rubbish or waste material or any hay, grass clippings or other combustible materials in any ash pit or other receptacle or upon the ground without a permit from the Fire Chief. 
(b)  Any smoke and odor resulting from the burning of refuse, trash or other materials, including but not limited to those materials outlined in this Subsection, are hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(Prior code,  6.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-2-270. - Continuing nuisance. 
    It is a nuisance for any building, land, premises, business, occupation or activity, operation or condition which, after being ordered abated, corrected or discontinued by lawful order of the City or any officer thereof, continues to be conducted or continues to exist in violation of: 
(1)  Any ordinance of this City; 
(2)  Any regulation enacted pursuant to the authority of an ordinance of this City. 
(Prior code,  6.06.030; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 3 - Junk Vehicles 

Sec. 7-3-10. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this Article: 
    Abandoned vehicle means any vehicle left within the limits of any street, road, highway or alley or upon property of another without the consent of the owner of such property for a period of 24 hours or longer. A vehicle shall not be considered abandoned if its owner or operator is unable to remove it from the place where it is located and so notifies law enforcement officials and requests assistance; thus, a properly licensed operable vehicle shall not be considered abandoned if the vehicle is parked in a legal manner within a designated parking space. 
    Costs means the expenses of removing, storing or selling a junked vehicle. 
    Fully enclosed structure means an enclosure which is totally and completely enclosed on all sides and which effectively shields its contents from view of the public, adjacent walkways, roadways and alleys. An example of a fully enclosed structure would be a garage, a privacy fence (made of wood or another material approved by the City) or an opaque, commercially fitted vehicle cover that covers the vehicle from bumper to bumper. 
    Hobby means the repairing, reconditioning or rebuilding of vehicles that is done for personal enjoyment or entertainment, with no profits, compensation or reimbursement of any kind involved. 
    Hobby-type vehicle includes, but is not limited to, a vehicle which has been modified for off-road use or is made for off-road use, such as a stock car racer, dune buggy or ATV. 
    Junk vehicle means any vehicle which is not capable of travel in its existing mechanical condition; any dismantled, partially dismantled, discarded, wrecked, demolished or partially demolished vehicle; or any vehicle designed for highway travel not bearing a current license plate or license certificate. 
    Major recreational vehicle includes, but is not limited to, boats, boat trailers, travel trailers, pickup campers or coaches (designed to be mounted on automotive vehicles), motorized dwellings (motor homes), tent trailers and the like, and cases or boxes used for transporting recreational equipment, whether occupied by such equipment or not. 
    Vehicle means a machine that is pushed, pulled or propelled by power other than human power, designed to travel along the ground, in the air, through water or on roads or paths by use of wheels, treads, runners, slides, wings or hulls, and which is used to transport persons or property or pull non-self-propelled vehicles of machinery. The term vehicle includes, without limitation, automobile, airplane, boat, truck, trailer, motorcycle, motor scooter, moped, tractor, buggy or wagon. 
(Prior code,  6.04.010; Ord. No. 765,  1, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-3-20. - Junk, abandoned and/or unlicensed vehicles prohibited. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to leave any junk, derelict, abandoned and/or unlicensed vehicle, or any parts thereof, on any public street, alley or highway within the City. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to store, keep or place any junk, derelict, abandoned and/or unlicensed vehicle, or any parts thereof, upon any public or private property within the City. It is also unlawful, as owner, occupant, landlord, tenant or party in control of any real property within the City, to permit or allow any junk, derelict, abandoned and/or unlicensed vehicle, or any parts thereof, to be placed or kept on any private property within the City, except and unless it is in a fully enclosed structure, completely concealed behind a privacy fence and/or completely covered bumper-to-bumper with a fitted opaque cover. 
(c)  Exceptions: 
(1)  Any vehicle registered as a collector's item by the State under the provisions of Sections 42-15-101 and 42-15-102, C.R.S., provided that such vehicles are maintained in such a manner that they do not constitute a health hazard, a safety hazard or a fire hazard and are contained in a fully enclosed structure, completely concealed behind a privacy fence and/or covered bumper-to-bumper with a fitted opaque cover. No more than two collector vehicles shall be maintained on private property. 
(2)  Vehicles stored or kept on the premises of a business enterprise operated in a lawful place and in a lawful zoning district and in a lawful manner when necessary to the operation of such business enterprise, provided that any dismantled, discarded, wrecked, demolished or partially demolished vehicles are stored in a fully enclosed structure. 
(Prior code,  6.04.030; Ord. No. 765,  1, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-3-30. - Parking and storage of major recreational vehicles and hobby type vehicles. 
(a)  No major recreational vehicle and/or equipment shall be parked or stored for more than seven consecutive days on any public street or property that is not designated for that specific use. 
(b)  Visitors may use their motor homes and campers for no more than three weeks if the units are parked on private property. No such equipment shall be used for living, sleeping or housekeeping purposes when parked or stored on a residential lot or in any location not approved for such use. 
(c)  All hobby-type vehicles shall be stored in a fully enclosed structure, totally concealed behind a privacy fence and/or completely covered with a fitted opaque cover. 
(Ord. No. 765,  1, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-3-40. - Hobby repair work. 
    It is unlawful for any person to repair, keep or work on any junk vehicle as a hobby unless such hobby is conducted in and totally contained within a fully enclosed structure and conducted in such a manner so as not to create a safety, health or fire hazard; except that this shall not apply to minor repair and maintenance activities, such as, by way of illustration, the changing of oil, sparkplugs or tires, so long as said minor work does not exceed a period of 24 hours. Repair of vehicles purchased for repair and resale or vehicles repaired for any compensation received shall be considered an auto repair business, not a hobby. 
(Prior code,  6.04.040; Ord. No. 765,  1, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-3-50. - Auto repair business. 
    It is unlawful for any person to engage in a vehicle repair business on residential premises or premises zoned for residential use under Chapter 16 of this Code. A person shall be deemed to be in the vehicle repair business if he or she undertakes the repair of any vehicles belonging to other persons, or if he or she has purchased any vehicles for repair and resale or any other vehicles other than those used regularly by himself or herself or his or her family. The presence of any vehicles on residential property which are undergoing repairs and which are not owned by and registered in the name of the occupant of the premises shall be deemed a prima facie violation of this Section. As used in this Section, the word person shall include any person actually engaged in such automobile repair and the occupant of the premises upon which the repair has occurred. 
(Prior code,  6.04.050; Ord. No. 765,  1, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-3-60. - Investigation. 
    The Chief of Police is hereby authorized to investigate any matter at any place within the City which reasonably appears to be in violation of the provisions of this Article. 
(Prior code,  6.04.060; Ord. No. 765,  1, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-3-70. - Notice. 
    If, after an investigation, there is probable cause for believing a violation of this Chapter exists, a written warning shall be placed on the vehicle or property. Such written warning shall include the violation involved, the date and time of violation, the signature of the issuing officer and a time limit in accordance with the following Paragraphs: 
(1)  Junk vehicles: 24 hours if the violation is on the street; 90 days if the violation is on private property. 
(2)  Abandoned vehicles: seven days to correct or remove the cause of the violation. 
    For the purpose of this Section, the tenant, occupant or lessee shall be deemed the agent of the owner of the premises. 
(Prior code,  6.04.070; Ord. No. 765,  1, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-3-80. - Issuance of summons and complaint. 
    If, after the time prescribed from the time of issuance of the warning of the violation, the cause of such violation has not been removed or corrected as set forth in Section 7-3-20 or 7-3-30 above, a summons and complaint shall be issued to the person named on the written warning unless satisfactory arrangements for an extension of the time have been made with the Code Enforcement Officer. The summons shall contain at a minimum the following information: the vehicle, by make, year and model, if possible, and location. In the event that the owner of the vehicle or his or her agent, manager, tenant, resident, lessee, renter or occupant of the premises on which such vehicle is located cannot be located in order to serve such notice of violation, then a summons and complaint shall be issued against the vehicle. Said summons and complaint shall be firmly attached to the vehicle, or parts thereof, in plain sight. 
(Prior code,  6.04.080; Ord. No. 765,  1, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-3-90. - Effecting removal. 
    The Code Enforcement Officer or the Police Department is hereby empowered and authorized to remove and impound vehicles, or parts thereof, from any public street, alley or other public place or from private property in any of the following circumstances: 
(1)  Upon failure, neglect or refusal of any person notified pursuant to Section 7-3-70 above to properly remove the cause of said violation from the City, to place it in a fully enclosed structure or to correct the violation within the time limits stated hereinabove. 
(2)  When any abandoned vehicle is found on public or private property. 
(3)  When any vehicle is parked in such a position that it constitutes an obstruction to traffic or is unlawfully parked in any prohibited or restricted area; is parked or so used as to endanger or be likely to endanger any user or potential user of any public highway; or is in violation of the traffic ordinances of the City or of any rule or regulation promulgated in connection therewith by the Chief of Police, acting in conjunction with the City Council. 
(Prior code,  6.04.090; Ord. No. 765,  1, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-3-100. - Penalty. 
    Any person convicted of violating any portion of this Article shall be punished in accordance with Section 1-4-20 of this Code. 
(Prior code,  6.04.100; Ord. No. 765,  1, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-3-110. - Costs. 
(a)  All costs incurred by the City for the removal and storage of a vehicle, or parts thereof, shall be assessed to the owner and become a lien on the vehicle. Such costs shall include a sum as set forth in the City's Fee Schedule for the administrative expenses of the City plus the costs charged by the company for towing and storing the vehicle. 
(b)  In case the owner or agent of the owner of such property fails to pay such costs within 30 days after a statement therefor has been rendered, the Chief of Police shall order the vehicle disposed of as an abandoned vehicle under Section 42-4-1801, et seq., C.R.S. 
(c)  The City Council is hereby authorized to modify by resolution any costs, fees or fines set forth in this Article. 
(Prior code,  6.04.110; Ord. No. 765,  1, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-3-120. - No remedy exclusive. 
(a)  No remedy provided herein shall be exclusive, but the same shall be cumulative. 
(b)  It is not the policy or purpose of this Article to repeal or preempt any other provision of this Code. 
(Prior code,  6.04.120; Ord. No. 765,  1, 9-12-2000; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 4 - Garbage and Refuse 

Sec. 7-4-10. - Accumulation of refuse prohibited. 
    Any accumulation of refuse or other material on any premises, improved or unimproved, in the City is prohibited and is hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-4-20. - Responsibility for refuse on premises. 
    It is the duty of every person, whether owner, lessee or renter of any vacant lot, building or premises, including any place of business, hotel, restaurant, dwelling house, apartment, tenement or any other establishment, at all times to maintain the premises in a clean and orderly condition, permitting no deposit or accumulation of refuse or materials other than those ordinarily attendant upon the use for which such premises are legally intended. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-4-30. - Disposal of rubbish upon public places prohibited. 
    Any person who throws into any street, alley or vacant lot in the City any wrapping paper, waste paper, old clothes, shoes, hats, bottles, broken glassware or pieces of board, or anyone who sweeps from his or her place of business any straw, paper, filth or litter, shall be deemed the author of a nuisance and, upon conviction, shall be fined. 
(Prior code,  6.10.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-4-40. - Removal of refuse from business. 
    Discarded refuse, including automobile parts, stoves, furniture and junkyard refuse, shall be removed periodically by the proprietor so that the premises are clean and orderly at all times. Silt and similar deposits from automobile wash racks shall be removed by the establishment creating such deposit. Any accumulation of refuse that is highly explosive or flammable which might endanger life or property shall be removed to such places as approved by the Chief of Police or the Fire Chief. Such removal shall be handled by the establishment responsible therefor. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-4-50. - Recovery of costs for removal of nuisances by City. 
    For the purpose of carrying out the provisions of this Article, City officials shall have power to proceed in all cases as prescribed in this Code and by law, whenever any nuisance is abated at the expense of the City after notice to the owner of such premises upon which such nuisance is found or of the author of such nuisance, by suit as in actions of debt. 
(Prior code,  6.10.060; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-4-60. - Disposal of harmful materials in streets, alleys, etc., prohibited. 
    It is unlawful to throw or otherwise deposit ashes, garbage, cans, glass, papers or any other offensive matter or any matter which would cause injury to any street, alley, avenue or public ground in the City. 
(Prior code,  6.10.090; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-4-70. - Penalty. 
    Any person convicted of violation of any provision of this Article shall be punished by a fine in accordance with the provisions of Section 7-1-190 of this Chapter. 
(Prior code,  6.10.100; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 5 - Weeds and Brush 

Sec. 7-5-10. - Noxious Weed Management Advisory Board. 
(a)  A Noxious Weed Local Advisory Board is hereby established and shall be known as the "Rocky Ford Noxious Weed Local Advisory Board" (the "Board"). 
(b)  Membership of the Board shall be the same as the membership of the City Council and Mayor. 
(c)  Whenever the City Council meets, it shall also be in session as the Rocky Ford Noxious Weed Local Advisory Board. 
(d)  The Mayor shall serve as the Chairperson of the Board. 
(e)  The City Clerk shall serve as the Secretary of the Board but shall not be a member of the Board. 
(f)  The duties and responsibilities of the Board are: 
(1)  The Board shall develop a management plan for the integrated management of designated noxious weeds and recommended management criteria for noxious weeds within the area governed by the City. 
(2)  The Board shall review the management plan at regular intervals but not less often than once every three years. 
(3)  The Board shall have the power to declare noxious weeds and any state noxious weeds designated by rule to be subject to integrated management. 
(4)  The Board may require identified landowners to submit an individual integrated management plan to manage noxious weeds on their property and shall have the sole and final authority to approve, modify or reject the submitted management plan. 
(Ord. No. 817, 11-8-2005; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-5-20. - Declaration of nuisance. 
    It is unlawful for any person owning, occupying or using any lot or property to allow weeds, brush or rubbish to accumulate on said lot or property, including the sidewalk area in front of or alley behind said lot or property. 
(Prior code,  6.12.070; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-5-30. - Duty of property owner to cut. 
    It shall be the duty of every person owning, occupying or using any lot or property, including the sidewalk area in front of or any alley behind such lot or property, to remove all weeds, brush and rubbish therefrom. 
(Prior code,  6.12.010; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-5-40. - Yearly removal required. 
    Every person, as mentioned in Section 7-5-30 above, shall remove all weeds, brush and rubbish from the lot or property, sidewalk area in front of and the alley behind the lot or property, and shall keep such lot or property free from such weeds, brush and rubbish at all times during the year. 
(Prior code,  6.12.020; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-5-50. - Notice of failure to remove weeds and rubbish. 
    If such weeds, brush and rubbish are not removed from the lot or property, the Fire Chief, City Manager, Chief of Police or Code Enforcement Officer may serve notice of such failure. Such notice shall be complete upon personal service of it upon any resident or person at the premises, by handing the same to any resident 15 years of age or over at the premises, by affixing the same to the door of any improvement or building on the premises or, if the property is unimproved, by posting the same in a conspicuous place on the property. Such notice shall be dated, shall state that, if such weeds, brush and rubbish are not removed within five days after the notice, the City may remove the same at the expense of the property, property owner, possessor or user. 
(Prior code,  6.12.030; Ord. No. 740,  1, 9-22-1998; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-5-60. - Removal by City and recording of removal costs. 
    After such five-day period, the City may proceed to remove such weeds, brush or rubbish from the premises. The City shall assess the entire cost of removal to the person who owns, possesses or occupies such property. The costs shall include the following: 
(1)  The amount as set forth in the City's Fee Schedule per man-hour for removal; 
(2)  An administrative fee as set forth in the City's Fee Schedule; 
(3)  Equipment costs at standard billed rates; and 
(4)  An inspection fee of five percent of the costs listed in Paragraphs (1) through (3) above. 
(Prior code,  6.12.040; Ord. No. 740,  2, 9-22-1998; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-5-70. - Assessment of lien on property; publication of notice. 
    The amount of such assessments shall be a lien on the property, and notice thereof shall be given by publication once in a newspaper of general circulation in the City. Said notice shall contain a description of the property upon which the lien is claimed, the name of the owner and the amount of the lien. 
(Prior code,  6.12.050; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-5-80. - Penalty for nonpayment. 
    If said assessment is not paid within 60 days, the same may be certified by the City Clerk to the County Treasurer for collection, together with a ten-percent penalty, in the same manner as other taxes are collected. 
(Prior code,  6.12.060; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-5-90. - Violation. 
    In addition to the notice and penalty provisions set forth above, any person violating any of the provisions of this Article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and each such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof during which any violation of any of the provisions of this Article is committed, continued or permitted. Upon conviction of any such violation, such person shall be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000.00. 
(Prior code,  6.12.080; Ord. No. 740,  3, 9-22-1998; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 6 - Trees 

Sec. 7-6-10. - Prohibited trees. 
(a)  It is unlawful and deemed a nuisance to sell or import into the City or plant or cause to be planted within the City limits any female box-elder tree ( Acer negundo ), female cottonwood trees ( Populus spices ), Siberian elm ( Ulmus pumila ) or other undesirable plants as designated by ordinance upon any property within the City, and the planting or setting out of these certain plants is declared to be a menace to public health, safety and welfare and a public nuisance. 
(b)  The owner of any property within the City, upon which any tree listed in Subsection (a) above has been planted after the effective date of the ordinance codified herein, shall cut and remove such tree from his or her property after being given two days' written notice to do so by the City. 
(c)  In case of the failure of any owner of such property to cut and remove such tree as required in Subsection (b) above, the City shall cut and remove such tree. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-6-20. - Trees and limbs in public right-of-way. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner of any property adjacent to the public right-of-way to remove any trees or limbs located in or above the public right-of-way when such trees or limbs constitute a danger to public safety. Such trees and limbs shall constitute a nuisance. For the purposes of this Section, a danger to public safety shall include all trees and limbs which hinder visibility or which may otherwise affect public health, safety and welfare, and trees and limbs which present a structural defect which may cause the tree or limb to fall on a person or on property of value. 
(Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-6-30. - Control of trees and shrubs. 
(a)  The City Council shall have the power to promulgate, amend and repeal rules, regulations and specifications for the trimming, spraying, removal, planting, pruning and protection of trees, shrubs, vines, hedges and other plants within the City limits. 
(b)  The City Council shall have the responsibility to cause to be inspected all trees, shrubs, vines, hedges or other plants upon any property within the City limits. 
(c)  The City Council hereby finds, determines and declares that the existence within the City of Dutch elm disease and other tree diseases, together with other insect pests or disease, constitutes a threat to the forestry of the City and endangers the health, safety and welfare of all inhabitants of the City. In order to control or eradicate said threat, the City Manager shall make investigation and determination as the City Council deems necessary for the protection of all trees, shrubs, vines, hedges or other plants upon any property within the City limits, and shall further spray or cause to be sprayed all trees, shrubs, vines, hedges or other plants located upon any premises owned, controlled or occupied by any person within the City, including premises owned, controlled or occupied by the City or any other governmental agency, with such materials in such manner or at such time, at least annually, in the control of elm beetles or any other pest or disease which may exist in or be a threat to the forestry of the City. 
(d)  The City Council shall have the power to require the owner of any property or the owner of any property abutting on any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place to: 
(1)  Remove any dead or diseased tree, shrub, vine, hedge or other plant. 
(2)  Remove any dead overhanging boughs determined to be dangerous to life, limb or property located on the premises of the owner or upon any public or private property abutting the premises of the owner. 
(3)  Trim, spray, prune or remove any tree, shrub, vine, hedge or other plant which may be determined to be a nuisance or to be dangerous to life, limb or property located on the premises of the owner or upon any public or private property abutting the premises of the owner; or which may be determined to interfere with or obstruct the movement or traffic or pedestrians, or construction and maintenance of utility lines, or obstruct the lights from any street lamp. 
(e)  The City Council shall cause notice to be given to the owner of any property, which notice shall state the date of investigation, the person conducting the investigation, the results thereof and the mandatory action required to abate the nuisance or alleviate the danger. Such notice shall be sent in writing, addressed to the owner if known, and, if not known, then to the occupant, and if there is no occupant, then to the last known address of the last reported owner as shown by the records of the County Treasurer. Notice shall be sent by certified U.S. mail and shall be effective upon the date of mailing. Such notice shall grant a period of 20 days to accomplish the remedial action required. 
(f)  In the event the owner or occupant of any premises fails or neglects to comply with the notice provided herein, the City Council is authorized to take the action required by such notice at the expense of the owner, agent or occupant of such property, which expense shall be collected as hereinafter provided. 
(g)  The costs of spraying and insect control incurred pursuant to this Section shall be defrayed by the assessment of a monthly fee as set forth in the City's Fee Schedule, to be billed monthly in advance as part of the water bill of each water recipient within the City limits. 
(h)  The costs of other tree care incurred pursuant to this Section shall be and are hereby assessed upon the lots and tracts of land where the trees are located. After completion of such other tree care, the City Engineer shall prepare and send to the City Clerk a schedule showing the description of the lots and tracts of land upon which the trees are located and cared for, the costs thereof and the names of the owners thereof. Upon receipt of the schedule, the City Clerk shall assess costs of such tree care to the owner of the tract of land. The amount so assessed shall be a lien in the amounts assessed against each lot or tract of land until the same is paid, and the same shall have priority over other liens, except general taxes and prior special assessments. Such assessment must be paid within 30 days from the time the assessment is made. 
(Prior code,  2.06.070; Ord. No. 767,  1, 11-28-2000; Ord. No. 790,  1, 11-25-2003; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-6-40. - Penalty. 
(a)  In case any assessment due and payable under this Article, except that set forth in Subsection 7-6-30(g) above, is not paid within 30 days from the date the assessment is made, the City Clerk shall certify the same to the County Treasurer, to be placed by him or her upon the tax rolls of the current year and to be collected in the same manner as other taxes are collected, with a ten-percent penalty thereon to defray the cost of collection. 
(b)  The maintenance of untreated elm trees and bushes upon any premises on or after May 15 of any calendar year is hereby declared to be a misdemeanor, and any person owning, controlling or occupying any premises upon which such untreated elm trees or elm bushes are in existence shall be guilty of a violation and, upon conviction thereof, may be fined. 
(Prior code,  2.06.070; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
ARTICLE 7 - Animals 
Division 1 - General Provisions 

Sec. 7-7-10. - Purpose. 
    The City Council declares that the purpose of this Article is to provide for the control of rabies for the protection and control of animals within the City, and that those matters are in the interest of the public health, welfare and safety. 
(Ord. No. 882,  5.01.010, 7-10-2012; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-7-20. - Title. 
    This Article is known and may be cited as the "Rocky Ford Animal Care and Control Ordinance." When citing the provisions of this Article in any summons, subpoena, pleading, summons and complaint or other document, it shall be sufficient to make reference to the Rocky Ford Animal Care and Control Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 882,  5.01.020, 7-10-2012; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-7-30. - Recordkeeping requirements. 
(a)  The Chief of Police shall keep accurate and detailed records of the impoundment and disposition of all animals coming into custody of the Police Department or animal shelter, and of all reports of animal bites reported to the Police Department. 
(b)  The City Clerk shall keep a complete and accurate record of all registrations and City rabies tags issued by the City pursuant to Division 2 of this Article and may designate a place at which duplicate originals of those records shall be maintained. 
(Ord. No. 882,  5.01.030, 5.04.070, 7-10-2012; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-7-40. - Authorization to enforce. 
    The provisions of this Article shall be enforceable by the Code Enforcement Officer or a member of the Police Department. If an animal is impounded, the Code Enforcement Officer or a police officer may institute proceedings in the Municipal Court on behalf of the City against the owner, charging the owner with a violation of the appropriate section of this Article or other applicable law. The Code Enforcement Officer and a police officer shall be authorized to issue, sign and serve summonses and complaints and to make all determinations within their discretion in compliance with the provisions of this Article. Nothing contained in this Section shall be construed as preventing the Code Enforcement Officer or a police officer from instituting a proceeding in the Municipal Court for violations of this Article or other applicable law where there has been no impoundment. 
(Ord. No. 882,  5.01.040, 7-10-2012; Ord. No. 914,  1, 2-9-2016) 
Sec. 7-7-50. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this Article, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise, the following words and terms are defined as set forth in this Section. 
    Animal means any living creature, domesticated or wild, other than a human being. 
    Animal owner means any person who has attained the age of eight years who owns, keeps, harbors, allows to remain about his or her premises or otherwise has custody or control of any animal in the City, whether individually or in conjunction with others, for any length or duration of time, whether such person is a resident or nonresident of the City. The parent, guardian or custodian of any child under the age of eight years who owns, keeps, harbors or has custody of any animal shall be deemed to be the owner of such animal. This definition shall not include the Code Enforcement Officer, animal control officers and police officers while acting in accordance with their official duties under this Article. 
    Cat means any domesticated animal of the species Felis catus or Felis domesticus . 
    Code Enforcement Officer means any officer or employee of the City designated by the City to enforce the provisions of this Article, whether or not that person is a certified law enforcement official, including but not limited to animal control officers and police officers. 
    Commercial kennel means any establishment or other place where one or more animals, either temporarily or permanently, are bred, born, raised, boarded, trained, kept or fed for money or any other consideration, or for sale. 
    Dog means any domesticated animal of the species Canis familaris . 
    Guard dog means any dog disciplined to protect persons and/or property by attacking or threatening to attack any person found within the area authorized to be patrolled by such dog. 
    Harbor means the act of keeping or caring for an animal or providing premises to which the animal returns for food, shelter or care. 
    Leash means a substantial chain, cord, rope or similar device sufficient to hold in restraint the animal to which it is attached. 
    Pet means any domesticated animal intended for human company and enjoyment. 
    Pet kennel means any person engaged in the business of breeding, buying, selling or boarding animals of any species. 
    Pet shop means any commercial establishment engaged in the buying and selling of a variety of pets.
